rationale: This species is considered to be Vulnerable at the Global, European and EU 28 levels. It is restricted to forest fragments in Sardinia (Italy). Since this species was first identified in 2002, it has been captured in only three localities, two in the same National Park. The population is probably very small, although more localities will probably be discovered in the future. Forests in Sardinia sum up to less than 2,000 km<sup>2</sup>, and their quality is declining.
habitat: The Sardinian Long-eared Bat occurs in the most wooded areas parts of Sardinia, and roosts in natural caves. Two of the three known localities are situated in karstic areas, one locality lies near the sea coast (Mucedda et al. 2002). Artificial habitats are not used. It is a sedentary species.
threats: Roost disturbance (as a result of tourism) and habitat loss (caused by forestry management) are the main threats to the species.
population: This species was first described in 2002 and is poorly known. It is considered to be rare.
range: The Sardinian Long-eared Bat (Plecotus sardus) is restricted to the island of Sardinia (Italy). The three known localities are situated near to the coast or at low elevations.
conservationActions: It is protected by national legislation in most range states. There are also international legal obligations for its protection through the Bonn Convention (Eurobats) and Bern Convention. It is included in Annex IV of EU Habitats & Species Directive. Two of the three known localities are in the National Park of Gennargentu and the Orosei Gulf. Recommended research actions include surveys and monitoring to determine distribution, status, and population trend. Protection of roosting and foraging habitat is also recommended.

rationale: This species is assessed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a broad range of habitats, presumed large population, and the absence of major threats.
habitat: This is a highly adaptable species that is often associated with arid to moist sandy, open areas or places with sparse scrub. It is found in coastal dunes and stabilized vegetated dunes further inland, and it is also found in orchards, vineyards, fields, oases, rural gardens and urban areas. This terrestrial species is found close to ground cover such as stones and vegetation. In West Africa it is found along the River Niger, in the Sahel and in the most humid areas of the Sahara, in areas with relatively dense vegetation (Trape et al. 2012). It is largely nocturnal in the summer and diurnal in the winter. Females give birth to between two and six or seven fully formed live young. Animals feed on small insects (Trape et al. 2012). The two known Turkmen localities are from montane situations, one from a small stream gorge.
threats: There are no major threats to this species.
population: It is a very common species in many parts of its range. Some sub-populations are expanding with land reclamation in arid areas, and the species is well able to colonize new areas wherever it is introduced. It is known from only two localities in Turkmenistan, each represented by a single specimen, one in the central Kopet Dagh Mountains and one on the Badkhyz Plateau.
range: This very widespread species occurs in northern and northeastern Africa and West Asia, and in a few parts of southern Europe. In Africa, it ranges from central Mauritania and Western Sahara (where it is known from one Western Saharan and two, disjunct, Mauritanian records, but is presumed to be more widespread), southern, central and northeastern Morocco, Melilla and the Chafarinas Archipelago (Spain), through northern Algeria, Tunisia and northern Libya to northern Egypt, and south along the Nile Valley to Sudan. Isolated sub-populations are known from Mali, Chad, Niger, southern Algeria and Somalia. In West Asia it occurs in western and southern Turkey, western Syria, Lebanon, Israel, western and eastern Jordan, coastal parts of the Arabian Peninsula (in Saudi Arabia, Yemen, Oman, United Arab Emirates, Qatar, and Kuwait), and in Iraq, Iran, and southern Turkmenistan to western Pakistan. It is "doubtfully indigenous" in the latter two territories, and in coastal Iran (Sindaco and Jeremçenko 2008). In Europe, it is present in Italy (on the islands of Sardinia, Sicily, Lampedusa, Linosa, Lampione and Conigli; with mainland populations near to Naples), Malta, and a few parts of mainland Greece (and the islands of Crete, Chios, Kea, Euboea, Rhodes and Karpathos). It also occurs on Cyprus. It is found from sea level up to 2,500 m asl (Morocco). Records from Eritrea, Ethiopia and Kenya are now referred to other species. The isolated subpopulations in Mauritania's Adrar region, the Air Mountains, and in Mali along the Niger Loop are considered relictual (Trape et al. 2012). An introduced population may have become established in the USA, where it was first collected in Florida in 1999 (Krysko et al. 2011), and it is likely to have become established in Italy (Krauss 2009).
useTrade: It is collected from the wild for the pet trade, but is also commonly bred in Europe for this purpose.
conservationActions: This species is listed on the Berne Convention. It occurs in a number of protected areas, including both of the known localities in Turkmenistan. It is in the Red Data Book for Turkmenistan. Research is needed to resolve the taxonomy of this possible species complex (S. Baha El Din pers. comm.).

rationale: Listed as Least Concern because it is widespread, common, and there is no evidence of threats or a substantial decline.
habitat: In Pakistan it has been recorded in dry, rocky places. It is generally not found in houses (Minton 1966). Its typical habitat is cliffs, dry areas and scrub, and it can also be found in caves.
threats: There are not thought to be any threats other than localized stone quarrying.
population: In Iran it is known only from a single, possibly translocated specimen. It is locally common in India, with no indication of decline (Vyas pers. comm. 2019). It was reported to be common in Kutch in the original description.
range: This species is distributed in Kutch, southeast of Sind (Pakistan) in immediately adjacent India, and coastal Las Bela in Pakistan. In Iran it is known from a single record from Bushire in Fars Province, which may be a misidentification or a translocated animal (Anderson 1999). There are records from Jessore and Chotila in Gujarat and Mount Abu in Rajasthan (Vyas pers. comm. 2019).
useTrade: There is not suspected to be any substantial use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Further studies are needed into the record of this species from Iran.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, it occurs in a number of protected areas, has a tolerance of a degree of habitat modification, and because it is unlikely to be declining.
habitat: It is found on rocky limestone, sandstone and volcanic hills (with pistachio savanna-type vegetation) and in caves (Ščerbak and Golubev 1986 [1996], Anderson 1999). It can be found in anthropogenic landscapes, but favours rocky situations and is not found in larger settlements or in cities. The females lay clutches of one or two eggs.
threats: There are no major threats to this adaptable and widespread species as a whole. It is likely to occur in protected areas in Iran.
population: It is common within suitable habitat.  The population is presumed to be stable.
range: This species is present in eastern Iran (Khorasan and Baluchistan). It is thought likely to occur in Afghanistan, but Wagner et al. (2016) report only Tenuidactylus voraginosus for this country. It may occur further west in Iran, but data are lacking (R. Nazarov pers. comm. 2016). It occurs from 760 to 900 m asl.
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species has been included in the USSR and Turkmenistan Red Data Books. It may be present in protected areas in Iran.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern because, although it is seldom recorded, it has a relatively wide distribution, is tolerant of a broad range of habitats, and because no major threats have been identified.
habitat: This snake occurs in tropical dry deciduous forest from plains to low hills. In Odisha, a specimen was observed on a coconut tree (at 6 m) close to mangrove forest, in Bhitarkanika Wildlife Sanctuary, and is also known from within mangroves. In Sri Lanka it has been recorded from dry and intermediate forests, grassland and home gardens (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. 2019). It has been recorded from leaf litter. It is a nocturnal and an arboreal snake and reportedly a good climber (Whitaker and Captain 2004). It is often found in houses looking for gecko prey and their eggs (Whitaker and Captain 2004). It can also be found in caves and rock piles (Narayanan and Mohapatra pers. comm. 2019).
threats: It is not known whether any threats to this species exist in India. It appears tolerant to a degree of habitat modification, however it is generally killed on sight by people when they encounter it (mistaking it for a venomous species). In Sri Lanka, it is impacted by loss and fragmentation of forest habitat (typically through conversion to agricultural use), and forest fires.
population: Although widespread, this species has been reported to be rare in areas where it occurs (Whitaker and Captain 2004). In India, there is no information on population trends, as it has been found only opportunistically (Ghosh pers. comm. 2019). It is an uncommon species in Sri Lanka with declining populations (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. 2019).
range: This snake is endemic to India and Sri Lanka. In India, it is known from multiple localities in Tamil Nadu, Andhra Pradesh, Odisha, Karnataka and Kerala (Boulenger 1893, Ferguson 1895, Wall 1920, Whitaker and Captain 2004), and Pondicherry (A. Ghosh pers. comm. 2019). It is present throughout the dry zone of Sri Lanka (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. 2019). It is found at elevations of sea level to around 1,200 m asl. (N.S. Achyuthan pers. comm. 2019).
useTrade: The species is not in use.
conservationActions: This species is listed on Schedule IV of the Indian Wildlife (Protection) Act, 1972. It occurs in many protected areas. Further survey work is needed to understand its taxonomy, distribution, biology, ecology, population status and threats.

rationale: This species has an EOO of < 20,000 km<sup>2</sup> and it is found on three, or possibly four, of the Canary Islands, which are each considered to be a single location based on the threat of habitat decline. It is linked to forest habitats that are shrinking, and recent declines have been recorded in the largest known breeding colony. For these reasons, it is classified as Vulnerable (VU B1ab(iii,v)).
habitat: The Canary Big-eared Bat (Plecotus teneriffae) is highly associated with woodland habitats (coniferous and mixed), although it occasionally forages in more open and arid areas. Its diet consists primarily of moths. Recorded roost sites include volcanic tubes, caves, and crevices in abandoned buildings (Trujillo 2002). Tree holes and bat or bird boxes are never used (Benzal and Fajardo 1999). The La Palma maternity colony is located in a natural cave. This species is considered to be sedentary (Fajardo and Benzal 2002 in Hutterer et al. 2005).
threats: The population declined in the 1950s after aerial fumigation for pest control. Current threats include disturbance of colonies in their roosts, use of pesticides on agricultural land near to the forests, loss of woodland habitat, restoration of buildings and the destruction of roost sites (Trujillo 2002). The recent decline of the La Palma maternity colony has been attributed to disturbance, and it is known that at least one individual from this colony has been taken by private collectors (Trujillo 2002).
population: Summer colonies usually consist of 10-30 females (the maximum number recorded is 61). Winter clusters are usually small (c.10 animals), and the species often roosts solitarily at this time of year. There are only two known breeding colonies (on La Palma and Tenerife respectively). The larger of these two (the La Palma colony) has declined in number in recent years (Trujillo 2002).
range: The Canary Big-eared Bat is endemic to the Canary Islands (Tenerife, La Palma, El Hierro and probably also La Gomera), where its Area of Occurrence is less than 3,000 km<sup>2</sup>. It occurs at elevations between 100 and 2,300 m (<span lang="EN-US">Trujillo 2002).
conservationActions: It is protected by national legislation in Spain. There are also international legal obligations for its protection through the Bonn Convention (Eurobats) and Bern Convention. It is included in Annex IV of EU Habitats & Species Directive. A bat protection programme aimed at protecting caves used as roost sites from human disturbance was instigated in 1993 (Benzal and Fajardo 1999). Protection of the species' woodland foraging habitat is also recommended (Trujillo 2002).

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, and presumed large population.
habitat: The species has been found close to streams in forests and gallery forests. Some individuals were found in a cave with a small current, where they hid in small holes between rocks (Perret and Mertens 1957 in Barej et al. 2010). Eggs are deposited on moist surfaces on rocks, and males seem to guard the eggs at night (Amiet 1991 in Barej et al. 2010).
threats: The extent and quality of its habitat is declining due to increasing human habitation, expanding agriculture, including cocoa, palm, banana plantations, both industrial and subsistence-scale logging, and degradation of its aquatic habitat due to agricultural runoff of herbicides and pesticides (N. Gonwouo, M. Barej and M. Hirschfeld pers. comm. June 2012).
population: Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species occurs from eastern Nigeria, through Cameroon and Equatorial Guinea, to southern Gabon and northern Republic of Congo, between 315-1,000 m asl (Barej et al. 2010 and references therein). Some records from Cameroon, Equatorial Guinea and Gabon were previously thought to belong to Petropedetes newtonii but, following genetic and morphological analysis, they were assigned to this species (Barej et al. 2010).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
No specific conservation actions are currently known for this species, but it does occur in Bakossi Hills National Park and other proposed protected areas, and possibly Campo - Ma'an National Park (N. Gonwouo pers. comm. June 2012). 

Research Needed
More research is needed on this species' distribution, population size and natural history.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large overall population, and because it occurs in a number of protected areas and has a tolerance of a degree of habitat modification.
habitat: This species is found in both dry and wet forests, open jungle, forest borders, caves and cultivated areas (Schleich and Kästle 2002) where it lives in small to medium bushes, scrubby vegetation and also on tall trees with profuse branching. It is said to be a common predator of poultry and other common birds (e.g., pigeons), as well as bats (Mohapatra and Srinivasulu pers. comm. 2019). This species usually rests inside tree holes, especially in Ficus bengalensis and other large trees (A. de Silva pers. comm. August 2010).
threats: It has been reported that this species is often killed while forest is being cleared, due to the perception that it poses a threat to humans (De Silva 2006). However, due to the wide range of this species, localized events of persecution by humans should not be considered a major threat. Habitat loss has also been cited as a localized threat to this species (CAMP workshop 1997), although it appears to have wide ecological tolerances.
population: In India this species has been described as fairly common (Daniel 2002, Sharma 2003), and the population is considered stable, as it can be found in areas close to villages (P. Mohapatra pers. comm.). In Sri Lanka is appears to be a rare species, with declining populations (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. 2019).
range: This snake has been recorded from India, Sri Lanka and possibly Nepal. In India, the species is found in most of the country except the northeast, with records from Gujarat (widely except Katch - Vyas), the Ganges valley, Orissa, West Bengal, and Rajasthan provinces, and the entire Western Ghats (Sharma 2003). It is frequently found in Chhatisgarh (Suraj). It is generally found throughout Sri Lanka, however, was noted to be absent in a survey in the Knuckles Mountain Range (Project Knuckles 2005). In Nepal, this species is perhaps known from the eastern and western Terai (Schleich and Kästle 2002), but it has been suggested that this may represent Boiga siamensis. It has been recorded from 150 to 2,000 m asl.
useTrade: This species is used by snake charmers.
conservationActions: In India, this species is listed on Schedule  IV of the Indian Wildlife (Protection) Act, 1972. This species is found in many of protected areas. There is a need for research on the taxonomy and threats to this species. There is a general need for conservation awareness to prevent killing of harmless snakes.

rationale: Plagiopholis styani has been assessed as Least Concern, as it is widely distributed and has no known major threats at this time. There are protected areas that coincide with the species' distribution which probably provide small safeguards for this species.
habitat: This species is known to occur in areas of montane and bamboo forest, where it inhabits caves (Orlov et al. 2000). It has been recorded between 1,000 and 1,300 m asl.
threats: This species may be experiencing localized habitat loss and degradation, however, as this species has a wide range this should not be considered a major threat at this time.
population: This is an uncommon species.
range: This species ranges from southeastern Gansu throughout southern China, including Hunan province. It is also found in Taiwan and northern Viet Nam (Orlov et al. 2000, Huang et al. 1999, Zhao and Adler 1993). In Viet Nam, records exist for Muong Te (Lai Chau Province), Sa Pa (Lao Cai Province), Tu Ly (Hoa Binh Province) and Ky Son (Nghe An Province) (Orlov et al. 2000, Nguyen et al. 2009).
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilized.
conservationActions: There are no direct conservation measures in place for this species, however, there are protected areas within its range. No further conservation measures are needed.

rationale: Listed as Near Threatened because of a population decline (estimated to be close to 30% over the last ten years) inferred from over-exploitation, habitat destruction and degradation, and general apathy.
habitat: Python molurus is mostly found in forested areas, but is also found in mangroves, semi-arid forests and grasslands, marshes, streams and rivers. It is found in wet rocky areas near streams and pools, large rotting logs, large burrows, caves, crevices, old and ruined structures. It is a good climber and an expert swimmer. It is more nocturnal than diurnal. It feeds on small to large mammals, birds, reptiles and amphibians preferring to mostly feed on mammals. Breeding occurs between December to February after which it lays between 15–100 eggs in the months of March and June (Daniel 2002, Whitaker and Captain 2004).
threats: Although collection of snakes is legally banned in India, this activity still is in existence. This species is under threat due to local as well as international markets for the illegal demand in leather industry. Scores of individuals are collected, and smuggled for pet trade. It is eaten as subsistence food. Animals are killed when preying on livestock (chickens and goats). It is also under threat due to habitat degradation and habitat loss due to anthropogenic activities. It is threatened in dry deciduous areas by rampant forest fires. Mining is considered to be a threat to this species in the Eastern Ghats of India.
population: <span lang="EN-US">While this is a widely distributed species known from many localities throughout much of India (Smith 1943, Daniel 2002, Whitaker and Captain 2004), its population has undergone drastic decline due to illegal trade for skin, pet trade and due to decline in quality of habitat and general apathy.
range: This python is widely distributed in Sri Lanka and India, with subpopulations in northeastern Pakistan an scattered into Nepal and along the India-Bangladesh border; the species does not occur in Bhutan (cf. Whitaker and Captain 2004, Barker et al. 2018). In south-eastern Pakistan, populations are presumed to have been extirpated (Barker et al. 2018). Indian subpopulations are known from throughout much of the country (Smith 1943, Daniel 2002). It is found at elevations of 10 to 2,000 m asl.
useTrade: In some parts of India Python molurus is used for local consumption (meat). It is in high demand for its skin that is used in the leather industry. Fat deposits of this snake are used in the pharmaceutical industry. Bones are used for local superstitions. It is smuggled, locally and at national level, extensively for pet trade. It is collected for Zoological gardens and as museum exhibits. It is often seen with snake charmers.
conservationActions: In India, it is protected under Schedule I of the Wildlife (Protection) Act, 1972. It is listed in Appendix II of CITES, but subspecies molurus is listed in Appendix I. In its range it occurs in many protected areas. Further survey work is needed to understand its biology, ecology, population status and trends.

rationale: The species is listed as Least Concern because it has adapted to man-made habitats and is widely distributed in Borneo. If there is a change in the current management of agricultural lands towards more effective pest control methods and if present harvest levels of this species are maintained, this may impact this species detrimentally and its conservation status would need to be reviewed. Similarly, further loss of natural habitat may also impact on the status of this species, hence ongoing monitoring is required.
habitat: This species occurs in moist areas with soft soils, where this nocturnal snake hides in rodent burrows during the day. In wetter habitats, the python prefers to use slightly elevated burrows (M. Auliya pers. comm. March 2012). It is found in lowland forest, but due to its nocturnal habits and choice of shelter sites is uncommonly encountered in these habitats. The snake is most frequently encountered in agricultural lands, both croplands and plantations (including oil palm, coconut and cocoa), adjacent to forested areas (M. Auliya pers. comm. September 2011). A strong swimmer, the snake may use irrigation canals and other water-bodies to move, and there are historical reports of this python from wetlands (M. Auliya pers. comm. March 2012). The Bornean short-tailed Python is, however, a fully terrestrial snake and so requires areas with some land to persist as a viable population (M. Auliya pers. comm. March 2012).
threats: The main threat to this species is the hunting pressure for skins and the pet trade. Meat is also a by-product that is sold on the local market. Although trade is extensive, nearly all recently-collected specimens have been taken from anthropogenic habitats, and so there is currently little pressure on this species in the natural forested areas. As deforestation is extensive throughout Borneo, however, the replacement of natural habitats with plantations and farmland may increase the pressures on this snake, which adapts well to habitat conversion.
population: The species is often considered as rare or uncommon throughout its pristine habitat, and it is always associated to various degrees with extensive agricultural lands.
range: Python breitensteini is a lowland species that has not yet been recorded from altitudes higher than 1,000 m asl. Based on both historical and relatively recent records the species is likely to be present throughout the entire island of Borneo in both the Malaysian and Indonesia territories, as well as Brunei (one record from Brunei; specimen number from Museum of Brunei BM 142.1974), with the exception of the central highlands above its maximum upper altitude. Records are known from scattered sites across the entire island.
useTrade: The species is widely collected all over Borneo for its skin and meat, and is involved in the international pet trade (Auliya 2006). In Indonesia, most snake collectors are searching for snakes as a supplementary source of income, as this does not provide enough to support daily needs. The total level of  exploitation is believed to be increasing and have become larger than the maximum  quota allowed (the annual export quota for Kalimantan in 2011 is 10,800 skins and 1,620 individuals for international pet trade). All specimens harvested for trade, for all purposes, are derived from agricultural lands, including plantations. The species has been observed to be sold for food for local consumption in local markets in Sarawak, Borneo (I. Das pers. obs 2011). There is evidence of cross-border trade of this species between the provinces of East Malaysia and Indonesia (M. Auliya pers. comm. September 2011).
conservationActions: This species in known from protected areas and is listed on Appendix II of CITES. No trade of wild harvested snakes is allowed from Sarawak. Annual harvests of this species in Indonesia are limited by capture and export quotas. The current conservation measures in place do not correspond with the necessary enforcement, which needs to be more effective.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern as although it has a relatively restricted range, there are no major threats and because the population is unlikely to be declining.
habitat: This species lives in forests, but has also been recorded from the caves of Alishan Mountains. It is often found in dark and wet environment, such as leaf litter, rotten woods, and occasionally found in trails. As with other members of the genus it may be oviparous. The diet consists largely of  slugs.
threats: There appear to be no significant threats to this species.
population: No population status information is currently available for this species.
range: This species is endemic to Taiwan, China (Zhao & Alder 1993). It occurs at 1,000 to 3,000m asl.
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilized.
conservationActions: No conservation actions are currently known for this species. It is present in some protected areas. More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history and threats. It is a Class II protected species in Taiwan.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable, in view of a possible population decline estimated at over 30% over the past ten years (principally in China) resulting from overexploitation for the food and skin trade.
habitat: It occurs in hilly and rugged terrain covered with wet and dry forests, deciduous and pine forests, and grasslands (David and Vogel 1996). It lives in forest, forest clearings, scrublands, plantations, and near villages. It is often found deep inside caves (up to several kilometres inside) in karst regions, making it one of the world's few true cave-dwelling snakes (David and Vogel 1996).
threats: This species may be threatened by overharvesting. It has a large range, but geographic variation across  its range suggests that this species contains evolutionary distinct  lineages, each having smaller ranges that are more vulnerable to  extinction. Nevertheless, there is no data on the impacts of harvesting on this snake. In the Southern Ryukyus, factors causing the recent population decline of this snake include an increase in roadkills due to the development of a paved road system, and predation by exotic predators such as weasels and peacocks (Ota 2014).
population: This species is infrequently encountered, although it can be abundant in caves. It is presumed to be declining to some extent as a result of collection in much of its range. The Ryukyu endemic subspecies Elaphe taeniura schmackeri  is uncommon and the frequency of observations has declined in most of the islands within its range (Ota 2014).
range: This species occurs from northeastern India across mainland China to Taiwan and the Ryukyu Islands (Japan), southward to Sumatra (Indonesia) and Borneo (Smith 1943; David and Vogel 1996). There are unconfirmed records from the Primorskiy Territory of Russia (a single specimen collected in 1862 close to the Korean border, which may represent an introduction). Pope (1935) suggested that the species' native range extended as far north as the Yangtze River Valley, but had been introduced by people further northward in China. It has not been recorded from Nepal. It is found at elevations of coastal areas to 3,000 m asl.
useTrade: This species is heavily collected for food. skin, and for the international pet trade in China. There is no trade in India.
conservationActions: Taxonomic study is needed to better understand geographic variation (and infraspecific nomenclature) across the range of this species. It is present in some protected areas. Volume of trade for food and skins should be monitored. In the Japanese Red Data book the subspecies, Elaphe taeniura schmackeri, is listed Vulnerable on the basis of a decline in both the population and habitat quality (Ota 2014).

rationale: P. curtus is a relatively widely distributed species, although it has a more restricted geographic distribution than P. brongersmai and P. breitensteini. Its natural habitat is known to be declining due to the deforestation of the western part of Sumatra, where the remaining forest is increasingly fragmented. The species is known to be collected for the international pet trade but is often easily misidentified as P. brongersmai or P. breitensteini, what makes it difficult to estimate the severity of impact of this threat to this species. The area of occupancy and extent of occurrence are too large to qualify for any of the threatened categories under criterion B. Hence it is is listed as Least Concern at present, but the quality and extent of its habitat are known to be declining, and there is a potential threat of increasing collecting rates, therefore this species requires monitoring and regular reassessment as it could well warrant listing in a more threatened category in the near future.
habitat: This forest species is frequently found in tree plantations and is known to inhabit a wide range of forested habitats from lowlands to montane habitat up to 1,000 metres above the sea level.
threats: Collection for trade is the main threat to this species, however, the species is also threatened  by habitat loss due to agricultural development.
population: Compared to Python brongersmai, traders claimed that Python curtus are much more difficult to find, so that most specimens in trade are actually P. brongersmai. However, trade makes no distinction and collect both forms as same species indistinctly. According to Iskandar pers. comm. (2011), it was not possible to find any specimens of the species in the forested areas from where it is known to be native for the last 30 years, and most recent museum specimens come exclusively from traded individuals. As a consequence, it is believed that P. curtus is relatively uncommon.
range:
This species is endemic to the western part of the Barisan mountain range in Sumatra (Bengkulu, West Sumatra and North Sumatra Province) and Siberut in Mentawai Islands (Dring et al. 1990). A record from Palembang in Sumatra is regarded as questionable (Zug et al. 2011). Due to the complex trade dynamics in Sumatra the provenance of specimens east of the Barisan mountain range is in doubt.
In their analysis of the distribution of members of the P. curtus group, Zug et al. (2011) could only verify the presence of this species at Mt. Kabor and Kaba Wetan, although these authors also accept the validity of records from Sibolga (Shine et al. 1998), Padang, Bandar Lampung (Barker and Barker 1994) and Bengkulu (Keogh et al. 2001).

The species was previously thought to occur in Peninsular Malaysia, Sumatra and Borneo, but is nowadays considered to be endemic to Sumatra, where it is restricted to the west side of the Barisan mountain range.
useTrade: The species is mainly collected for the international skin trade, and to a lesser extent for the pet trade and traditional medicine. According to Zug et al. (2011), the most recent voucher specimens available in museum collections for this species were derived from the leather market. In Indonesia, most snake collectors are searching for snakes as a supplementary source of income, and the total level of exploitation is believed to be increasing and is larger than the maximum quota allowed for this country of 1,890 skins and 450 specimens for the pet trade (Appendix II of CITES  2011).
conservationActions: The species is protected in Indonesia, and it is listed on CITES Appendix II. Although the Indonesian authorities distinguish between the three species in establishing a quota for each of them, the extent to which these quotas are enforced in the field is unclear. The species is known to be present in Kerinci Seblat National Park, Rimbo Panti Nature Reserve, Batang Gadis National Park and Siberut, Mentawai Islands. Further field work in the area might show that the species also occurs in Leuser National Park. The sustainability of current capture quotas should be verified as it is likely that the species is exploited over the permitted numbers. As a result, enforcement of the current compliance of established quotas is needed.

rationale: This species is listed as Vulnerable on the basis that it has an extent of occurrence of around 6,000 km<sup>2</sup>, the population is considered to be severely fragmented, and it is undergoing a continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat. Based on current records, its area of occupancy may be below 500 km<sup>2</sup>, but available locality data is not sufficiently comprehensive across the range, or at sufficiently high resolution, to confirm this and more research may suggest that this species warrants listing in a higher category.
habitat: This species is associated with rock faces in boulder-dominated areas, particularly those with moss and lichen-covered caves, within a matrix of either savanna grassland or monsoon forest (Somaweera and Somaweera 2009). This is a communal species found in groups of 3-11 individuals, and a single cave may hold up to 50 individuals in multiple groups (Somaweera and Somaweera 2009). Communal nest sites can contain up to 100 eggs and the same site may be used over multiple breeding season (Somaweera and Somaweera 2009). Animals are nocturnally active on trees outside caves at night, and remain in dark areas during the day (Somaweera and Somaweera 2009).
threats: Removal of forest for varied reasons, including settlement and agriculture, represents a threat to this species, and forest fires may have some impact. Most suitable habitat in its range lies within protected areas which limits large-scale habitat destruction, despite some encroachment. There is some quarrying but it is small-scale and restricted to the north of the range. Granite blasting has been observed both within and outside protected areas, following which the species has not been detected (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. 2019). The major threats to this species are the conversion of caves to hermitages (and the attendant expansion of temple complexes) and destruction of suitable rocky habitat (including that within protected areas) in order to obtain building materials (Karunarathna and Amarasinghe 2011, S. Karunarathna pers. comm. 2019), and these practices are common within protected areas. There is some persecution as a result of traditional beliefs (T. Amarasinghe pers. comm. 2019). Most caves have already been converted to hermitages, where the species occurs in low numbers (Karunarathna and Amarasnghe 2011). Large road development projects, settlement and industrial zones are already underway in flat areas in the southeast of the range.
population: This species is not common. Observations within suitable habitat at the same localities over 10 years suggest the animals are becoming harder to find at least in some areas (S. Karunaratha pers. comm. 2019), which may correspond to as much as a 25% decline in the Pitakumbura area (S. Karunarathna pers. comm. 2019). At Hulang Nuge, where the species was present ten years ago, it can no longer be found. In many surveyed sites, communal clutch sizes have been observed to decline drastically over the past 10 years, and in some areas only 3-4 eggs are found in clutches (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. 2019). The population is considered to be severely fragmented in light of these reported declines, as this species occurs at low densities in individual sites and recolonization following local extinction is unlikely due to the distribution of suitable habitat and this species' low vagility.
range: This species is endemic to the monsoon forest region of eastern and southeastern Sri Lanka (Somaweera and Somaweera 2009) at elevations of 125-800 m asl. (Kuranarathna and Amarasinghe 2011).
useTrade: It is unknown whether there is any use of or trade in this species. It is possible that it may be of interest to the Chinese medicinal trade, but there are no reports of demand for this species at present (T. Amarasinghe pers. comm. 2019).
conservationActions: This species is known from two protected areas. Population studies (including research into population densities to clarify viability of individual subpopulations) and ecological research to clarify specific microhabitat requirements are recommended. General awareness-raising of the importance of caves as gecko habitats is recommended, and efforts to limit persecution of this gecko. As many localities lie near temples, Karunarathna and Amarasinghe (2011) suggest that these could be made centres for this awareness-raising. Government agencies should minimise removal of granite rocks, illegal forest clearance, and chena cultivation (Karunarathna and Amarasinghe 2011).

rationale: Listed as Near Threatened given that, even though it is a common species with the ability to survive in a variety of disturbed environments (is not severely fragmented and known from more than ten locations), it has an estimated extent of occurrence of 3,005 km<sup>2</sup> and its natural habitat in the Dominican Republic is declining. It almost qualifies for a threatened listing under criterion B1ab(iii).
habitat: It is terrestrial in a variety of mesic habitats, including plantations, woods, gardens, ravines and trash piles in urban areas. Males call from caves, rocks, or low vegetation. Eggs are laid on the ground and it breeds by direct development.
threats: The Eastern Plains are an area of significant development in the Dominican Republic. Continuing conversion of habitats for agricultural land, urbanization, and for the tourism industry is reducing the availability of high quality habitat for this species, and although the species is able to exist in disturbed environments the current rate of development is likely to have an overall negative impact on the population (S. Inchaustegui, M. Rodríguez, L. Diaz, M. Landestoy, C. Marte pers. comms. March 2011).
population: It is abundant in suitable habitats within its known distribution, and it has been recorded on a regular basis throughout its range  (S. Inchaustegui, M. Rodríguez, L. Diaz, M. Landestoy, C. Marte pers comms. March 2011). It was last seen in 2011.
range: This species is endemic to the coastal zone of the Eastern Plains of  the Dominican Republic. It has been reported across an area of 113 km and it is widely distributed within its range  (S. Inchaustegui, M. Rodríguez, L. Diaz, C. Marte pers comms. March 2011). Its range, taken here as a proxy for its extent of occurrence (EOO), is estimated to be 3,005 km<sup>2</sup> from its area polygon.
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
It occurs in several small protected areas, although some may likely require better management. Additional habitat protection would also be needed. The Dominican governmental agency Ministerio de Educación Superior, Ciencia y Tecnología (MECyT) is currently financing a three-year Dominican conservation project on threatened frogs due to climate change (RANA-RD), and which is expected to contribute towards a national Dominican amphibian conservation action plan with policy recommendations (C. Marte, M. Rodríguez and L. Diaz pers. comms. March 2011).

The Amphibian Ark Conservation Needs Assessment process (Amphibian Ark 2011) conducted in the joint IUCN-Amphibian Ark workshop where this species was reassessed identified that further conservation actions for this taxon should include in situ conservation.

rationale: This species has been assessed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution throughout Southeast Asia. It is abundant throughout its range, can tolerate a high degree of habitat modification, and is present in multiple protected areas. Further research into its taxonomy is recommended.
habitat: This scansorial, nocturnal species occupies a wide range of habitats from coastal forests, lowland and hill dipterocarp forests, lower montane primary and secondary rainforest, and riparian areas to modified environments such as urban areas (Bauer and Branch 2004, Das 2010, Grismer 2011). In Palawan, this name is applied to a gecko that exhibits a closer association with pristine forest (Supsup et al. 2020). It has been found in a wide variety of microhabitats such as rainforest leaf litter, under rotting logs, beneath tree bark, on the surface of stumps and living trees, in arboreal ferns at heights 2 to 4.5 m in trees in the forest and caves and rock crevices (Bauer and Branch 2004, Das 2010), as well as in coastal vegetation bordering the beaches (Grismer 2011). It is easily found on large boulders along streams (J. Binaday pers. comm. 2021). This arboreal species preys on insects, other arthropods (Bauer and Branch 2004, Das 2010) and worms (Grismer 2011). It is a communal nester in rock crevices, with more than 50 eggs laid together (Bauer and Branch 2004, Das 2010). It is likely to breed year-round (Grismer 2011).
threats: It is unlikely that any major threats are impacting this species.
population: This species appears to be relatively abundant in much of its range (L. Grismer and E. Quah pers. comm 2017). It is commonly found in cave systems in Catanduanes in the Philippines (C.J. dela Cruz pers. comm. 2021). It is abundant in Cavite on Luzon, where it is considered to co-occur with the less disturbance-tolerant Gekko mindorensis, and is regarded as having an at least locally stable population (R. Lagat pers. comm. 2021).
range: This species is widespread in Southeast Asia occurring in Thailand, Indonesia, Malaysia, northern islands in the Philippines, Singapore (Chan-ard et al. 2015) and Borneo (Das and Yaakob 2007). In Thailand, it has been recorded northward to Pang-nga Province (Chan-ard et al. 2015). In Indonesia, it has been found in Sumatra, the Mentawai Archipelago, Sulawesi, Palau Simeulue, Pulau Berhala, Java, and the Moluccan islands of Kei (from which it has not recently been recorded - Karin et al. 2018), Aru, Ambon and Ceram (Manthey and Grossmann 1997, Bauer and Branch 2004, Rosler et al. 2011). It has not been recorded from most of mainland New Guinea, although there is a record from Fakfak (B. Tjaturadi unpublished data 2010). These may represent an introduced population. Within the Philippines, it has been recorded from the islands of Palawan, Calamian Islands, the Sulu Archipelago, Mindanao, Dinagat, Camiguin, Leyte, Luzon, Guimaras, Panglao Island (offshore Bohol) (M. Gaulke pers. comm. 2008) and Tatayan. It is locally abundant throughout nearly all Peninsular Malaysia and widespread in the Seribuat Archipelago. It is also known from the islands of Langkawi and Singa Besar, Pangkor, Perhentian Besar, Redang, Tenggol, Pinang, Jerejak, Besar and Pisang (Grismer et al. 2011). This species has been recorded from sea level up to 1,500 m asl (Das 2010).
useTrade: This species is not found in the commercial international pet trade (L. Grismer and E. Quah pers. comm. 2017). It is traded domestically in the Philippines as snake food, along with other common house geckos (G.B. Santos pers. comm. 2021).
conservationActions: Given the abundance of this species throughout its extensive distribution, and the fact that it is in part a human commensal widely distributed throughout Southeast Asia, it is not likely to require any conservation measures (L. Grismer and E. Quah pers. comm. 2017).

rationale: Based on the species' large distribution (from the Talaud Islands across northern Moluccas [Indonesia] in the west, across New Guinea and to the Solomon Islands in the east) and its ecological flexibility, this species is assessed as Least Concern. The species occurs, however, in a number of island subpopulations, and there is no information on whether harvesting or any undocumented anthropogenic pressures may have impacted individual subpopulations, particularly in the northern Moluccas.
habitat: This species occurs abundantly in a variety of habitats including closed-canopy forest and modified areas such as plantations, cultivated land, rural gardens and human habitations (Setiadi and Hamidy 2006). It has occasional records from the littoral zone and from within cave systems (M. McCoy pers. comm. August 2012). It is mainly nocturnal but occasionally moves about during the day. It displays both terrestrial and arboreal behaviour, and can sometimes be found in tree hollows and in oil palms. On the ground it lives among any suitable cover from leaf litter to rock piles, plantation debris, grass tussocks and under fallen timber. When young, it feeds upon small lizards, particularly skinks, and larger snakes feed upon larger lizards and small mammals. This species has been found deep within limestone caves where it was presumably feeding on small bats and/or juvenile frogs of the genus Cornufer that also occurred there. This snake can be aggressive in temperament, striking repeatedly if provoked. It is ovoviviparous and up to 20 or more young are produced at a time (McCoy 2006, de Lang 2013).
threats: It is unlikely that any major threats are impacting this species. It is possible that overcollection for the pet trade may cause or have caused localized declines, and anecdotally villagers in some areas attribute an increase in rat densities to reduced boa populations (M. McCoy pers. comm. August 2012). The impact trade may have had on individual subpopulations in parts of its range is uncertain. The Solomon Island population was perceived to be stable (McCoy 2006) and import into the European Union and the United States is illegal, although exports have been reported in CITES data for 2015 and 2016.
population: This is a common species. According to McCoy (2006) the Solomon Island population appears stable, and it is abundant in a variety of habitats including forest, cultivated areas and human habitation.
range:
This species has a wide distribution occurring in New Guinea, the Solomon Islands (east to Santa Cruz - Zug 2013), and the Indonesian islands of Halmahera, Bacan, Morotai, Moti, Tidore and Ternate west to the Talaud Islands (Smith 2001, Koch et al. 2009, de Lang 2013). A report of the species' occurrence in northern Sulawesi is based on a 19th century record from "Minahassa" (Nord Celebes) (Meyer 1870–1873) and has been questioned by more recent authors as it has never subsequently been confirmed (Koch et al. 2009, Koch 2012). Whether a record from Obi Island refers to Candoia paulsoni tasmai requires verification (de Lang 2013). This species occurs from sea level to at least 300 m asl (McCoy 2006) (possibly higher at Telefomin, although this locality requires confirmation - M. O'Shea pers. comm. 2015).

In Papua New Guinea it occurs on the northern coast from Morobe to Milne Bay, and also from the Milne Bay Province islands of Goodenough, Fergusson, Dobu, Normanby, Kiriwina, Kitava, Woodlark, Rossel and Tagula (O’Shea 1996, 2007). It has been recorded on the eastern Admiralty islands (needs confirmation) and virtually all the Solomon islands except for Ontong Java, Duff, Tikopia and Anuta.  The distribution pattern suggests that the taxonomy needs to be reviewed (A. Allison and A. Stubbs pers. comm. September 2011). A number of other records from Papua New Guinea - from Telefonin, the Huon Peninsula in Morobe Province, the Fly River and the Trans-Fly - have been variously attributed to this species or to Candoia carinata. It is possible (but unconfirmed) that the two taxa co-occur in the Huon Peninsula (M. O'Shea pers. comm. 2015), however, the other records are thought likely to be in error and examination of museum specimens is required to clarify the species' occurrence in Telefonnin, the Fly River and the Trans-Fly (M. O'Shea pers. comm. 2015).
useTrade: Leary (1991) reviewed the live reptile and amphibian export trade from the Solomon Islands between 1989 and 1990: a total of 27,675 reptiles were exported, 4,251 (15.4%) of which represented this species. Two shipments from the Solomons in 2015 and 2016 report the export of 930 wild specimens (https://trade.cites.org). In 2013, Indonesia exported 1,080 live specimens (de Lang 2013). According to the CITES trade database, Indonesia exported 463 live specimens in the period 2016–18 (https://trade.cites.org). Harvest quota for 2020 is permitted for 150 live specimens from Halmahera (Kuota pengambilan tumbuhan dan penangkapan satwa liar  - periode 2020). Endemic island subspecies (e.g., those of Woodlark and Misima islands) may be vulnerable to over-collecting.
conservationActions:
This species is listed under Appendix II of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES). This species has protection status in Papua New Guinea but not in Indonesia.

In August 2006, the Solomons suspended trade of all wildlife native to those islands and became a party to CITES in March 2007 (Shepherd et al. 2012). 

This species occurs in protected areas in New Guinea. Field research is recommended to evaluate the species' population status and whether current offtake levels impact subpopulations, particularly with regard to those on individual Moluccan islands. The taxonomic status of a number of records, e.g. on Obi Island, needs to be investigated.

rationale: Candoia carinata has been assessed as Least Concern, mainly due to the species' relative extensive distribution occurring in eastern Indonesian islands, across New Guinea, the Bismarck Archipelago and Admiralty islands. New Guinea populations may not be affected by any significant threats at present. The species is regularly harvested for the international pet industry; however uncertainties remain in regard to actual offtake levels, mortality prior to export, and whether commonly harvested subpopulations have declined.  Further research is therefore required to clarify these uncertainties, and taxonomic research is recommended. Legal export appears to be restricted to the New Guinea subspecies C. candoia tepedeleni, and research is needed to confirm that the nominate species is not subject to illegal harvesting.
habitat: This species can be found in a variety of habitats from lowland pristine, riverine and secondary forests to caves and also disturbed environments such as plantations and rural gardens (O'Shea 1996) up to 700 m asl (Edgar and Lilley 1993). Most species of the genus are considered terrestrial species (Foufopoulos and Richards 2007), however, the slender body and prehensile tail of Candoia carinata demonstrate its arboreal lifestyle (de Lang 2013). It is ovoviviparous and gives birth to up to six (in captivity of up to nine young) (Wirz 2002). Its diet consists primarily of skinks but may also take geckos, their eggs and frogs (O’Shea 1996).
threats: It is currently unknown if the species is impacted by any major threats. Reported export levels for the commercial pet trade are unlikely to pose a significant threat to this species across its range but may have local impacts, and information on mortality rates of animals in transit (which may suggest that trade estimates derived from export and import data under-record the scale of collection) or population trends is lacking.
population: Information on the species' population status is lacking. At present it is not thought to be subject to major threats, but information on any impacts of harvesting on local subpopulations are unknown.
range: This species has a large distribution, ranging from the eastern Indonesian islands (Sulawesi and the Moluccas - Candoia carinata carinata), and New Guinea to the Bismarck Archipelago (where it is represented by the separate subspecies C. c.  tepedeleni). In Indonesia it has been recorded on Sulawesi, Sangihe Islands, the Moluccas (Ambon, Banda Islands, Neira, Boano, Gorong, Haruku, Saparua, Seram, Tanimbar islands, Yamdena (den Bosch 1985, O’Shea 1996, de Lang 2013, A. Stubbs pers. comm. 2019). In Indonesian New Guinea it occurs throughout West Papua Province and across the northern coastal region to the Huon Peninsula of Moreby Province, Papua New Guinea. Some records from the Papuan Peninsula require verification (M. O'Shea pers. comm. 2015). It is found in the south west of Papua New Guinea in Western, Southern Highlands, and Gulf Province. It is also found throughout the Bismarck Archipelago and Admiralty islands. It is found at elevations from sea level to around 1,525 m asl (O’Shea 1996).
useTrade: Yuwono (1998) recorded the trade of this species from Indonesian New Guinea, and reported that thousands of specimens could be collected if required. Natusch and Lyons (2012) noted the trade of this species from Jayapura and the Vogelkop in Indonesian New Guinea. Sixteen and eighty-three individuals (respectively) were recorded at wildlife traders between September 2010 – April 2011. This species is listed under CITES but does not have protected status in Indonesia. The Indonesian harvest quota established for 2020 is 300 from Papua and 350 from Papua Barat, while export quota for the whole country is 618 (Kuota pengambilan tumbuhan dan penangkapan satwa liar - periode 2020). In 2013, the export quota was 1,080 live specimens (de Lang 2013), but no specific quotas exist for the Moluccas despite well-established harvests of other reptile species in this region.
conservationActions: This species is listed under Appendix II of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) (http://www.cites.org/eng/app/appendices.php). This species has protected status in Papua New Guinea but not in Indonesian New Guinea (Natusch and Lyons 2012). This species occurs in protected areas in New Guinea and the Bismarck Archipelago, but these are unlikely to provide safeguards against harvesting. Monitoring the trade and harvest levels of this species is recommended.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its tolerance of habitat modification, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: This species is found in mountainous areas with dry rock formations, vertical rock walls, in caves (Baha El Din 2006), in trees and on ruins and houses in urban and rural areas. It lays two eggs in a clutch. It is principally nocturnal, but is also active diurnally (Metallinou et al. 2015).
threats: There are no major threats to this adaptable species.
population: This is a common to abundant species.
range: This species ranges from eastern Egypt and the extreme north of Sudan east of the Nile Valley, east through southern Sinai (along the southern coast), southern Israel, and southwestern Jordan into the Arabian Peninsula (Saudi Arabia and Yemen). Records from northeastern Africa (Djibouti to Somalia) and central Sudan represent Ptyodactylus ragazzii, formerly a subspecies of P. hasselquistii (Sindaco and Jeremčenko 2008). It is found from 200 m below sea-level up to 1,450 m asl. The subspecies P. h. krameri is known from a single specimen from a non-specific locality in Lebanon, which may represent an introduction (Sindaco and Jeremčenko 2008).
useTrade: This species is not collected.
conservationActions: It occurs in many protected areas. Further taxonomic studies are needed for this species.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a broad range of habitats, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining.
habitat: This species can occur in very different climates due to its ability to adapt to being either nocturnal or diurnal. It is found in Mediterranean scrubland, and also in arid areas, and is a rock dwelling animal that can also use wadi beds and riverbeds and houses.
threats: There are no major threats to this species.
population: It is a widespread species that is locally common in the less arid parts of its range.
range: This species ranges from western Egypt (including much of the Eastern Desert and Western  Desert and Sinai) and Sudan, east to most of Israel and western Jordan. It also occurs in scattered localities in Syria, north to Palmyra (only Palmyra mapped at present). It may be present in Libya, but its presence here needs to be confirmed. It does not appear to be present in Saudi Arabia.
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It occurs in many protected areas. Further taxonomic studies are needed for this species, particularly populations in Egypt and Sudan currently referred to this species (S. Baha El Din pers. comm.).

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable as the species occurs in a fairly small area which given the threat of potential development would be treated as a single location. The planned development, once it starts to happen could well impact most if not the whole area and this would drive this species very quickly to Critically Endangered. There is some uncertainty concerning the plausibility of the development happening, but the listing as Vulnerable seems sufficiently precautionary should the development plans go ahead.
habitat: Specimens have been recorded from the vertical sides of large boulders in the middle of a wadi (van der Kooij 2000). It has also been observed on large vertical rock walls (Gardner 1994). It can also be found in very deep caves.
threats: Gardner (1994) states that "At present its habitat is not affected by human activity to any great extent, but recent government pronouncements indicate that considerable development is planned for the Jebel Akhdar and the Saiq Plateau in particular".
population: It appears to live at low densities (Gardner 1994).
range: This relict species is endemic to the higher elevations of the Jebal Akhdar in Oman (van der Kooij 2000). It has been recorded from 1,850-2,250 m asl (van der Kooij 2000).
useTrade: This species is not in trade or use.
conservationActions: The species is not present in any protected areas. Further studies are needed into the distribution, abundance, natural history, and threats to this little-known species.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered because its extent of occurrence is about 21 km2, it is found in a single location that is affected by a continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat due to tourism development. Although an important part of the range of the species is within a protected area, it also falls within a highly developed area for tourism, and the protection category permits more tourism development.
habitat: This species has been found on limestone outcrops, cliffs, caves entrances, rocky shelters, sinkholes, rustic wooden houses roofed with “guano” (palmfronds) within forested areas, tree cactus (Dendrocereus nudiflorus), and on fig (Ficus sp.) root tangles.  The limestone rock at the type locality is mostly covered by a microphyllous evergreen forest. It is an oviparous species that feeds on insects (Díaz and Hedges 2009).
threats: The major threat for this species is habitat loss and habitat fragmentation due to deforestation for tourism and residential areas. All known localities lie within a protected area, but are very close together and subject to the same pressures (A. Fong pers. comm. 2017). Although the protected status permits more tourism development within the park (CNAP 2013), this presently takes the form of trails and small buildings that may have only limited impacts on this species' habitat (A. Fong pers. comm. 2016). Nevertheless, if current rates of tourist development continue it is estimated that all natural habitat on Península de Hicacos will be lost within 50 years (Gonzalez et al. 2012, A. Fong pers. comm. 2017). Gonzalez et al. (2012) mention that the species has a fragmented distribution, with an area of occupancy of about 4 km2 that has decreased by 20% in the last 15 years.
population: This is a common species within its very limited range (Díaz and Hedges 2009). The habitat is heavily fragmented, however, as this species is common in remnant habitat patches it is not clear whether the species qualifies as a severely fragmented population (A. Fong pers. comm. 2016).
range: This species is endemic to Cuba, where it is only known from the Península de Hicacos, Matanzas Province (Díaz and Hedges 2009).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Its known range lies within with  Paisaje Natural Protegido Varahicacos (González et al. 2012), but the conservation category of this area allows further low impact tourism development (CNAP 2013). Classified as Critically Endangered (CR) in the Cuban National Red List Assessment (González et al. 2012). Further research in population trends, threats, ecology and distribution are recommended for the species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that, while no threats to this species or its habitat have been identified, it is so far known from a very restricted area and apparently occurs at low population densities. Further research is therefore required to clarify the distribution of this species and to determine whether it occurs as a sufficiently small population to warrant listing in a threatened category.
habitat: Riyom is characterized by rocky cliffs up to 1,300 m above sea level within a savanna landscape (Trape et al. 2012). This diurnal species has been found close to caves and within faults in the rocks (Trape et al. 2012).
threats: Although this lizard is confined to the densely-populated Jos Plateau, within this region it is restricted to rocky cliff habitats which are probably not subject to significant human disturbance (J.-F. Trape pers. comm. 2012). It is unknown whether any specific threats to the gecko itself exist.
population: This species is only known from a small number of specimens at a single site (Trape et al. 2012).
range: This species is known only from Riyom, on Nigeria's Jos Plateau, and it is probably endemic to this region (Trape et al. 2012). Its extent of occurrence is, however, unknown, as while the species has so far only been recorded from one site, this is in an area of rocky cliffs that stretches for many kilometres which has rarely been surveyed for reptiles (J.-F. Trape pers. comm. 2012)
useTrade: This species is used by local communities as a fetish, but is only collected incidentally and is not specifically targeted (J.-F. Trape et al. 2012).
conservationActions: The species is not found in any protected areas, and there is not thought to be any immediate risk to its cliff habitats (J.-F. Trape pers. comm. 2012). Research is needed to clarify its distribution and population status, and to determine whether any specific threats exist.

rationale: Listed as Endangered on the basis that this species has an area of occupancy conservatively estimated at 40 km<sup>2</sup>, and certainly well below 500 km<sup>2</sup>, it is known from only five locations defined by threats from mining and deforestation, and there is a continuing decline in the quality and extent of its habitat as a result of these pressures.
habitat: This gecko is confined to high relief, rocky areas of dense humid forest (Trape et al. 2012). It occurs on cliffs, in caves, and among scree, where it is found during the day on rocks and tree trunks (Trape et al. 2012). It is found in adits (mine entrances) in abandoned mines around 60 years old, but is absent from areas with current large-scale mining operations (J. Penner pers. comm. 2012). It feeds on small insects (Trape et al. 2012).
threats: Deforestation, driven by logging and agricultural encroachment, and open-cast mining (e.g. for iron ore - M.-O. Rödel pers. comm. 2012) are the major threats to the species, threatening most or all known localities (M.-O. Rödel and J. Penner pers. comms. 2012).
population: There is no information on the population trends of this species, although it is known to be uncommon and highly localized (Trape et al. 2012; J. Penner pers. comm. 2012).
range: This species is apparently confined to several disjunct regions of West African montane forest: Mt. Nimba on the border between Liberia and Guinea, the Loma Mountains of Sierra Leone, the Ziama region of Guinea, and Mt. Tonkoui in Cote d'Ivôire (Trape et al. 2012). It has been recorded between 600 and 1,133 m asl. (J. Penner pers. obs.; Trape et al. 2012).
useTrade: It is unknown whether there is any use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is present in the protected areas of Ziama Forest Reserve and Mt. Nimba Biosphere Reserve.

rationale: Listed as Near Threatened because of an observed population decline of close to 30% in the last 10 years, due to ongoing habitat conversion and degradation in its range and possibly also due to the impact of chytridiomycosis, thus making the species close to qualifying for Vulnerable under criterion A.
habitat: This canopy-dwelling species occurs in lowland rainforests and montane humid forest, and lays eggs in tree holes where larvae develop and are tended by adults that lay unfertilized eggs to feed their young. It can be found in caves in the region of La Pera, Chiapas (Roberto Luna pers. comm.). It is found in both intact forest and, at least in Costa Rica and Panama, it can be common in young secondary growth forest and coffee plantations far from forest (B. Kubicki, B. Hilje and S. Rodríguez pers. comm. 2007). In Mexico it can be found in intact forest, and in coffee and banana plantations (L. Canseco and J.L. Aguilar-López pers. comm. Red List Assessment Workshop 2014).
threats: The most important threats to it are chytridiomycosis-related declines and severe disturbance, clearance and transformation of its original habitat to open areas, arising from small-holder farming and subsistence wood collecting. Collection from the wild is not thought to represent a threat to the species as many of the individuals found in the trade are from captive sources (B. Klocke pers. comm. June 2018). One specimen from Finca Kubicki in Guayacán, Costa Rica tested positive for the amphibian chytrid fungus, Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Zumbado-Ulate et al. 2019).
population:
This species is rare and has a very fragmented range. It is difficult to observe because it is a canopy species, but an increased understanding of its call and natural history have improved the ability of scientists to detect the species (Costa Rica Red List Assessment Workshop 2019).

In Mexico, the species appears to have disappeared from some sites, but it is still present at others. Between 2005 and 2014, more than 20 individuals were observed in historical and new localities in Veracruz, Puebla, Oaxaca, Chiapas, and Tabasco (Luría-Manzano et al. 2014, Térrez-Pérez and Barragan-Vázquez 2017). In Honduras, it is known only from a few specimens (Wilson et al. 2003), but no major declines have been detected (J. Townsend pers. comm. 2019).  

In Costa Rica, this species may have experienced declines and was formerly considered to be rare in the previous species' assessment. Pounds et al. (1997) noted that it disappeared from places around Monteverde. It is now frequently encountered and has been recorded in historical and new localities in recent years (Costa Rica Red List Assessment Workshop September 2019). It is common at Buenos Aires de Guapiles, Rainforest Adventures at the edge of Parque Nacional Braulio Carrillo (S. Salazar pers. comm. September 2019) and Turrialba area (C. Barrio-Amorós pers. comm. September 2019). Kubicki (2008) notes that it persists in Guayacán, where it can be regularly heard calling in the appropriate habitat. In San Vito, it was frequently encountered in the 1990s, but recent efforts to find the species there have not been successful (C. Barrio-Amorós pers. comm. September 2019).

In Panama, the species was never common, but it was regularly encountered at some sites. In recent years, the species has disappeared from several known sites, including the area around El Valle de Anton (Panama Red List Workshop 2015). These disappearances have been attributed to chytridiomycosis-related declines. It was last recorded from Cerro Bruja, Parque Nacional Chagres in 2007 (Sosa-Bartuano 2018), Reserva Hídrica Cerro Turega in 2010 (Sosa-Bartuano 2017) and one individual was heard on Cerro Gaital National Monument in 2015 (E. Griffith pers. comm. October 2015). It is reasonable to estimate a population decline of 20-25% in the last 10 years, due to ongoing habitat conversion and degradation in its range and possibly due to the impact of chytridiomycosis.
range: This species is found in eastern Mexico, eastern Honduras, central Costa Rica and central Panama, between 95-2,000 m asl. In Mexico, fragmented subpopulations exist on the Atlantic slopes of the Sierra de Los Tuxtlas in Veracruz, northern Oaxaca State in Chiapas, and new records have extended its range to southeast Puebla (Luría-Manzano et al. 2014) and southern Tabasco (Térrez-Pérez and Barragan-Vázquez 2017). It has not yet been recorded from Belize, Guatemala, El Salvador or Nicaragua, but McCranie et al. (2019) suggested the species would be found in southeastern Nicaragua.
useTrade: This species is in the international pet trade. In Costa Rica there is not much, if any, off-take from the wild (Costa Rica Red List Assessment Workshop September 2019).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is protected in Los Tuxtlas and El Ocote Biosphere Reserves in Mexico, Parque Nacional Braulio Carrillo and Reserva Biológica Alberto Manuel Brenes in Costa Rica, Parque Internacional La Amistad in Panama, and Reserva Biológica Tawahka Asagni in Honduras. It is a high priority species in Panama's National Amphibian Conservation Action Plan (ANAM 2011) and is listed as a species of high concern in Honduras (Wilson et al. 2003). An ex situ population of this species is breeding at the Panama Amphibian Rescue and Conservation Project (Gratwicke et al. 2016), and some individuals are maintained and bred at US zoos and aquariums although they are not managed as part of a species' survival plan. The Costa Rican Amphibian Research Center (B. Kubicki pers. comm. September 2019) and Rainforest Adventures (S. Salazar pers. comm. September 2019) have in-situ efforts to supplement natural breeding sites with artificial ones. 

Conservation Needed
Habitat management including habitat protection, improved management of protected areas and legislation is required, in addition to the development of a range-wide species conservation plan.

Research Needed 
The research priorities for the next five years include the following goals: 1) document and calculate historic vs. current area of occupancy, 2) evaluate Bd-susceptibility of the species, 3) clarify the taxonomic questions detailed in Faivovich et al. (2018) suggesting that this is in fact a species complex and eastern subpopulations (Costa Rica and Panama) may represent new species (see taxonomic note), 4) acoustic monitoring is required to improve the understanding of the distribution of this canopy-dwelling species.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 1,732 km2, it is known from three threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat on the Peninsula de Barahona, Hispaniola due to a variety of threats.
habitat: It is found in dry scrub forest, and retreats by day into caves and rock crevices. It can be found in rural gardens and pastures, in so far as they are on karst formations (M. Rodriguez and L. Diaz pers. comms. March 2011). Eggs are laid on the ground, and it breeds by direct development.
threats: The main threat is habitat loss from conversion to cattle pastures, charcoaling and infrastructure development for human settlement (villages and small towns). There is also a cement factory that is fed by limestone mining within the range of the species (S. Inchaustegui pers. comm. March 2011).
population: It is a very common species in suitable habitat (in 2008, ten individuals were collected over the span of two hours and in 2010 a total of 13 individuals were collected in one cave; M. Rodriguez and L. Diaz pers. comms. March 2011). Its population is not considered to be severely fragmented as defined by the IUCN Guidelines.
range: This species occurs on the Peninsula de Barahona, in Hispaniola, from sea level up to 600 m asl. It occurs in three threat-defined locations (M. Rodriguez and L. Diaz pers. comms. March 2011). Its range, taken as a proxy for extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 1,732 km2.
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
It occurs in Parque Nacional Jaragua and Parque Nacional Sierra de Bahoruco, but these parks are not well managed and significant habitat destruction is ongoing within the park's limits; these protected areas are in need of improved and strengthened management for biodiversity conservation, and additional habitat protection is also needed. The species is also present in the Reserva Cientifica Via Panorámica Aceitillar. More information is needed on this species' population status and ecology.

The Amphibian Ark Conservation Needs Assessment process identified this species as a candidate for ex situ research.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its tolerance of a degree of habitat modification and presumed large population.
habitat: This is a nocturnal species of primary humid lowland forest, and secondary forest. Adults are found under surface debris and in leaf-litter, its range often associated with caves or rocky stream banks. It breeds by direct development.
threats: There are no major threats to this species at present, though the species may be susceptible to chytrid fungus as it was detected in Panama before the epizootic, but was not detected afterwards in 2006 or 2007 (Woodhams et al. 2008).
population: It is relatively rare in Costa Rica and common in Panama, though it has been extirpated in El Copé (Crawford et al. 2010). The population is presumed to be stable.
range: This species is known from the Atlantic lowlands from extreme southeastern Costa Rica to eastern Panama and on the Pacific versant in central Colombia; subpopulations in the river valleys of Sinú, Cauca, and Magdalena are questionably placed here (following Lynch 1986). It occurs at elevations from 10-1,200 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions: The species has been recorded from many protected areas in Panama and Colombia and one in Costa Rica.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 516 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in five or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, and the number of mature individuals and extant subpopulations.
habitat: This species lives in caves and crevices in pine-oak forest, and has also been recorded from a tunnel under a church. It is terrestrial and breeds by direct development. Some of the localities where this species is no longer recorded have been degraded by human activities, including clearing all the forest. It is therefore not thought to be tolerant of habitat disturbance (S. Rovito pers. comm. October 2019).
threats:
Deforestation for wood extraction and the expansion of small-scale agriculture are a major threat to this species. The removal of the forest habitat from areas above caves causes the caves to dry out, resulting in the apparent disappearance of most of this species' population. In addition, Cueva de Ahuacatlan, located beneath the aforementioned church, is filled with human waste and garbage, while Cueva de Potrerillos had vestiges of a large bonfire (T. Burkhardt pers. comm. 2006, S. Rovito pers. comm. October 2019). Bd samples from between 1964–2019 were tested and returned positive results for the time shortly before the species is thought to have started declining (S. Rovito unpubl data 2019).

The emergence of the salamander chytrid fungus (Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans, “Bsal”) as an amphibian pathogen has caused dramatic declines in European salamanders since its arrival in 2010 through the international pet trade (Feldmeier et al. 2016). While the presence of the fungus has not been confirmed in the Americas, it is spreading in Europe and risks spreading further. The threat of infection and population declines in salamanders is thought to be highly likely and detrimental to the majority of native species, should the fungus arrive in Mexico (Basanta et al. 2019, Mexico Red List Assessment Workshop October 2019). However, a study by Basanta et al. (2019) used ecological niche modelling to infer the suitable distribution of Bsal and found that this salamander's distribution does not seem to overlap with B sal suitable areas. However, Bsal could have different strains with genetic physiological and virulence differences, such as the case with Bd (Rosenblum et al. 2013), so further work is needed to understand any potential threat of Bsal to this species (Basanta et al. 2019).
population: Although this species has never been common, it used to be seen regularly prior to the 1970s (S. Rovito pers. comm. October 2019). Regular surveys to the type locality and its vicinity in San Luis Potosí recorded only a single individual between 2004-2019, however the species is regularly encountered at another locality in San Luis Potosí (S. Rovito pers. comm. October 2019). It was found once in extreme eastern Querétaro in 2005, north of known localities in the state, and at a new locality in Hidalgo in 2010 where it has been regularly recorded over the last nine years (S. Rovito pers. comm. October 2019). The species seems to have disappeared from most of its historical localities, even though it is being found at new localities (S. Rovito pers. comm. 2014, 2019). These declines coincide with the arrival of Bd in Mexico (S. Rovito pers. comm. October 2019).
