Defining and refining core and buffer areas is a critical part of the ongoing management of these Reserves. Roosting sites of bats should be included as a layer in determining the location of such zones within biosphere reserves. This means that important bat underground (natural and man-made) roosts (including those of  R. smithersi) should be included wherever possible in core or buffer areas where developments (including mining) would have to be regulated. Such conservation zonation plans (including Strategic Environmental Frameworks, EMFs) would inform planning by Provincial Nature Conservation (including the protected areas expansion strategy) and municipal Integrated Development Plans (IDPs), thereby affording protection to roosting sites.

rationale: <span lang="EN-GB">Listed as Least Concern because it is relatively widespread in Mozambique and eastern Zimbabwe. Its extent of occurrence is >20,000 km<sup>2</sup> and its area of occupancy (cave roosting sites) is probably >2,000 km<sup>2</sup>. Although its population is probably decreasing through bushmeat hunting and guano mining, there is no evidence that the decrease has been rapid enough to warrant Near Threatened or threatened status.
habitat: The natural history of this newly described species is largely unknown. R. mossambicus usually roosts in limestone caves. It is associated with the southern savanna biome, in intact and disturbed habitats. Its altitudinal range extends from 60– 500 m in Mozambique, and to 1000 m Asl in NW Zimbabwe (Taylor et al. 2012).
threats: This species is collected for bushmeat in Mozambique (particularly in the Inhassoro province). Additionally, the local communities disturb the roosts of this species with guano mining activities.
population: There is no information on population size. Museum specimens have been collected from seven sites in Mozambique, and one locality in Zimbabwe (Monadjem et al., 2010a, b; Taylor et al. 2012; S.M. Goodman and M.C. Schoeman, unpublished data). Population sizes at roost sites were estimated between 50 – 400 (Monadjem et al. 2010b; S.M. Goodman and M.C. Schoeman unpublished data). Environmental niche models suggest additional roost sites may be present, but the localities are unknown.
range: Records across the southern African subregion combined with environmental niche models suggest that R. mossambicus is widespread in the savanna biome in Mozambique and north-west Zimbabwe (Monadjem et al. 2010a, b; Taylor et al. 2012). The species is known from a wide elevational range, from as low as 60 m to at least 500 m Asl in Mozambique and 1000 m Asl in Zimbabwe.
useTrade: This species is collected for bushmeat in Mozambique (particularly in the Inhassoro province).
conservationActions: R. mossambicus has been recorded from Niassa Game Reserve and Gorongosa National Park. Additional surveys are needed to learn more about the distribution, natural history and threats to this species. Existing cave roosts need to be protected from guano mining and hunting for bushmeat (S.M. Goodman and M.C. Schoeman unpublished data). Other potential threats include habitat loss (due to charcoal collecting and logging) and fire.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of the large extent of occurrence, area of occupancy, number of subpopulations, and population size, and because the species probably is not declining.
habitat: This species is mostly semi-fossorial, inhabiting in a wide variety of environments, from dry to humid, including pine forest, grass flatwoods, grasslands, open rock areas, and tropical hammocks.
threats: No major threats are known. Habitat destruction is a local threat in some areas, but this species tolerates a fair amount of low intensity habitat alteration.
population: This species is represented by a large number of occurrences (subpopulations). Adult population size is unknown but presumably exceeds 10,000 and probably exceeds 100,000. Extent of occurrence, area of occupancy, number of subpopulations, and population size probably are relatively stable or declining at a rate of less than 10% over 10 years or three generations.
range: This species is endemic to the eastern and southeastern United States. Its range extends from southern New Jersey, Maryland, and Kentucky southward to southeastern Louisiana, southern Mississippi, southern Alabama, and southern Florida (Conant and Collins 1991, Burbrink 2002). Introduced populations have been recorded on several islands of the Caribbean, with established introduced populations in the Bahamas (New Providence and Grand Bahama), Grand Cayman, the US Virgin Islands (St. Thomas), and the Lesser Antilles (Saint Barthélemy; and Guana Cay of Pelikan, a satellite of Sint Maarten) (Buckner and Franz 1994, Henderson and Powell 2009, Perry et al. 2003, Powell and Henderson 2012, Seidel and Franz 1994, R. Powell pers. comm. 2016). It is unknown whether all of these introduced populations are extant (R. Powell pers. comm. 2016), although it is still (uncommonly) recorded on Grand Cayman. Isolated records, presumed to be waifs rather than established populations, are known from multiple additional islands within most of these island groups and from Grand Turk in Turks and Caicos (R. Powell pers. comm. 2016).
useTrade: In the United States, it is a common pet.
conservationActions: Many occurrences are in protected areas.

rationale: This species occurs on at least fourteen islands on several island banks, is adaptable to human-modified habitats, and so has been assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This is a xerophilic species, which is found around coastal habitats including human settlements. It has also been found in Cocos plantations, on beaches, under rocks on the roadside, and in caves.
threats: Development activities have not had any major negative effects on subpopulations of this geckos, and it is not thought to be subject to major threats.
population: There is no population density information available for this species. Its population status is unknown.
range: This species is endemic to the Bahamas. It is found on Crooked Island, Fortune Island, Rum Cay, North Cay, Fish Cay, Acklin Island, Castle Island, San Salvador, Man Head Cay, Green Cay, Low Cay, East Plana Cay, West Plana Cay, Samana Cay (Schwartz and Thomas 1975). Reports from Conception Island are questionable (Franz and Buckner 1998). The total area of these islands is approximately 700 km².
useTrade: There is no information on any use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: The species occurs in a number of protected areas.

rationale: Chilabothrus inornatus is assessed as Least Concern due to its large distribution, lack of widespread threats, and ability to inhabit altered environments. Population numbers have declined in the past but this boa is still relatively common in many areas, and occurs in several protected areas.
habitat: This species is found in a variety of habitats. It occurs in moist forests, dry forests, karst landscape, caves, and even altered environments such as plantations, rural gardens, and urban areas.
threats: This species has undoubtedly been threatened in the past and declined in numbers. Habitat loss and fragmentation are the major threat to the species. Road construction destroys habitat and creates areas where the snakes are killed when crossing roads. It is preyed upon by introduced cats and mongooses, and captured for the pet trade. People will kill animals when they see them because of a fear of snakes.
population: This species is described as common in undisturbed karst areas of northwestern Puerto Rico (Tolson and Henderson 1993). Much of the boa's apparent rarity undoubtedly relates to observers' difficulties in visually detecting the species in forests (Wunderle et al. 2004), and this boa is not as rare as previously thought (Puente-Rolon and Bird-Pico 2004). Although the species is probably less abundant than it was in pre-Columbian times, recent accounts indicate that it is still widespread on Puerto Rico.
range: This species is widely distributed in Puerto Rico, and is especially abundant in the northern karst region (Acevedo-Torres et al. 2005). This species has an elevational range of 0 to 480 m above sea level.
useTrade: This species is captured and sold in the pet trade. On a very small scale, fat is extracted from this species because their oil is used in traditional medicine.
conservationActions: This species occurs in many protected areas. It is legally protected by the US Endangered Species Act of 1973. Listed on CITES Appendix I (as Chilabothrus monensis or Epicrates inornatus).

rationale: Least Concern because of its large extent of occurrence, it is thought to have a stable population, it occurs in several protected areas, and the threats do not affect it fast enough to qualify for a more threatened category.
habitat: This species is found in mesophyllous evergreen and semideciduous forest, mogote vegetation complex, and coastal and subcoastal microphillous forest. It is most frequently found on limestone cliffs and the mouths of caves. It feeds on invertebrates and other lizards including its own congeners. It is an egg-laying species (Henderson and Powell 2009).
threats: Habitat loss as a result of deforestation due to agriculture, livestock farming and urban expansion are considered to be localized threats. There is no evidence to indicate that they ate causing population decline in the species at present.
population: This species is abundant. This species has been reported to reach densities of 428-1,404 individuals/ha, with an encounter rate in coastal scrub of 11.5 lizards/hour (Rodríguez-Schettino 1999).
range: This species is endemic to Cuba where it occurs in the mainland from La Habana Province east to Holguín, Granma, and Santiago de Cuba Provinces. It is also known from Archipiélago de los Canarreos, apparently as an introduced population (Henderson and Powell 2009, Rodríguez-Schettino et al. 2013).
useTrade: There is no significant use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: The distribution of this species coincides with several protected areas. There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Further research in population trends, ecology and distribution is recommended for the species.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern, although it has an extent of occurrence below 10,000 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in rocky habitats subject to no major threats, it is common, and not is thought to be declining.
habitat: This gecko is found in caves, crevices and overhangs, where it is most active during damp evenings in the wet season (Cogger 2014). Animals feed on insects, spiders and smaller geckos in the trees (Cogger 2014).
threats: Fire is a localized threat, but its rocky habitats may give it some protection from any impacts.
population: It is relatively common in appropriate habitats.
range: This species is restricted to the northwest Kimberley region in Western Australia (Cogger 2014). It occurs on Boongaree Island.
useTrade: This species can be kept as a pet, but licenses are required for capture of wild individuals.
conservationActions: There are currently no species-specific conservation actions in place for this species. It is known to occur within the Mitchell River and Prince Regent National Parks (Atlas of Living Australia 2015).

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that this species is relatively common and, despite localized habitat degradation due to fire in parts of its range, it is subject to no major threats.
habitat: This species is found in caves and crevices, and in low vegetation of sandstone hills in the western Arnhem Land escarpments (Cogger 2014).
threats: Changes in fire regimes are degrading the species' habitat in localized portions of the range.
population: This can be a common species in some places, but is hard to find.
range: This Australian species occurs on the Arnhem plateau and escarpment, in the northern Northern Territory (Cogger 2014).
useTrade: This species can be kept as a pet in some states and territories of Australia with the appropriate license.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation actions in place for this species. It has been recorded within Kakadu National Park (Atlas of Living Australia 2015) and two indigenous areas: Warddeken and Djelk.

rationale: The species is endemic to Cuba and the Bahamas, but has a wide distribution and is broadly tolerant of human impacts within this range, and so is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species is found in xeric woods, broadleaf forest, coastal scrub on small cays, and human habitations, where it is associated with leaf litter and other surface debris. It is an egg laying species (Henderson and Powell 2009).
threats: While it is most common in forest, the species appears to tolerate human impacts (R.G. Reynolds pers. comm. 2015). In Cuba localized threats to the species include habitat loss due to  agricultural activities, livestock farming and urban expansion (A. Fong. pers. comm. 2016).
population: The species is quite common, but localized (R.G. Reynolds pers. comm. 2015).
range: This species occurs in many islands of the Bahamas, and on Cuba, including the satellite islands of Archipiélago de Sabana-Camaguey and Cayos los Ballenatos (Henderson and Powell 2009).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: The species occurs in many protected areas. No conservation measures are needed for the species as a whole, however, it is composed of several subspecies, each one with its own distinct distribution, and some of which may warrant local assessment to clarify whether they are subject to specific threats and of conservation concern.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence is less than 555 km<sup>2</sup>, and it occurs at two locations affected by habitat loss and habitat fragmentation due to deforestation for urban and tourism development and livestock farming.
habitat: This species is from areas with vegetation characterized by Sea-grape (Coccoloba uvifera) and dry scrub forest (Hedges et al. 1999, Torres et al. 2013). Individuals have been collected on a coastal limestone cliff  (Hedges et al. 1999) and in the mouth of a cave (Torres et al. 2013). One specimen regurgitated an Eleutherodactylus blairhedgesi (Hedges et al. 1999).
threats: The two localities where the species has been collected are places of tourist influx (González et al. 2012, Torres et al. 2013). In Carbonera there is also livestock activity with abundant and extensive pastures. The forest remnants are found around the entrances of the caves and are small, consisting of secondary vegetation and are degraded (Torres et al. 2013). Exotic introduced species, such as the mongoose, are predators of juveniles and adult snakes, however, at this point, it is not known how this mammal impact this snake's population.
population: There are no population information about this species.
range: This species is endemic to Cuba where it is known only from two localities: on Loma de Canasí, Mayabeque province and on Carbonera, Matanzas province (González et al. 2012, Torres et al. 2013). It has been collected at 3 m asl (Hedges et al. 1999).
useTrade: The species is being captured for export for the illegal pet trade, and the number of individuals captured could become indiscriminate in the future.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. One of the localities where the species has been found is in Reserva Florística Manejada Canasí, however, no legal designation as a protected area has been approved for this site (CNAP 2013). Further research in population trends, threats, ecology and distribution are recommended for the species. Legal protected status is recommended for Reserva Florística Manejada Canasí. The species is classified as Critically Endangered (CR) in the Cuban National Red List assessment. The family Tropidophiidae is included in Appendix II of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) (González et al. 2012).

rationale: Listed as Least Concern because although it has a restricted extent of occurrence (about 1,290 km<sup>2</sup>), all of its distribution is within a protected area and while threats have been identified, these are presently localized.
habitat: The species is known from coastal and sub-coastal xeric scrub and semi-deciduous mesophyllous forest (González et al. 2012). It is found in caves and shaded rocky areas of modified limestone rocks known as “diente de perro” (Domínguez et al. 2006), always within forested areas (A. Fong pers. comm. 2016).
threats: Although all the range of the species is within a protected area, localized threats include habitat loss due to deforestation through logging activity (González et al. 2012, A. Fong pers. comm. 2016).
population: It is an uncommon species.
range: This species is endemic to Cuba, where it occurs on Guanahacabibes Peninsula, Pinar del Río province (Domínguez et al. 2006, Rodríguez-Schettino et al. 2013). Its elevation range is between sea level to 25 m asl (González et al. 2012).
useTrade: The species is being collected for export from Cuba for the illegal pet trade, and the number of individuals captured could increase in the future if the demand for the species persists.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. However, all the the range of this species coincides with  Área Protegida de Recursos Manejados Península de Guanahacabibes. Classified as Endangered (EN) in the Cuban National Red List assessment (González et al. 2012).  The family Tropidophiidae  is included in Appendix I of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) (González et al. 2012).  Further research in population trends, threats, ecology and distribution are recommended for the species.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern since, although its known extent of occurrence (EOO) is less than 10 km<sup>2</sup>, it is expected to occur more widely, there are no current threats and the species adapts to disturbed habitats,
habitat: This species has been found in primary and secondary rainforest but is more common close to largely cleared village areas (Kraus and Allison 2009). It is abundant inside large caves comprised of smooth clay, sometimes found up to 20 m deep inside caves where males have been observed calling from small ledges (Kraus and Allison 2009). Equally, individuals also commonly inhabit grassy and lightly treed areas surrounding the mouths to these caves (Kraus and Allison 2009). When disturbed, this species plays dead and refuses to move (Kraus and Allison 2009). It breeds by direct development.
threats:
There are no major threats to this species.

Presently, there are no records of infectious amphibian chytrid fungi (Batrachochytrium spp.) on New Guinea (Bower et al. 2017, 2019). There is a risk that human activities may introduce these fungi to the island. While there is no known significant impact on closely-related microhylids in Australia, there are records of declines caused by chytridiomycosis on direct-developing species in other families. Therefore, should chytrids be detected on New Guinea, this species should be re-assessed as a matter of urgency as it could be at risk of infection and decline (Melanesia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019).
population: It appears to be locally abundant in areas close to human habitation (Kraus and Allison 2009). Its population trend is unknown.
range: This species is known from the vicinity of the type locality on the northeastern slopes of the Muller Range, Southern Highlands Province, Papua New Guinea, between 1,700-2,180 m asl (Kraus and Allison 2009). It is likely to occur at similar elevations throughout the Muller Range (F. Kraus and S. Richards pers. comm. August 2019).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
The species does not occur in any protected areas.

Conservation Needed
Declines due to the arrival of chytrids are known to be rapid and severe. Therefore, a common analogue species should be identified and the capacity for ex-situ conservation (e.g. captive assurance populations and genome banking) should be developed in country. There is a high risk that the introduction of chytrids could be caused by human activities, “enforcing quarantine measures through policy changes, investing in compliance, promoting education, and minimizing risks, including transportation of infected sources” (Bower et al. 2019) is strongly recommended (Melanesia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019). 

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: The species is listed as Vulnerable, it has a small geographic range, known from 2-3 locations. Its area of occupancy is around 1,000 km². Hurricanes and severe weather are the main threats to island populations, also its forest habitat is declining due to expansion of tourism activities (new buildings). These threats might affect the species and other insectivorous species by changing or reducing availability of prey.
habitat: This bat is poorly known. It is insectivorous (Nowak 1999), but there is no information on its habitat and ecology. On Barbados, M. nyctor was found near caves, gullies and rocky outcrops (LaVal and Schwartz 1974). More recently it was confirmed near the same caves, but also near a river with freshwater pools with densely packed trees, and also near cliffs with rock crevices (Genoways et al. 2011).
threats: Hurricanes and severe weather are the main threats to island populations. At a smaller scale, changes in cover land use might affect this and other insectivorous species by changing or reducing availability of prey.
population: The species roosts in caves (Timm and Genoways 2003). It can also be found in anthropogenic habitats (Rodriguez Duran and Kunz 2001).
range: This species occurs in Lesser Antilles, Barbados and possibly Grenada (Simmons 2005, Larsen et al. 2012, Pedersen et al. 2013).
conservationActions: More research is necessary to establish the actual distribution of the species. The morphological and genetic distinction of the Grenada population might indicate subspecific status. No data exist on its use of habitat resources or reproduction, making it difficult to propose what conservation actions are needed.

rationale: Listed as Near Threatened since although its extent of occurrence is probably less than 5,000 km2 and its habitat might be declining, thus making the species close to qualifying for Vulnerable, it probably occurs in more than ten locations, and its range is probably not severely fragmented. If Speleomantes ambrosii bianchii is reassigned to S. italicus rather than S. ambrosii, the extent of occurrence and number of locations for S. ambrosii will be reduced, and reassessment will be necessary.
habitat: It is known from humid rocky outcrops, caves, crevices, and forested areas in the vicinity of streams. Individuals may occasionally be found climbing in vegetation. The species reproduces through the direct development of a few terrestrial eggs.
threats: Threats to this species include general localized loss of suitable habitat and illegal collection.
population: It is generally common within its limited range, with no evidence of any decline.
range: This species is restricted to scattered localities (at least 12 localities are known) in La Spezia Province, north-west Italy. The populations east of the Magra River around Massa Carrara belong to a recently discovered subspecies, Speleomantes ambrosii bianchii. Genetic research indicates that this subspecies may actually belong to S. italicus rather than S. ambrosii (Carranza et al. 2007). There is an introduced population in Monteviggioni (Siena, Tuscany). It is found at altitudes ranging from near sea level to around 2,300 m asl.
conservationActions: It is present in Parco Nazionale delle Cinque Terre and Parco Naturale delle Alpi Apuane. The species has a very restricted range and needs further conservation attention. Prior to being considered a separate species S. ambrosii was listed on Appendix II of the Bern Convention under S. italicus. It is also listed on Annex IV of the EU Habitats Directive.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 8 km2 and its area of occupancy (AOO) is c. 4 km2, it occurs in a single threat-defined location, and there is a continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: Adults of this species generally range in both forest and fynbos biomes, breeding in clear perennial streams in ravines on Table Mountain. Adults have been found in damp, sheltered habitat well away from streams, including in caves. The tadpoles require longer than 12 months to complete metamorphosis, and so it is important that there is perennial water to allow the larvae to develop.
threats:
The main threats are the spread of alien vegetation, suppression of the natural fire regime in fynbos potentially causing bush encroachment, and the presence of water storage reservoirs on the mountain which can affect the consistency of stream-flow. Soil erosion caused by human pedestrian traffic on hiking paths may be a threat around some of the streams (Skelton Gorge and Nursery Ravine). Water abstraction from Windows Gorge by Kirstenbosch Gardens has resulted in 150 m of habitat loss below the abstraction point and limits the vertical movement of tadpoles in summer when abstraction occurs (K. A. Tolley unpub. data 2015). Monitoring in 2013 showed that c. 27% of the total tadpole counts in Windows Gorge and 24% of metamorphs were below this abstraction point during spring, with these pools becoming dry and vacant of individuals once abstraction began in January 2014 (K. A. Tolley unpub. data 2013). It is presumed that any tadpoles below the abstraction point are eliminated from the population once abstraction begins.

Plantations (for exotic trees) used to be a threat but have now been largely removed so that these no longer pose a risk to the species. Other threats to this species which are listed have not been quantified and assessments of each must be made in order to unify the future conservation effort.
population:
Adults of this species are elusive, and are only seen occasionally, whereas tadpoles are typically plentiful where habitat is suitable. Subpopulations on Disa and Original Disa streams are considered stable (Minter et al. 2004; de Villiers unpub. data 2015) as the habitat there is not impacted. The number of tadpoles in Skeleton Gorge may have decreased, but monitoring of tadpole numbers suggests that populations at Windows and Skeleton Gorges are likely stable at present above the water abstraction point (K. A. Tolley, E. Le Roux and A. de Villiers unpub. data 2014). However, during the summer, the stream below abstraction point dries up and is likely to cause declines within the subpopulations at Windows Gorge as tadpoles cannot survive. In recent years, tadpoles were rarely recorded from Nursery Gorge (A. de Villiers, unpub. data 2015). Tadpoles were historically found in Cecelia Gorge, but they have not been recorded since 1980 (Minter et al. 2004) due to heavy land transformation and afforestation around that stream. It is thought that they are locally extinct at that locality (Minter et al. 2004), although it should be noted that the upper reaches of Cecelia were not transformed but have not been searched due to difficulty of access.

At least two of the streams (Windows and Skeleton Gorges) can be considered a single genetic population (K. A. Tolley unpub. data), while other streams have not yet been investigated.
range: This species occurs in a single threat-defined location and has a very restricted range as it is endemic to the southern and eastern slopes of Table Mountain, in the Western Cape province, extreme southwestern South Africa, between 240–1,060 m Asl. It was historically recorded from eight streams, but is currently only present in five. It is no longer present in Platteklip Gorge, Valley of the Red Gods and Cecilia streams (A. de Villiers pers. comm. August 2016). The Cecilia subpopulation is considered to have been locally extinct for decades (Minter et al. 2004). Its AOO is around 4 km2 and its EOO is 8 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species' entire range is incorporated in the Table Mountain National Park, which is believed to protect more than 70% of the species' population, and the estate of Kirstenbosch National Botanic Gardens (South African National Biodiversity Institute) which has no special protection. The species has been considered Endangered since 1998 (and Critically Endangered since 2004). In 2014, the Table Mountain Ghost Frog Action Group was formed consisting of the main stakeholders, to review the threats and to establish an action based framework for conservation of this species. 

Research and monitoring are being carried out to estimate population size through occupancy modeling, and to establish whether there is connectivity between streams using genetic analyses. Each stream is also being systematically surveyed over their entire lengths to record presence/absences.The monitoring of tadpole populations and threats to stream habitat will continue.

Conservation Needed
High priorities for action relate to rehabilitation of Cecelia Gorge by SANParks, improvement of water quality in Skeleton Gorge, and setting ecological reserves (including improvement of stream habitats below water abstraction points) for Nursery and Windows Gorges.

Research Needed
The relative impact of threats must be researched, and an action plan would allow highlights for areas requiring future work (A. de Villiers pers. comm. August 2016).

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 20 km², it occurs in one threat-defined location and there is ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat. It has been tagged as Possibly Extinct as it was last seen in 1962 and recent surveys in 2010 failed to detect this species, although it is acknowledged that it may not have been an optimum time in which to detect the species (e.g. not during rains).
habitat: Most of the specimens were collected in sinkholes or caves and a few were found in open montane grassland. It presumably breeds by direct development.
threats: There is very little direct information available for this poorly known species and threats to the species are not well understood. During a survey in 2010, the vicinity of the type locality was found to be intact (J. Harvey pers. comm. 2012). However, there are both diamond and gold mining activities locally. The diamond mine at Chimanimani is currently outside the national park, but artisanal mining is known to have caused significant riparian damage on the Zimbabwe side (supposedly worse in the southern part of the park) and is also known to take place in fluvial areas on the Mozambique side  (M. Cunningham pers. comm. 2012). Furthermore, rumours were circulating during a visit in 2010 that the government was considering deproclaiming part of the national park for a commercial gold mine (M. Cunningham pers. comm. 2012). Thus, considering the available data, it is not implausible that mining activities pose a threat to the species. Finally, as with other species occurring in isolated montane habitats, it could be at risk from the effects of climate change.
population: It is probably a rare species. It was not found during a survey in 2010, but this may have been due to the time of year, e.g. not during the rains (J. Harvey pers. comm. 2012). There have been no records since this species was discovered in 1962 (when 16 specimens were collected) and it is thought that this species could be possibly extinct.
range: This species is known only from a single threat-defined location - its type locality - in the western Chimanimani Mountains in eastern Zimbabwe, where it occurs above 1,500 m asl (Poynton 1963). However, the Chimanimani Mountains extend into Mozambique so the species is likely to occur across the border. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 20 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
The area from which it has been recorded is protected, primarily in the Chimanimani National Park, but the level and effectiveness of protection is unknown. 

Conservation Needed
Conservation measures can be recommended if this species is recorded again.

Research Needed
Research is needed on this species' taxonomic status, distribution, population status and natural history. Surveys are urgently needed to relocate this species and should also aim to determine population trends.

rationale: Tarentola americana has been assessed as Least Concern. This species has a wide distribution across Cuba and the Bahamas, is abundant in places, and can inhabit anthropogenic environments.
habitat: This species is found on cliffs, in caves, around coconut trees, and in house walls and rafters.
threats: This species is associated with caves, which are often severely impacted by even minimal human disturbance (Buide 1966, Dodd 2003) - such as, at least historically, by bat guano collection (S.D. Buckner pers. comm. 2015). Nevertheless, at present there are not thought to be any major threats across its range as a whole.
population: This species has been reported to be rare throughout its range (Schwartz 1968), but it is abundant in suitable habitat (Buide 1966, Henderson and Powell 2009).
range: This species is found throughout Cuba, including Isla de la Juventud and the Archipiélago de Sabana-Camagüey, and on the Great Bahama Bank (Díaz and Hedges 2008, Henderson and Powell 2009). The range of the Bahamas endemic subspecies Tarentola americana warreni includes the islands of Andros, Eleuthera, Great Exuma Island, Long Island, the Ragged Island range (Great Ragged, Little Ragged, Flamingo Cay, and Water Cay), and many smaller islands in between.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is likely that this species occurs in several protected areas of Cuba, and it has been recorded in Exuma Cays Land and Sea Park in the Bahamas (S.D. Buckner pers. comm. 2015). Additional surveys would be valuable.

rationale: Tropidophis pardalis has been assessed as Least Concern, as it is found in a broad area of western Cuba (its distribution elsewhere in Cuba is poorly known) and surrounding islets, with no major threats affecting the species at present. However, as habitat loss is extensive on Cuba, any future declines of the habitat, range or population of this species could lead to a threatened category in future assessments.
habitat: Not much is known about this species' ecology, but it appears to be mesophilic and has been found in wooded areas, parks, river banks, and rain forest (Schwartz and Henderson 1991). It is nocturnal and ground-dwelling, being found during the day under rocks in cave hollows, in rock piles in recently cut woods and on rocky hills. It has also been found in grass stalking Anolis and amidst palm fronds on the ground (Schwartz and Henderson 1991). All species of the Tropidophis genus are viviparous (Hedges 2002).
threats: Localized threats to the species include habitat loss due to agricultural activities, livestock farming and urban expansion. Also, exotic introduced species, such as the mongoose, are predators of juveniles and adult snakes, however, at this point, it is not known how this mammal impact this snake's population.
population: In the past, this species has been found in moderate abundance in some localities, such as around the city of Havana. It is also one of the more frequently encountered Cuban species in the genus Tropidophis. However, its range is disjunct, even in western Cuba, and it is not among the most common snakes in Cuba (Henderson and Powell 2009).
range: This species inhabits Cuba and neighbouring islands, including the Archipelago de Sabana-Camaguey (Cayo Coco, Cayo Paredon Grande) and Isla de la Juventud (Schwartz and Henderson 1991). Its primary distribution on the main island is in western Cuba, including Pinar del Rio and La Habana provinces. The species is known from relatively few localities elsewhere in Cuba, and is clearly not continuously distributed throughout the island.
useTrade: The species is been collected for export from Cuba for the illegal pet trade, and the number of individuals captured could increase in the future if the demand for the species persists.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place, or needed, for this species. However, part of the range of this species coincides with numerous protected areas. The family Tropidophiidae is included in Appendix II of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) (González et al. 2012). Further research in population trends, ecology and distribution are recommended for the species.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence is about 563 km<sup>2</sup>, and it is found in two locations that are affected by a continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat due to agriculture activities, urban expansion and tourism development.  This species is under a high risk of extinction, even more so since any part of its range coincides with a protected area. Further research should be carried out to determine the population size and distribution of this species.
habitat: The type locality is located on the coast and is a region of low elevation karst topography (Hedges and Garrido 2002), presumably with dry broadleaf forests. Díaz et al. (2014) described the other known locality as a sub-coastal karstic plateau with abundant caves, and semideciduous forest on limestone of marine origin as the original habitat surrounding the caves. Many of these caves have sinkholes that allow sunshine and rain to enter, conditions conducive to the development of shrubs and vines in some chambers. The caves floor is red soil with rock mounds under sinkholes. These authors found their specimens inside caves, and no individuals were observed outside the cave system. Specimens were collected on the floor of the caves (until 100 m from the entrance); in a sinkhole containing some vegetation, leaf litter, and rocks; and hidden within a hole in a rock (the specimens retreated into the hole when disturbed by headlamps). It feeds on frogs of the genus Eleutherodactylus (Díaz et al. 2014).
threats: The main threats are habitat loss and fragmentation due to deforestation for agriculture, livestock farming and urban expansion (residential and tourism areas), which is accentuated by the small range of this species. The type locality is a beach site with a big tourist influx. In the other known locality, the human impact is evident in the rubbish dumping, cattle farming, and military use of caves (Díaz et al. 2014). Also, the highly invasive Sicklebush (Dichrostachys cinerea) forms dense thickets, displacing original vegetation around caves (Díaz et al. 2014).Exotic introduced species, particularly mongoose, is a predator of juveniles and adult snakes, however, at this point, it is not known how this mammal impacts this snake populations.
population: It is an uncommon species. Only seven specimens are known, the holotype collected in 1945 (Hedges and Garrido 1992) and the others more recently in 2014 (Díaz et al. 2014).
range: This species is only known from Holguin Province, in the northern coast of eastern Cuba. It is known from Guardalavaca (Hedges and Garrido 2002) and Gibara (Díaz et al. 2014). The separation between both localities is about 68 km2 in airline distance (Díaz et al. 2014). The species has been found from near sea level to 20 m asl (Hedges and Garrido 2002, Díaz et al. 2014). Torres and Garrido (2017) map a potential distribution based on the availability of suitable habitat that extends further to the west and east than these records suggest, but would represent a maximum extent of occurrence of at most 3,000 km2.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species does not occur within a protected area and no known species-specific conservation measures are in place. The establishment and management of protected areas are suggested to provide small safeguards for the species. More research is needed into the ecology, distribution, abundance and threats for this species. The family Tropidophiidae is included in Appendix II of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) (González et al. 2012).

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of the large extent of occurrence, large number of sub-populations and localities, and presumed large population size.
habitat: It can be found in small, clear upland streams, clear springs, caves and shaded seepages. It is occasionally found in swamps and lake margins. Sometimes it is also encountered in forested wet areas away from streams, especially during rainy periods. Individuals are often found under rocks, logs, leaves or moss in or near water. Eggs usually are attached to undersides of rocks in running water.
threats: Deforestation for commercial and residential development, and its impacts on stream conditions are the primary potential threats, but in general this species is secure throughout most of its range.
population: The total adult population size is unknown but it is considered to exceed 10,000, and the population appears to be stable.
range: This species can be found in eastern North America from southern Quebec and southern Maine to northern Georgia, Alabama and northeastern Mississippi (Conant and Collins 1991). This range is restricted to the Appalachian Mountains.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It occurs in many protected areas. No conservation measures are needed.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of the large extent of occurrence, large number of sub-populations and localities, and large population size, and use of a wide range of habitats.
habitat: This species occurs in various habitats in wooded regions, near cool clear streams and ponds in the north and in warm, turbid swamps in parts of the south. It disperses from the water's edge into fields and woods in some regions. When inactive, it hides at the bottom of water bodies or in caves in some areas. Eggs and larvae develop in standing water of woodland ponds, bog ponds, stream pools, sloughs and flooded ditches, often in sites with few or no fishes (e.g. Holomuzki 1995).
threats: Local sub-populations are no doubt impacted by clear-cutting and urbanization, although the species as a whole is not considered to be threatened.
population: There are thousands of sub-populations; it is considered to be abundant and stable. There are local declines in Ontario, Canada.
range: This species occurs in eastern North America (United States and Canada) from the Gaspé Peninsula to Wisconsin, south to southern South Carolina, northern Georgia, southern Mississippi and southeastern Texas (Conant and Collins 1991). It is absent from most of far southeastern U.S. and the prairie region of Illinois and vicinity.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
There are no conservation measures needed. It occurs in many protected areas.

rationale: Assessed as Least Concern as it is a widespread and common species with no major threats.
habitat: Inhabits arid and semi-desert vegetation zones where suitable roosts and food are available. Recorded in semi-desert grassland with areas of Acacia scrub in oases with gardens and orchards surrounded by sandy desert and hamada, in gorges of wadis with some Tamarix and oleanders (Nerium oleander). Roosts in dry caves, ruins, underground tunnels (including catacombs), mosques and old buildings, and sometimes in fissures, small crevices and among boulders. The species is sendentary and it stores fat in autumn for the winter months.
threats: Human disturbance in roost sites and pesticide use against locusts are the main threats
population: The Egyptian Mouse-tailed Bat (Rhinopoma cistops) appears to be particularly abundant near oases. However, both distribution and abundance are undoubtedly insufficiently investigated because the roosts and suitable habitats are often unreachable. Colonies range in size from a few bats up to several hundred, maximum is about 1000 individuals (Egypt). This species is assumed stable throughout its distribution range. Population information remains unknown for most of its African distribution.
range: Occurs across arid northern part of Africa and western Arabia, north to Israel and Syria, south to South Sudan. Occurs up 1,100 m Asl in the Maghreb and western Arabia.
conservationActions: No specific measures are known or are in place, but occurs in protected areas across the range. A study on the impacts of pesticides is required, especially ways in which the impact might be minimised.

rationale: Rhinolophus willardi is listed as Endangered under criterion B1ab(i,iii,v) because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 3,588 km², and all individuals are from a single unprotected region (forest patches within the Misotschi-Kabogo highlands) where there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: Rhinolophus willardi is known from unprotected forest patches in the montane forests of the Misotschi-Kabogo highlands (Kerbis Peterhans et al. 2013). The two nearby capture sites were at 1,880 m and 1,950 m asl. The species is assumed to roost in caves and mines, similar to other species in the R. maclaudi group.
threats: This species is known only from one (1) location (two nearby capture sites) in unprotected forest patches the Misotschi-Kabogo highlands (Kerbis Peterhans et al. 2013). This area is destabilized by regional conflict which is contributing to unregulated forest clearing, habitat degradation and loss. The species likely roosts in caves and mines, which are heavily disturbed within the region.
population: Currently there is no information on the species population size, but it is suspected to be decreasing due to unregulated forest clearing within its limited range. Further, cave roosting bats are heavily hunted and the roosts disturbed in the region.
range: Rhinolophus willardi has been been recorded from one (1) location (two (2) nearby capture sites) in unprotected forest patches in the Misotschi-Kabogo highlands, north of Kalemie, Kilicha River, western shore of Lake Tanganyika, South Kivu Province, eastern Democratic Republic of Congo (Kerbis Peterhans et al. 2013).
useTrade: The species is thought to be hunted in its cave roosts, a common practice in this region of Africa.
conservationActions: This species is in urgent need of conservation attention since it is only known from one location in unprotected forest patches in the Misotschi-Kabogo highlands, a region destabilized by conflict. Research is needed into the species distribution, population size and trends, habitat, ecology, and threats.

rationale: Rhinolophus kahuzi is assessed as Endangered under criterion B as it is only known from one (1) location (Kahuzi-Biega National Park) and has an area of occupancy (AOO) of ca 120 km² and an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 155 km². Given the ongoing conflict in the region, it is assumed that its overall EOO, AOO, population, and roosting/foraging habitats are declining from unregulated logging and over-harvesting for food.
habitat: The type specimen was collected at 2,600 m above sea level, and is the only known record of this species. It was recorded in mixed Afrocarpus and Nuxia forest on the slopes of Mt Kahuzi (Kerbis Peterhans et al. 2013). The species is assumed to roost in caves as is typical of similar species in the Rhinolophus maclaudi group where it is subject to disturbance and hunting. Further, there is unregulated forest harvest in the area related to the ongoing conflict in the region.
threats: This species is only known from the type locality, the Mt Kahuzi area (Kerbis Peterhans et al. 2013), where its habitat is assumed to be declining due to unregulated forest clearing that are typical patterns associated with conflict zones in the region. Further, its risk of extinction is exacerbated as the species is only known from this one (1) location where the species is assumed to be under great pressure from over-harvesting as a food source in its cave roosts; a common practice in this region.
population: Rhinolophus kahuzi is known from a single specimen collected from the western slopes of Mt Kahuzi (at 2,600 m). The species population size is unknown and is assumed to be declining as it is in a conflict zone where there is unregulated forest clearing that is removing important forest habitat and from over-harvesting of the species for food (a typical pattern in this region, especially given the ongoing conflict).
range: Rhinolophus kahuzi is known from a single specimen collected at 2,600 m in elevation from the western slope of Mt Kahuzi, Kahuzi-Biega National Park, South Kivu Province, eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (Kerbis Peterhans et al. 2013). Its area of occupancy (AOO) is ca 120 km² and its extent of occurrence (EOO) is around 155 km². Furthermore, given most species in the R. maclaudi group have highly restricted distributions, we are conservative in assuming that the distribution of R. kahuzi is limited to this one (1) location in the Mt Kahuzi region until additional data confirms otherwise.
useTrade: The species is assumed to be over-harvested for food as this is a typical pattern in this region of Africa.
conservationActions: This species is in urgent need of conservation attention. Despite the fact that it is known to occur within a protected area, the region has been destabilized by conflict. Additional research on the species distribution, habitat, ecology, population and threats is needed to inform effective conservation actions within the national park and the broader region.

rationale: <span class="datalabel1">This species is only known from the type locality until now (Wu and Thong 2011) and it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Little is known of the habitat preferences or behaviour of R. schnitzleri. The holotype was captured from a cave surrounded by cultivated areas, within a distance of 200 meters to the closest village, and about 50 kilometers to Kunming City (Wu and Thong 2011).
threats: <span class="datalabel1">Specific threats to the species is unknown as only one has been captured. Given it was captured in a cave, normal threats to cave bats, including in-roost disturbance are likely relevant.
population: There is no information on population sizes at present.
range: This species is endemic to China, and only known from the type locality at Xiao-dong Cave, Yunnan province (Wu and Thong 2011).
conservationActions: <span class="datalabel1">Specific conservation actions to the species are unknown as only one has been captured. Given it was captured in a cave, protecting cave roosts is a logical conservation measure. Further studies are needed into the taxonomy, distribution, abundance, ecology, and threats to the species.

rationale: Rhinolophus thailandensis is assessed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, it occurs in a number of protected areas, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: The species is known to roost in limestone caves and forages in (sub) tropical moist forest habitats (Francis 2019, Ellis 2020). It is known to inhabit the lowlands (80m amsl) as the highlands (1,790 m amsl) (Ellis 2020).
threats: There are unlikely to be major threats affecting the species throughout its range. Deforestation due to logging, agriculture, plantations and urbanisation is probably affecting some populations. Roost cave disturbance is likely negligeable given the remoteness of its known locations of occurrence.
population: Little is known but the population is assumed to be stable.
range: The species is endemic to Thailand.
useTrade: The species is not known to be hunted, used, or traded.
conservationActions: Rhinolophus thailandensis is currently only known from protected areas (e.g. Chiang Dao Wildlife Sanctuary, Khlong Wang Chao National Park, Pha Daeng National Park; Ellis 2020). Little is known about this species and additional research is needed to determine the species distribution, population status and trends, and ecology. Further research is therefore required to establish conservation action plans.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable because it has an area of occupancy below 20 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs at ten locations defined by ongoing (on Lord Howe, representing the majority of the range) and (on four offshore islands) plausible future impacts of invasive species that are degrading its habitat and may - based on evidence of reduced reproductive activity and possible local extinction in parts of Lord Howe Island - be causing an ongoing decline in the number of mature individuals.
habitat: This arboreal and rock-dwelling species is found on boulder slopes and rock faces, and on trees, especially White Oak or Norfolk Island Hibiscus (Lagunaria patersonia) (Cogger 2014, Wilson and Swan 2013). The study by Bray et al. (unpublished) found that the species exhibited a preference for areas sheltered from strong winds, and that they utilized forest, palm and open rocky habitats where suitable shelter and oviposition sites (root systems or crevices in trees or rocks) existed. The species was found to nest communally, with each female laying a single egg, and individual oviposition sites showed evidence that they were reused over multiple years (Bray et al., unpublished). Broken eggshells in the south of the island were found in caves (Bray et al., unpublished). The species appears to exhibit a highly extended incubation period for a gecko, of around 8-9 months (Bray et al., unpublished).
threats:
A significant decline on Lord Howe Island has been attributed to the accidental introduction of the invasive Black Rat (Rattus rattus) from a shipwreck in 1918. The Black Rat preys on the eggs of this gecko, resulting in recruitment failure. This introduction has resulted in this gecko being confined to small pockets of suitable microhabitat in which rat-proof oviposition sites were abundant (Colgan et al. 2005). The offshore islands are sufficiently close to Lord Howe that the rat may be able to colonize them naturally; while rats have not become established on the islands in the last century, they remain a potential threat and four of the islands are now regularly visited by tourists or researchers, which may increase the likelihood of accidental introduction (D. Chapple pers. comm. 2017). 

Cogger (2004) identified several threats to both lizard species found on Norfolk Island: past habitat loss and degradation, soil compaction and erosion caused by grazing and burrowing rabbits (Phillip Island) and invasive plants, the increased risk of spreading exotic/invasive species of plants and animals to offshore islands through increased tourist visitation to those islands, the increased threat of direct habitat damage to offshore islands through impacts of human traffic, including fire risk from camp fires, and direct habitat loss through land clearance. Within the last decade the invasive House Gecko Hemidactylus frenatus, which has resulted in declines and extinctions of island geckos elsewhere in the world through competitive exclusion or predation (Csurhes and Markula 2009, Cole et al. 2005), has been heard calling on Lord Howe (D. Chapple pers. comm. 2017). It is unclear whether this species is presently established on Lord Howe, but it is widespread on the Australian mainland and extensive shipping between the mainland and Lord Howe probably makes its establishment on the island inevitable (D. Chapple pers. comm. 2017).
population:
On Norfolk Island this species has apparently been extinct since before human settlement and is known only from sub-fossil remains. It is still abundant on the offshore islands and rocks that remain rat-free (Smith et al. 2012). A survey by Cogger et al. (2000) suggests that this species has a population of between 99,000 and 176,000 on Phillip Island, making it at least as abundant as, and probably much more abundant than, a 1978 survey by Cogger (1979 cited in Director of National Parks 2010), at which time this species was conservatively estimated to have a population of 100,000.

This species was apparently abundant on the main island of Lord Howe as late as the 1930s but is now uncommon, following a severe decline in its numbers and range presumably as a result of increased rat numbers (Bray et al. unpublished) and habitat changes. A  single "dense population" was found to survive in the north of the island between North Beach and New Gulch in surveys between 2010 and 2013 (Bray et al. unpublished), but no evidence was found that the species survives elsewhere in this part of Lord Howe. While the species was found to be widespread in the centre of the island in this study, it generally occurred at low densities, with the densest recorded subpopulation estimated to consist of around 300 individuals in an area of 3,000 m2 using mark-recapture techniques (Bray et al. unpublished). Only a single juvenile was found in multiple surveys of the south (Bray et al. unpublished). No time series is available for determining recent population trends on the main island, as prior to the 2010-2013 survey the most recent systematic survey was in 1966, and failed to locate any geckos (Cogger 1971). Bray et al. (unpublished) found evidence in the form of broken eggshells that the species persisted recently in areas of the southern mountains where neither extant subpopulations nor evidence of recent breeding were detected, which may indicate that declines and potentially local extinctions are ongoing.

It is still abundant on the small, rocky, offshore islands on which there are large colonies of seabirds (Cogger 2014). On Blackburn Island, surveys recorded nine geckos in 30 minutes, and slightly lower (20 geckos in one and a half hours) numbers on Mutton Bird Island (Bray et al., unpublished).
range: This species occurs only on two oceanic island complexes in the western Pacific, off the eastern coast of Australia: Lord Howe Island and Norfolk Island (Colgan et al. 2005). It occurs on Lord Howe Island and its small satellite islands (Mutton Bird, Ball's Pyramid, Blackburn and Roach Island - Bray et al., unpublished data). It was formerly widespread on Lord Howe Island, but while recent records exist from sites across the island the species appears to remain widespread only in the central region, with a patchy distribution in the north and almost none from the southern mountains (Bray et al., unpublished). While this species has not occurred on the main island of Norfolk Island since prior to European colonization (Colgan et al. 2005) it remains extant on two of the satellite islands, Nepean and Phillip Islands, and on three small rocky islets - Moo'oo Stone, Bird Rock and Green Pool Stone, each about 100 m from the northern cliffs of Norfolk Island (Director of National Parks 2010).
useTrade: There is no significant use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions:
Lord Howe Island is a World Heritage Area. This species is gazetted nationally as 'Vulnerable' under the Commonwealth of Australia's Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act) (Colgan et al. 2005) and in New South Wales under the Threatened Species Conservation Act 1995 (New South Wales).

The 'Lord Howe Island Biodiversity Management Plan' (Department of Environment and Climate Change 2007) outlines the following recovery actions for threatened species on the island complex; those relevant to this gecko include: implementing the Lord Howe Island Board quarantine policy, protecting native vegetation, on-ground eradication and control of weeds, revegetation of priority sites, control and/or eradication of introduced vertebrate and invertebrate fauna, research and monitoring into species' ecology and management options, captive breeding and reintroductions, surveys of potential habitat, and community awareness. At present, although a quarantine plan has been prepared for Lord Howe, biosecurity screening and containment procedures are not always fully implemented and have not proven to be effective at preventing regular establishment of exotic species on Lord Howe (D. Chapple pers. comm. 2017).

rationale: Listed Vulnerable because the extent of occurrence is 5,722 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in fewer than ten threat-defined locations, and there are ongoing declines in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: It lives on low vegetation near streams and brooks, and among boulders and in caves in pristine rainforest; it cannot survive in altered habitats. Calling males have been heard from large cavities between boulders during the day and specimens have been found active near these cavities at night (Glaw and Vences, 2007). The breeding biology is unknown - it could reproduce by either direct or larval development.
threats:
The major threat is habitat loss due to subsistence agriculture, timber extraction, charcoal manufacture, livestock grazing, and expanding human settlements.

Species in this genus have tested positive for Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd), however currently there have been no negative effects observed within amphibian populations in Madagascar suggesting the Bd strain has a low virulence level (Bletz et al., 2015).
population: It is a rare species and, due to ongoing declines in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species was previously known only from the island of Nosy Mangabe and the nearby mainland along the coast of the Antongila Bay, from 0-400m asl. It has now also been found to occur at Ambodiriana (around 150 km south of Maroantsetra) (Gehring et al., 2010). It is likely to occur at several sites between Ambodiriana and Maroansetra and may also occur on the Masoala Peninsula. The extent of occurrence is 5,722 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It occurs in the Réserve Spéciale de Nosy Mangabe. Although not yet confirmed from Parc National de Masoala it is likely to occur there as well.

Conservation Needed
Improved protection and management of forests throughout the region is required, including within the boundaries of protected areas.


Research Needed
Further research is required to clarify the species' natural history, distribution, population size and trends, and is essential to fully understand the distribution, origin, type and virulence of Bd lineages found in Madagascar (Bletz et al., 2015).

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining at nearly the rate required to qualify for listing in a threatened category.
habitat: In China and Vietnam, this species is commonly found in montane forests. It usually roosts in colonies and lives in natural or artificial caves.
threats: Urban constructions are the main threats for the population declines of  this species, as they caused destruction of forests and caves which the  species depends for predation and roosting.
population: The species global population is currently suspected to be in decline, due to habitat fragmentation and loss of key roost sites, but not at a rate to qualify as a threatened species.
range: This species is widely distributed in Southern China and Vietnam. Recently, it has been recorded from six provinces in China, including Hunan, Jiangxi, Guangdong, Guangxi, Yunnan and Guizhou (Sun et al. 2016, Gong et al. 2017) and three provinces in Vietnam, including Vinh Phuc, Tuyen Quang and Thanh Hoa (Tu et al. 2017).
conservationActions: There are no known conservation measures in place for this species. It is not known if the species is present in any protected areas.

rationale: Data available on population, demographic trends, ecology and threats of this newly described species are not sufficient to assess its risk of extinction, thus it is listed as Data Deficient (DD).
habitat: Rhinolophus indorouxii prefers high altitude moist and forested habitats similar to R. rouxii. Roost types include caves and crevices and may include man-made structures as well. No systematic study has been conducted to understand the ecology of this species.
threats: <span lang="EN-US">The main threats are anthropogenic disturbances and possibly forest fragmentation like many other cave roosting bat species. However, no studies have specifically identified particular threats and quantified their effects.
population: No study has systematically assessed the population status of this species. Observational data collected during surveys reveal a decline in population size in a cave roost in the Sheveroy Hills (B. Chattopadhyay 2016, pers. comm).
range: This species is reported from very few localities in the Eastern Ghat mountain ranges of Tamil Nadu and Southern Western Ghat mountain ranges south of the Palghat gap (Chattopadhyay et al. 2012, Wordley et al. 2015). Roosting colonies have been observed as high as 1,500 m asl at Yercaud in the Shevaroy hills. R. indoroxii is observed mostly in higher elevational forested areas with high rainfall. However, there is severe paucity of data and survey records about this species' occurrence. The present information on range is available from only few locations (Shevoroy hills, Sirumalai and Megamalai) and two studies. Recently, Wordley et al. reported the possibility of the presence of R. indorouxii in Valparai.
conservationActions: No conservation actions are known for this species

rationale: Listed as Least Concern because of its wide distribution range across Indochinese subregion and being observed in relatively large colony in many caves.
habitat: It is found in caves, limestone areas and in several forest types, from lowland to hill evergreen forest (Soisook et al. 2008). Female individuals were found pregnant in late February and lactating in May (Soisook et al. 2008).
threats: The major known threat to this species, as well as other cave bats, is habitat destruction, i.e. limestone quarrying, and forest conversion.
population: In Thailand, a few individuals of this species are often captured in the same harp trap when trapping is undertaken near karst habitat.  A relatively small size of colony, with about 10 to 50 individuals, was observed in day-roost cave (P. Soisook, unpublished data). However, a colony of about 1,200 individuals was recorded roosting torpid in a cave in western Thailand (Robinson et al. 1995).
range: This species is known from Myanmar, Vietnam, Cambodia and Thailand (north of the isthmus of Kra) (Soisook et al. 2008). It is also recorded from Lao PDR (Thomas et al. 2013). It is very likely to be occurred in China but current record is referred to Rhinolophus stheno (Zhang et al. 2009).
conservationActions: There is no conservation action or scheme in-place specifically for this species, although in Thailand it is being considered to be listed in the National Wildlife Protection Act (P. Soisook, pers. comm.).

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large  population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to  qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: In northern Myanmar, it has been found altitudes ranging from 615 to  1,230 m asl (Bates and Harrison 1997). In Southeast Asia, it appears to  have been recorded from somewhat disturbed areas.
threats: The threats to this species are not well known, although it is unlikely  to be threatened throughout its range. Although it is definitely  threatened by deforestation (generally resulting from logging operations  and the conversion of land to agricultural and other uses), it has been  recorded from some modified habitats and seems to be somewhat adaptable  in parts of its range.
population: It has only been caught in small numbers in all parts of the range (Francis pers. comm., Csorba pers. comm.).
range: Widespread in the Indo-Burma subregion, with only scattered records from China. The boundary between the closely related forms M. feae and M. jaintiana is not known.
conservationActions: It is present in a number of protected areas throughout its range.

rationale: Barbastella beijingensis is listed Data Deficient. It has a very limited known range, which is located in a populated area. Based on this, a threatened status might be justified, however, recordings of barbastelle bats in China are generally rare, scattered and insufficiently studied. Also, very few barbastelles from the Chinese territory have been properly identified using DNA sequences. Thus, it remains possible that B. beijingensis is much more widespread than is currently known.
habitat: The species is known from the area covered with mountainous warm temperate zone mixed forest with Chinese pine, arborvitae, and oaks. Abandoned tunnel and natural caves are reported as day roosts.
threats: This species can be threatened by uncontrolled visits and development of underground cavities that serve as roosts for it, as well as the destruction of habitats and the use of pesticides in the surrounding agricultural lands.
population: Only six specimens are known to date.
range: This species is known only from two locations; Southwestern Beijing,  China (408 m asl) where it was first described, and near Lingbao, Henan  Province, China (707 m asl).
useTrade: This species has no commercial value and not known to be involved into commercial trade. It can play certain role as a natural controller of forestry pests, but due to low population density its influence on agriculture in this respect is negligible.
conservationActions: No special conservation actions are known to date. Search of the day roosts and putting them under conservation and monitoring is highly recommended.

rationale: Barbastella darjelingensis is assessed as Least Concern as it has a wide range, part of which is located in sparsely populated regions, so it is difficult to assume threats to its existence in the near future. However, careful research is needed over most of the range, as the species may include cryptic taxa, which may have a higher threat status.
habitat: Strictly nocturnal species. Little is known about its habits, but, by analogy with other barbastelles, it is probably solitary or forming small colonies and feeding on middle-size flying insects. Known mainly from mountain areas up to elevation of ca. 2,350 m ASL. Inhabiting mountainous temperate and subtropical forests. In Vietnam it was found foraging over stream in a deciduous forest at the elevation of ca. 2000 m ASL (Kruskop and Shchinov 2010), in India animals were captured in an oak forest and over a forest clearing (Chakravarty et al. 2020). Day roosts probably in natural and artificial caves and caverns, rock crevices or in hollows under tree bark.
threats: This species can be threatened by uncontrolled visits and development of underground cavities that serve as roosts for it, as well as the destruction of habitats and the use of pesticides in the surrounding agricultural lands.
population: Considering its wide range there seems to be little information  available about the population of this species. According to published  records, this species is highly sporadic, with low density of  population, however it could be an artifact caused by distribution in  hard-to-reach areas. The species population is presumed stable.
range: As accepted here, the species has a vast distribution range from eastern  Afghanistan (Benda and Gaisler 2015) through northern India, Nepal,  Bhutan, south China, to Laos, northern Vietnam and Taiwan (Bates and  Harrison 1997, Smith and Xie 2008, Kruskop 2013). Known distribution  connected with the mountainous areas of moderate elevations.
useTrade: This species has no commercial value and not known to be involved into commercial trade. It most probably plays certain role as a natural controller of forestry pests, but due to low population density its influence on agriculture in this respect is negligible.
conservationActions: No special conservation actions are known to date. Special research for revealing of possible cryptic taxonomic diversity and clarifying of the species natural habits are recommended.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern, because it is widespread, relatively adaptable and there are no major threats.
habitat: This taxon inhabits varied habitats from semi-desert and steppe habitats to tropical forests. Usually roost in shaded areas, such as the cracks of rocks or buildings. Sometimes found in frontal parts of caves. Generally solitary or found in small groups. It is thought that its diet may include butterflies and moths. Nothing much is known about its ecology.
threats: There are no major threats to the species throughout its range.
population: There is no information on population sizes at present.
range: The species is widespread and is currently found in from China, Taiwan, Laos PDR, Myanmar, Thailand, Vietnam, India, Pakistan and Iran.
useTrade: This species it not included in trade and has no commercial value.
conservationActions: This bat requires no special conservations actions besides conservation activities common for all bats of the temperate zone. Its range does include a few protected areas in its range.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as it is known only from about 20 specimens and the information on its distribution, abundance, ecology or threats is very limited.
habitat:
The Lao specimens were captured in mist nets near Xe Kaman, a moderately large, fast-flowing river 50–100 m across, flowing through lowland evergreen rainforest in the Dong Amphan National Biodiversity Area. All of the Vietnamese specimens came from Cat Tien National Park. One specimen was collected near the headquarters of the Park, close to the Dong Nai River. This area is generally described as lowland rain forest with dipterocarp trees (Görföl et al. 2014).
Hypsugo dolichodon is closely associated with cave ecosystems. A single specimen was collected from Saddan-Sin Cave in Mon State, Myanmar (identified as Falsistrellus affinis by Bates et al., 2005). The cave is situated in a large isolated limestone outcrop and is surrounded by paddy fields and toddy palms. Two additional specimens were collected at Indian Single Rock Temple Cave. Several forested limestone outcrops surrounded by rice fields are present in the surrounding area. Remnants of evergreen, deciduous and mangrove forests are also present (Görföl et al. 2018).
Aside from a single male caught in evergreen forest, the five other specimens from Phnom Kulen National Park, Siem Reap Province, Cambodia were caught at a southwest-facing cave entrance in an area of semi-evergreen forest with scattered rocky outcrops and boulders. All three specimens from Kampot were caught at the entrance of Bat Khteas Cave, Chhngauk Hill, Kampot Province. The isolated karst hill where the cave is located is surrounded by seasonal wet rice cultivation, with many local farmers also cultivating small amounts of durian, banana, mango, coconuts, guava and cashew (Chheang et al. 2013, Phauk et al. 2013).
threats: The species is at least partly a cave-dweller, hence the disturbance of its roosting sites may be a threat. Also, one of the localities is a riverine habitat and it may be destroyed by dam construction works.
population: The species is known from only about 20 specimens from four countries and seven localities.
range: The known distribution of this species is limited to Laos and southern Vietnam (Görföl et al. 2014), Cambodia and Myanmar (Görföl et al. 2018). It has been found at Bat Khteas Cave, Chhngauk Hill, Kampot Province and in Phnom Kulen National Park, Siem Reap Province, both in Cambodia (Chheang et al. 2013, Phauk et al. 2013). It is suspected that the species is more widely distributed in the Indo-Burma subregion (Görföl et al. 2018).
conservationActions: The species occurs in three protected areas, but this not always ensures its protection. One of its localities may be destroyed by constructional works of a river dam.

rationale: Assessed as Data deficient. The species was first described in Yunnan province in China by Tiunov et al. (2011). After 2011, there are no reports about this species. There is inadequate information to make a direct, or indirect, assessment of its risk of extinction based on its distribution and/or population status.
habitat: The species normally was captured in limestone caves at about 2,000 m a.s.l.The species has been normally found roosting in the same caves as Rhinolophus sinicus, R. pusillus, Hipposideros armiger and M. laniger.
threats: There is no information on threats at present.
population: There is no information on population sizes at present.
range: This species is endemic to China, where it has been recorded from Jinning, Yunnan province, China (Tiunov et al. 2011).
conservationActions: The species has not been recorded from any protected areas.

rationale: This species is relatively widespread and evenly distributed across its range. There are no major threats to the species and hence it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: In Japan, it roosts in tree cavities, underground sites, and under  bridges (Kawai 2015). In China, it roosts in caves, mine tunnels,  cellars, wells, tree holes, attics, steeples, and under bridges and  rubble on the floor of caves (Smith and Sie 2008). In South Korea, it  roosts in caves during both winter and summer (Yoon 2010). This species  flies over the water surface and feed on small insects.
threats: Human disturbance of natural caves and other underground sites may be a potential threat, although it is unlikely to be a major threat at present.
population: There are currently no data regarding the population status of this species. The global population is assumed to be stable.
range: This species is known from the southern and eastern Siberia, Transbaikalia, north-eastern China, northern Mongolia, Far East Russia, Korean peninsula, Sakhalin, Kuril Islands, and northern Japan (Clark et al. 2006, Kawai 2015, Smith and Xie 2008, Yoon, 2010). In Japan, occurs only in Hokkaido (Kawai 2015). In China, it is known from the provinces of Heilongjiang, Jilin and Nei Mongol (Smith and Xie 2008).
conservationActions: In China, it is listed as Data Deficient (DD) (Jiang et al. 2016).

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution. However there is continuing decline in habitat quality in its range and presumed threat to this species due to tourism-related development; more accurate information in future may lead to more precise assessment.
habitat: Occurs in caves and caverns surrounded by coniferous forests, and occasionally in human habitation (T.A. Shah, pers. comm.).
