population: The largest colony of the species, in Cat Ba island, was included in Thong et al. (2012). It had an estimated population size of up to 500 individuals, this had dramatically declined to ca 130-150 individuals (Kruskop 2013) and even less than 80 individuals in 2017 (Thong et al., unpublished data). The current population of the species is estimated at fewer than 9,000 individuals and number of individuals at every known caves has declined remarkably since 2008 (Thong et al., unpublished data).
range: The species comprises two distinct subspecies (Hipposideros alongensis alongensis in karst islands in Ha Long Bay, including Cat Ba archipelago, and H. a. sungi within fragmented karst forests in mainland of northeastern Viet Nam). Topal (1993) included a record of the species from “Yu Do”, Yen Bai province, north-west Viet Nam, without geographical coordinates, which was subsequently cited in Can et al. (2008). However, this record is uncertain since there is no locality named “Yu Do” in Viet Nam (Thong et al. 2012).
useTrade: Illegal hunting of the species by local people in some   mainland areas.
conservationActions: The species is not listed in any lawful or legal document of Viet Nam.  Conservation actions including public awareness is essential in the Cat  Ba archipelago (Thong 2007, Thong and Furey 2008). Previously colonies  and roosting sites in caves in Cat Ba island were well conserved and  almost undisturbed. However, rapid development of cave tourism in the  Cat Ba archipelago, Ha Long Bay and other areas have threatened the  species since 2010. Strategies for the conservation of the species which  highlighted its endemic values were undertaken at national workshops  and meetings but received little attention from local authorities.

rationale: Hipposideros nicobarulae is assessed as Endangered under criterion B2ab(iii) as it is known only from the Nicobar group of islands of Andaman and Nicobar Islands, India and its area of occupancy (AOO) is estimated to be between 44–52 km² across at least 11 islands (Douangboubpha et al. 2011, Aul et al. 2014). Its area of occupancy, extent and quality of habitat, and the number of locations/subpopulations are declining. The overall population and number of mature individuals is inferred to be declining due to habitat degradation and loss. Its range is severely fragmented and the species is distributed in 3-5 locations, which are assumed to represent subpopulations, based on the spatial distribution of the islands. It is vulnerable to climate change related effects (sea level rise, strong cyclones); it is suspected to have been significantly impacted to the mass destruction of its habitat from a tsunami in 2004.
habitat: This species is known to roost in caves (Aul et al. 2014) and as a mixed sex colony in a sea cave (Douangboubpha et al. 2011). It has also been recorded from an abandoned military establishment (Hill 1967) and is assumed to forage in tropical lowland forest habitat. Deforestation is negatively impacting the species forest foraging areas and its cave roosts are inferred to be declining from disturbance. The 2004 tsunami razed over 95% of the Nicobar Islands' mangrove forests (Reddy et al. 2016).
threats: Hipposideros nicobarulae had its lowland foraging habitats severely damaged by the 2004 tsunami and its coastal cave roosts in the Nicobar Islands were partially or completely submerged, either killing bats or forcing them to vacate the caves (Aul et al. 2014). The species is impacted by periodic (May-June) in-cave disturbance due to poachers coming from Myanmar and Thailand to harvest edible swiftlet nests (Aul et al. 2014). Deforestation degrades and eliminates important foraging habitats (Reddy et al. 2016). Climate change brings threats from sea level rise and increased frequency of stronger cyclones where a single storm could severely damage both cave roosts and foraging habitats.
population: The population and number of mature individuals are suspected to be declining due to disturbance at cave-roosts, and loss and degradation of habitat. Its range is severely fragmented and the species is distributed in 3-5 locations, which are assumed to be subpopulations, based on the spatial distribution of the islands. Research and monitoring is needed to confirm the status, distribution, and trend of the species.
range: Hipposideros nicobarulae is endemic the Nicobar Islands, India. It is found on at least 11 islands including: Camorta Island, Trinket Island, Katchal Island, Little Nicobar Island, Great Nicobar Island, Tillanchang Island, Chowra Island, Bompoka Island, Teressa Island, and Nancowry Island (Douangboubpha et al. 2011) with a total land area of ca 1,840 km². Its is located in 3–5 locations (subpopulations) based on the spatial distribution of the islands, and its area of occupancy (AOO) is estimated to be between 44–52 km² and is declining.
useTrade: The species is not traded or hunted.
conservationActions: The species likely occurs in two (2) protected areas on Great Nicobar and Tillangchong islands. Protection of known roosts from all forms of disturbance and its foraging areas are top priorities. Establishment of proactive conservation programme involving local stakeholders and identiﬁcation of a ﬂagship species (Aul 2006). Additional research is needed to ascertain the current status of this species, threats, and its habitats.

rationale: Dyacopterus rickarti is listed as Endangered under criterion B2ab(iii) as the species is restricted to a few mountain ranges on Mindanao Island and Northern Luzon, Philippines. Its population is highly fragmented and it is only known from seven captures in six locations (four in Mindanao and two in Luzon). Its area of occupancy is 36 km². There is also continuing loss in area, extent and quality of habitat in the mountains where it has been captured.
habitat: Before 2007, this species was initially categorized as Dyacopterus spadiceus, which is also found in neighboring Southeast Asian countries. Data from Helgen et al. (2007) showed differences from this species to that of other Dyacopterus species. Limited records for this species are from montane forest habitats generally above 1,000 m asl to 1,680 m asl, suggesting it is restricted relatively high elevations on montane to mossy forest. However, the Mt. Pangal capture in Northern Sierra Madre is the lowest elevation record for this species at 550 m asl and is characterized as a lower montane forest. Records from New Bataan and Mt. Mahuson and Mt. Apo National Park were from degraded habitats, which may indicate that this species can tolerate some level of disturbance. In Mt. Apo National Park, for example, this species was captured in a net placed in a cultivated area. More research needs to be done on distribution extent and ecological requirements of this species to determine specific conservation needs of this endemic fruit bat. If it is similar to Dyacopterus spadiceus, this species may require cave habitats.
threats: The primary threats to the species is from past and ongoing forest habitat degradation and loss through the intrusion of agriculture, recreation/ecotourism, and rural communities into its known range. If the species is documented to use caves, like the similar Dyacopterus spadiceus, then we expect cave disturbance to be a significant threat as it is prevalent throughout the Philippines. While there are currently no records of hunting of this species, given its size, it is likely taken when other species are hunted in an area. More data are needed to ascertain the degree of threat from hunting.
population: Very little information is available about the population status for this species due to the limited data available. It is rarely captured, mostly at high elevations, and may be mistaken for similar species. More data are needed to determine population size and trends, and threats to this species.
range: Dyacopterus rickarti is a Philippine endemic species that has only been documented from seven (7) sites in six (6) locations, including Abra Province (550 m asl), Mt. Malibato, Opol, Misamis Oriental (altitude unrecorded), Mt. Kitanglad National Park, Sumilao, Bukidnon (1,450 m asl), Mt. Apo National Park, Davao City (1,185 m asl), Mt. Puting Bato, New Bataan, Compostela Valley (1,680 m asl), and Mt. Mahuson, Arakan Valley Conservation Area, Arakan, North Cotabato (1,260 m asl). Its area of occupancy (AOO) is 36 km². Additional information is needed to refine the understanding of the species distribution across the Philippines.
conservationActions: The current distribution of this species is at relatively high elevations, 550 m asl and above, which are mostly forest areas protected under Philippine law. But with continued intrusion of agriculture, recreation/ecotourism, and communities, habitats of this species must be protected. More research is needed to determine distribution, population, abundance, ecological requirements, threats, conservation and management of this species.

rationale: This bat is listed as Near Threatened (nearly meets criterion A2b) based on an estimated past population size reduction of 25-30% over the past 17.4 years (three generations; generation length = 5.8 years, Pacifici et al. 2013) across its range. In Taiwan, the species has undergone continuous declines of >90% in several of the largest known colonies and estimated losses of >70% of known individuals in the last 30 years and similar patterns are suspected throughout its range.
habitat: Habitat use, roost ecology and natural history for the species at global scale are poorly known. In Taiwan, the species has been known to roost in foliage of 35 plant species, mainly broad-leaved trees (e.g. Terminalia catapapa, Dimocarpus longan, Hibiscus tiliaceus and Swietenia mahagoni) and in buildings during breeding seasons (Chang 2007). Records are from small secondary forest fragments and settlements in rice paddy-dominated landscape in the lowland during breeding season. It has been recorded using nature caves and abandoned tunnels in mountain area with elevations over 1800 m as hibernacula in India (Chakravarty et al. pers. comm.) and in Taiwan (Heng-Chia Chang, pers. obs). In Pakistan, few individuals were captured in a mountainous landscape dominated by agriculture lands, forest patches and grassland in warm temperate zone (Mahmood-ul-Hassan and Salim 2015). In Taiwan, a well-studied maternity colony began to form in late March, and number peaked in May when pregnant females gave birth with one offspring during May to June. The bats left the maternity roost sites between mid-August and early October for hibernation sites (Shen and Lee 2000). The species is reported mainly feeding on small flying insects, including coleopterans, lepidopterans, dipterans, hemipterans (Yang 1996) and foraging in rice paddy (Ying-Yi Ho, unpubl. data) and riparian grassland (Joe Chun-Chia Huang, pers. obs.) in the lowland.
threats: Not much is known about the global threats of the species due to its general rarity. In Taiwan, the causes responsible for the wide and dramatic decline of this species are also unclear. However, several potential threats have been proposed. The continuous loss of arable land and uses of pesticide may have threatened the species by loss of food source. Several types of pesticide residue were detected from the faeces of this species (Heng-Chia Chang and Chia-Jung Tsai 2013). Since the species is at least partly cave-dwelling during winter hibernation, hence the disturbance of hibernacula and climate changes can be threats. Two roadkill incidences of the species reported from Taiwan (https://roadkill.tw/) indicate it is potentially risked by the expansion of road systems and increasing vehicle volume within its distribution range. A dead bat found near wind farm in coastal area in western Taiwan suggests the development of wind energy farms may threaten this species. Domestic cats might be another threat as a cat-killed incidence is found in Taiwan (Heng-Chia Chang, pers. obs). Observations in the field show the presence of artificial light could suppress its emerging from the roost (Yang 1996). It also tends to avoid artificial light during foraging in the night (Joe Chun-Chia Huang and Ying-Yi Ho, pers. obs.) suggesting light pollution may cause degradation of habitats quality, disturbances to the roost and interference to the migration movement. As it roosts among foliage, logging also threaten its populations. This species has conspicuous colouration, hence it may be used as ornament.
population: It is a generally rare although widely distributed species from northern South Asia to southeastern China and Taiwan (Csorba et al. 2014). It usually roosts as a few to tens animals, although under specific circumstances it can be relatively numerous, with up to over a thousand individuals in a single house roost (Heng-Chia Chang, pers. com.). In Taiwan, continuous and dramatic declines have been observed at all its largest known colonies. The three colonies containing >100 individuals all experienced a colony size decrease, from ~120-250 to 20 or less. (Heng-Chia Chang and Ying-Yi Ho, unpub. data). Similar trends of decline were also widely found in ~70% of other smaller colonies (Heng-Chia Chang unpub. data).
range: The species has a rather wide distribution from Afghanistan to Taiwan. Bates and Harrison (1997) and Mandal et al. (2000) report the species from Afghanistan, India (Jammu and Kashmir, Himachal Pradesh, Punjab, Maharashtra, Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, West Bengal, Sikkim, Assam, Meghalaya and Karnataka). It occurs also in Nepal (Mahalaxmi and Dhaulagiri), Pakistan, China (Tibet and Jianxi) and Taiwan. The species has one record from northern Vietnam (Csorba et al. 2014, Mahmood-ul-Hassan and Salim 2015). Earlier records of the species from the Laos, Philippines, Indonesia, North and South Korea, Tsushima Island (Japan) as well as China’s provinces of Fujian, Jilin, Shanghai and Sichuan are referable to other species (Csorba et al. 2014).
useTrade: This species has a colourful pelage and may be used as an ornament.
conservationActions: The species is listed as vulnerable in Taiwan (Cheng et al. 2017). There is no direct conservation assessment in the other countries within its distribution. In Taiwan, all known hibernacula are found in protected forest areas. The protection of roosts and foraging habitats is important for this species. Since the population in Taiwan is migratory, the connectivity between its breeding habitats and winter hibernacula sites therefore is critical for this species as well. Studies on migratory movement and influences of pesticides to its survival are necessary. Further monitoring to understand the intensity of the incidences by wind turbines, vehicle collision and cat kill is also recommended.

rationale: This species is listed Vulnerable due to a small range and ongoing decline. The extent of occurrence (EOO) is 18,551 km2 and it is known from only three locations, two in Ecuador and one in Colombia (Hood and Carter 2008). This species is rare everywhere. The habitat has been reduced and the species' range is thought to be fragmented, with continuing decline in habitat extent and quality, and therefore, the number of mature individuals.
habitat: This species' natural history is poorly known. From information at the genus level, it is found in rainforests and feeds aerially on tiny insects. It roosts in small to large colonies in well-lighted caves, rock crevices, culverts or tree hollows. It is found in rainforest (Emmons and Feer 1997). It is narrowly endemic to small area of Choco in Pacific rainforest (Davalos pers. comm.). In Ecuador this species has been found between 150 and 510 m asl (Albuja 1999). The only record from Colombia is at 1,200 m asl (Alberico et al. 2000).
threats: The habitat may be under threat due to deforestation (Davalos pers. comm.). Legal and illegal crops are grown in and outside protected areas, reducing habitat (Álvarez 2002, 2003). In Ecuador, the habitat is fragmented and faces a high risk of destruction in the near future because of the lack of control to illegal logging. The situation in Colombia is better than in Ecuador (Burneo pers. comm.).
population: In Ecuador it is rare and known only from three localities (Albuja-V 1999, McCarthy et al. 2000), although two of these are less than 3 km apart and are considered a single location. It is known from only one locality in western Colombia (Alberico et al. 2000). There are three threat-based locations.
range: This species occurs in west Ecuador and Colombia (Simmons 2005). This species has been recorded from four localities, however, it is presumed to occur within appropriate habitat between these localities. Two of the localities in Ecuador are very close and so they are considered to represent one location. There is only one locality for the species in Colombia: Río Chanco, Valle del Cauca (Alberico et al. 2000, Hood and Gardner 2008).
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: It is not known whether this species occurs in protected areas within its range (Davalo pers. comm.).

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining at nearly the rate required to qualify for listing in a threatened category.
habitat: The habitat consists of extensive open areas with potential roost sites having vertical faces to drop off from and take flight, such as crevices in rock outcroppings and cliff faces, tunnels and tall buildings. This species inhabits various types of open, semi-arid to arid habitats (Cockrum 1960, Allen 1987, Best et al. 1996, Ahlborn 2000). It is an insectivore (Barquez et al. 1993).
threats: It uses only select drinking sites and is severely limited by the availability of drinking water. Due to its wing structure, it is unable to drink from water sources less than 30 m long. As a consequence, Western Mastiff Bats are no longer found in many previously occupied areas and subpopulations may be in decline (Acker 2001).
population: This species is non-migratory (Best et al. 1996), although in Mexico apparently is a migratory species (Aragon 2005). It is a common species (Barquez pers. comm.).
range: This species occurs from California to Texas (USA), south to Zacatecas and Hidalgo (Mexico), in western Peru, Bolivia, northern Argentina, Paraguay, Brazil and Cuba (Simmons 2005). The distribution includes Misiones in Argentina and all of Paraguay and exclude southern tip of distribution in Argentina (Barquez et al. 2006). The Cuban material may be misidentified (Mancina pers. comm.). It also includes south Colombia.
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: The recommended conservation action is to avoid loss of drinking sites and habitat. It is found in protected areas.

rationale: This gecko is listed as Vulnerable on the basis that this species has an extent of occurrence barely exceeding 10 km<sup>2</sup>, an area of occupancy estimated to be 4 km<sup>2</sup>, all individuals are in a single location characterized by the impacts of quarrying, and while the species is not presently undergoing declines in its habitat or population it will be subject to a well-defined threat from a planned cement quarrying operation, the timeline of which is known with sufficient certainty that it is clear the species will lose 40% of its habitat - and presumably its population - immediately after quarrying activities begin, and will be driven to extinction soon thereafter in the absence of any protection of its karst habitat. While the species has only recently been described, given patterns of microendemism in karstic systems and its adaptations for a lifestyle in strict association with cave walls, it is thought to most likely be endemic either to the known locality or the immediate surrounding karst outcrop, all of which will be impacted by the quarrying activities. The situation needs to be monitored closely and if the locality where the species occurs is not given any protection and quarrying begins, it would immediately qualify for listing as Critically Endangered.
habitat: Cyrtodactylus hidupselamanya is a micro-endemic gecko dependent on the karst ecosystem in which it lives. Intact cave walls are essential for this species survival and it does not occur outside its karst microhabitat. Morphological measurements confirm that it is anatomically adapted to living on cave walls, with a flatter head and body, longer snout, limbs and tail (hence lowering the centre of gravity keeping the body closer to the cave wall) and larger eyes than is typical for forest-adapted taxa of the C. pulcellus complex, which are more robust. These adaptations suggest that this species has been surviving in close association with this formation, and in reproductive isolation from its close relatives, for a long time. Additionally genetic evidence shows that this species is very distinct genetically, with no evidence of gene flow between this population and any other member of the C. pulchellus complex. This species is an active forager that comes out of the karst cracks and holes at night to forage for food and mate. They cannot be found during the day.
threats: The major threat is the imminent limestone quarrying of the site by ASN Cement Sdn Bhd which has already prepared a DEIA report detailing the timeline for the quarrying operation. According to their report the collection site for this new species will be completely eliminated five years after quarrying begins, approximately ten years after the infrastructure is put in place, representing around 40% of this lizard's known habitat. The operational plans indicate that the entire limestone hill range will be gone 100 years after quarrying starts. Given the fact that this is a relatively unexplored karst system and that all other well-explored karst systems have numerous other microendemic taxa, it is likely there are other new species here that are yet to be described.
population: Seventeen individuals were observed in 14 person hours of collecting. The species is not uncommon in its microhabitat, but as far as is known, it is restricted to a single karst outcrop.
range: This species is known from a single karst outcrop situated in a limestone formation near FELDA Chiku 7 (5°03.327'N, 102°08.574'E) in Peninsular Malaysia.  In a survey on 19 March 2015, in a microhabitat with suitable cave wall faces with cracks and holes into which lizards could escape. Only one juvenile was found on vegetation near the limestone, suggesting that this species is strictly associated with this karstic habitat and so highly likely to be endemic to this locality, as similar karst systems are known to host multiple similarly-restricted micro-endemic species. This locality lies at 150 m asl.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no conservation actions in place.  The most effective feasible action is the protection of the QL3 and SITE A sections of the proposed site, which are where the geckos are found and which is the first area to be quarried. Given the fact that this is a relatively unexplored karst system and that all other well-explored karst systems have numerous other microendemic taxa, it is likely there are other new species here that have yet to be discovered and described, hence a comprehensive biodiversity survey is recommended. The area should also be monitored to assess the impact of the cement quarrying operation on this and other species.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that, although this species is known only from a small limestone outcrop, this site lies within a UNESCO archaeological site and no threats exist or are thought likely to impact the lizard or its habitat in future. Further research may however reveal that the species' population is sufficiently small to approach or meet the threshold for a threatened listing.
habitat: This saxicolous species lives on limestone karst outcrops and in the vicinity of the mouths of limestone caves. During the day, geckos are occasionally observed hiding in cracks and crevices of the outcrops. At night, lizards emerge and can be found perching or moving on the walls of the karst formation 1–3 m above the ground. No lizards have been found on the surrounding vegetation (Grismer et al. 2016).
threats: This species is not facing any immediate threats (E. Quah pers. comm. 2017).
population: This is a karst restricted species that is only found in a small limestone outcrop, and as such the population is likely to be small (potentially below 1,000 mature individuals - E. Quah pers. comm. 2017). The population is presumed to be stable (E. Quah pers. comm. 2017).
range: This species is only known from the type locality at Lenggong Valley, Ulu Perak, Perak, Peninsular Malaysia, at elevation of 104 m asl. (Grismer et al. 2016).
useTrade: This species is not known to be exploited for any commercial purposes (E. Quah pers. comm. 2017).
conservationActions: Its habitat is protected by the UNESCO Archaeological Heritage status of the Lenggong Valley (Gismer et al. 2016).

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that, although this species is known from four localities and the most recently identified subpopulation may be threatened by ongoing habitat loss in the Genting Highlands,  no major threats have been identified elsewhere and one subpopulation occurs in a well-protected area.
habitat: This diurnal species occurs both in limestone and granite boulders, crevasses and caves in lowland, old secondary forest. It is only occasionally seen on tree trunks or fallen logs but never on leafy vegetation (Flower 1899, Grismer and Chan 2008, Chan and Grismer 2008, Grismer 2011, Grismer et al. 2014). It is considered to be a habitat generalist (Grismer et al. 2014).
threats: This species appears to not be threatened as there is no ongoing habitat modification at most known localities (L. Grismer and E. Quah pers. comm. 2017). Ongoing development of the Genting Highlands is considered to represent a threat to the recently-identified population here (E. Quah pers. comm. 2017).
population: This species is only known from approximately ten specimens, including recent unpublished collections (L. Grismer and E. Quah pers. comm. 2017). This species is difficult to find at the localities where it occurs, but the population is thought to be stable (L. Grismer and E. Quah pers. comm. 2017)
range: This gecko occurs in central Peninsular Malaysia west of the Banjaran Titiwangsa mountains on the outskirts of Kuala Lumpur in Kepong, Ulu Gombak, and the Batu Caves, Selangor. It probably has a wider range than presently recognized, and recent records exist from the lower elevations of the Genting Highlands and the base of Bukit Tinggi (L. Grismer and E. Quah pers. comm. 2017). Its type locality is “the canopy walk trail at Forest Research Institute Malaysia (FRIM), state of Selangor, Peninsular Malaysia" at 120 m asl (Chan and Grismer 2008, Grismer et al. 2014).
useTrade: There is no information about any use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: One subpopulation of the species is found within a protected area in the Forest Research Institute of Malaysia (L. Grismer and E. Quah pers. comm. 2017).

rationale: Listed as Near Threatened on the basis that this species is presently known from two localities (each considered here to represent a single location) where it apparently occurs at low densities, one of which is at immediate risk from planned quarrying activities and the other of which, while subject to no known or expected threats, is not protected. It has an estimated extent of occurrence well below 5,000 km<sup>2</sup> and is subject to a projected, imminent decline in the extent and quality of its habitat at one location. As such it is close to qualifying for listing in a threatened category applying criterion B, but it is likely to remain secure at the type locality for the foreseeable future.
habitat: This lizard has been observed during the day on karst boulders and walls within a lowland dipterocarp forest and on boulders near the entrances of cave openings, and has been described as being wary and quick to take cover in crevices and on the backsides of boulders at the slightest provocation. Multiple lizards have been found to occupy the same boulder but none have been seen at night, indicating that this species is diurnal. A gravid female has been recorded carrying two eggs, indicating that reproduction takes place in June (Grismer et al. 2014).
threats: Currently there are no plans to query the limestone on which this species occurs, or to cut down the forest surrounding it's habitat, therefore there are no current threats to this species' survival (L. Grismer and E. Quah pers. comm. 2017). The recently-identified subpopulation in Chiku is at immediate risk from quarrying scheduled for this area (E. Quah pers. comm. 2017).
population: It is difficult to find the species at the type locality (L. Grismer and E. Quah pers. comm. 2017).
range: This species is only known from Bukit Hangus, Pahang, Peninsular Malaysia at 10 m asl (Gismer et al. 2014), and from a recent subpopulation identified in Chiku, Kelantan (L. Grismer and E. Quah, unpubl. data).
useTrade: This species has not been recorded in the commercial pet trade (L. Grismer and E. Quah pers. comm. 2017).
conservationActions: This species is not known from protected areas.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable on the basis that this species occurs at low densities on a small karst formation to which it is endemic, from which it is inferred that the population is unlikely to exceed 500 mature adults, although research is recommended to confirm this. No specific threats have been identified, but densities may remain suppressed by competition with or predation from the larger gecko Gekko monarchus.
habitat: This lowland saxicolous species is known only from the karst outcropping of Gunung Reng, an isolated tower karst formation situated along the east bank of the Pergau River at its junction with Batu Melintang, Kelantan, in lowland dipterocarp forest, and containing several separate caves.  Lizards of this diurnal species have been found along the periphery of the karst formation, within cracks on the shaded overhangs and surfaces of large, disconnected, karst boulders that have fragmented and fallen off the core, and on cave walls no more than two metres above the ground. The colour variation in the type series indicates this species may be adept at substrate matching (Grismer et al. 2008). It has never been observed at night and so it is not known if its coloration changes during the evening (Grismer 2011).
threats: The only potential threat to this species is the presence of the larger species Gekko monarchus, which may prey on or compete with Cnemaspis karsticola (L. Grismer and E. Quah pers. comm. 2017). G. monarchus is expected to be native to the area (E. Quah pers. comm. 2017), so it is likely to have co-existed with C. karsticola for an extended period of time.
population: This species is very rarely observed despite a number of surveys of this small formation. On this basis and given the small size of the tower the population is estimated to be below 500 mature individuals (L. Grismer and E. Quah pers. comm. 2017).
range: This species is known only from the tower karst formation of Gunung Reng, Kelantan, Peninsular Malaysia (Grismer et al. 2008) at 113 m asl. This small, isolated, tower karst formation is situated along the east bank of the Pergau River at its junction with Batu Melintang, Kelantan (Grismer et al. 2014).
useTrade: This species does not occur in the commercial pet trade (L. Grismer and E. Quah pers. comm. 2017).
conservationActions: At this point no conservation measures need to be implemented (L. Grismer and E. Quah pers. comm. 2017). Population surveys are recommended to clarify the population size of this species.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that, although this species is restricted to a small limestone outcrop and may consequently have a small population, it is known from a protected archaeological site where it is not subject to major ongoing or expected threats and the population is considered stable.
habitat: This diurnal species species has been observed in the shadows of karst boulders and cracks and on the walls of limestone caves, as well as outcroppings in the lowland karst forest surrounding the limestone massif. At night it has been found sleeping on the leaves of low vegetation near the karst walls, and on vines and the aerial roots of fig trees next to limestone walls. Breeding is believed to take place around the month of July (Wood et al. 2013).
threats: This species is not facing any immediate threats, and is unlikely to be at risk in future as this area is protected (E. Quah pers. comm. 2017)
population: This is a karst restricted species that is restricted to a small limestone outcrop. The population appears to be stable (E. Quah pers. comm. 2017).
range: This species was described from the southeastern base of the Banjaran Bintang in northern Peninsular Malaysia, where its type locality is "Gua Asar, Bukit Kepala Gajah limestone massif, Lenggong, Perak, Malaysia" at 78 m asl. It is also known from other caves in this area, including Gua Kijang, Gua Puteri and Gua Ngaum, and it has been recorded from the surrounding karst walls and karst forest (Wood et al. 2013, Grismer et al. 2014).
useTrade: This species does not appear to be exploited for any commercial purposes (E. Quah pers. comm. 2017).
conservationActions: This species is found within a protected archaeological site (E. Quah pers. comm. 2017).

rationale: This species is listed Critically Endangered on the basis that it has an estimated area of occupancy of 8 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in a single location (estimated based on the ongoing threat event of mining exploitation, which is expected to affect both known sites) and there is an inferred continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat due to mining activities. Additional research and habitat and site protection are highly recommended.
habitat: This diurnal lowland species appears to be restricted to karst outcroppings surrounded by lowland dipterocarp forest. Most lizards have been observed on vertical surfaces in shaded areas, and some within the openings of caves exposed to sunlight or on the rocks along the periphery of the outcrop. No specimens have been observed deep within the caves (Grismer and Chan 2009).
threats: The major ongoing threat to this species is mining, which has recently been found to be ongoing within its range and undoubtedly affects areas where the species occurs (L. Grismer pers. comm. 2018).
population: Very few specimens of this species have been recorded (L. Grismer pers. comm. 2017).
range: This rock gecko is known only from the karst formations that extend approximately 4.2 km from Gua Angin to Gua Pari-pari, within the Bau Limestone area in Sarawak, Malaysia. Its type locality is Gua Pari-pari, Bau District, Sarawak, East Malaysia, at approximately 30 m asl (Grismer and Chan 2009, Grismer et al. 2014). It appears to be restricted to this area, but not necessarily only to the specific caves where it has so far been recorded (L. Grismer pers. comm. 2017). Kurita et al. (2017) map three additional localities for this species, but do not name or otherwise refer to these and their sampled specimens were all taken from the two confirmed localities (L. Grismer pers. comm. 2018). Following the recommendation of L. Grismer (pers. comm. 2018), these localities are not considered further pending confirmation that they genuinely represent this species.
useTrade: This species is not utilized (D. Iskandar pers. comm. 2017).
conservationActions: It is not known from protected areas. Additional field work and site and habitat protection are highly recommended.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that, although this species is restricted to an island with an area of 6 km2, it occurs at high densities on an island subject to no ongoing threats, and none are likely as the island retains no forest and is not suitable for development.
habitat: The habitat on Pulau Pemanggil is severely degraded and has no discernible primary forest (Youmans et al. 2002). The cave-like systems formed by the piling up of large, granite boulders on top of one another maintain the microhabitats and refugia necessary to support a dense population of this species (Grismer and Das 2006). Lizards have been found in nearly every cave system at all elevations from sea level to 250 m asl (Grismer 2011a).
threats: There are no current threats to this species, as this island is not subject to any ongoing development and the species persists in a system of caves and granite boulders unsuited to development (L. Grismer and E. Quah pers. comm. 2017)
population: This species is restricted to a small island but occurs as a dense and presumably stable population (L. Grismer and E. Quah pers. comm. 2017).
range: This species is known only from Pulau Pemanggil, Johor, Malaysia (Grismer and Das 2006, Youmans et al. 2002, Grismer 2011b). The island has an area of approximately 6 km2.
useTrade: This species does not occur in the commercial pet trade (L. Grismer and E. Quah pers. comm. 2017).
conservationActions: This species is afforded some level of protection because its island home is located within the boundaries of a marine park (L. Grismer and E. Quah pers. comm. 2017).

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered on the basis that, although this species remains abundant at present, it is known only from one locality (with an estimated area of occupancy of 4 km2) which is considered a single location defined by an ongoing threat from mining, which is ongoing in part of the karst tower and is spreading throughout the remaining available habitat for this lizard.
habitat: This species inhabits limestone walls, adjacent boulders surrounded by limestone forest, and tree trunks and vertical and horizontal branches and vines in limestone forest vegetation. Lizards have been only found on cliff faces where these were eroded and exfoliated, providing cracks and holes in which to take refuge during the day. One specimen was observed deep within the cave where vegetation was absent. It is likely to reproduce in July (Grismer et al. 2014).
threats: Ongoing quarrying activities in Gua Kanthan are directly impacting the only known habitat for this species (Grismer et al. 2014) and expanding throughout the remainder of this karst tower. If quarrying activities at this site continues, this species will be pushed into extinction in the near future (L. Grismer and E. Quah pers. comm. 2017).
population: Although this species is only known from one locality, it is abundant there. Nevertheless, as the species is known from only one site the population of this species is considered to be below 1,000 mature individuals, based on observations over the last four years (L. Grismer and E. Quah pers. comm. 2017).
range: This species is only known from Gua Kanthan, Perak, Peninsular Malaysia, at 45 m asl (Grismer et al. 214).
useTrade: This species is not found in the commercial pet trade (L. Grismer and E. Quah pers. comm. 2017).
conservationActions: The type locality of this species is not protected and is actively being destroyed as a result of mining (L. Grismer and E. Quah pers. comm. 2017). Protecting the remaining habitat is the most appropriate action that can be taken to ensure the survival of this species (E. Quah pers. comm. 2017).

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that this species is known from nine localities across an area of approximately 15,000 km2, within which it is relatively common, and there are no confirmed threats. While it is possible the species is found in the pet trade, it is not known to be specifically targeted and any exploitation is unlikely to be at a level that would threaten this species with extinction.
habitat: This nocturnal, scansorial species lives on tree trunks in lowland dipterocarp forest (Grismer 2011). It has also been observed on karst formations taking refuge in cracks and on the ground, on road crossings, within a limestone cave, and climbing on granite boulders (Grismer 2011). Gravid females have been observed carrying two eggs during September, and hatchlings during the months of March, August and September, suggesting that the species breeds year round (Grismer 2011).
threats: This species is potentially collected for the pet trade, as members of the Cyrtodactylus pulchellus group are desirable for their patterning (E. Quah pers. comm. 2017). It is possible that this represents an ongoing threat (L. Grismer and E. Quah pers. comm. 2017)
population: This species is relatively common at most reported localities (L. Grismer and E. Quah pers. comm. 2017).
range: This species is present in Malaysia (Grismer 2011) and Thailand (Adang Island, Ratabhumi and Phattalung Province - Grismer et al. 2012). In Malaysia, it has been recorded from Pulau Langkawi in the Langkawi Archipelago, Kedah (Grismer and Norhayati 2008), the base of Gunung Jerai (Robinson and Kloss 1916), Perlis State Park (Grismer 2011), Ulu Muda, Bukit Chabang and Chuping (Sumontha et al. 2012). It is expected to occur also on some of the smaller satellite islands in the Langkawi Archipelago surrounding Pulau Langkawi (Grismer 2011).
useTrade: Individuals may be found in the international trade under the name Cyrtodactylus pulchellus (L. Grismer and E. Quah pers. comm. 2017).
conservationActions: This species is present in Perlis State Park (L. Grismer and E. Quah pers. comm. 2017).

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that, although this species appears to be adaptable and the population is thought to be stable, its known range is adjacent to a residential area where several possible threats are ongoing and it is not known from protected areas. Further research may reveal that this species is more widespread than presently recognized, in which case it will warrant downlisting.
habitat: This species inhabits disturbed secondary limestone forests near a residential area, where specimens have been found at night on a wooden fence, on tree bark,  on leaves near cave entrances, and on a limestone boulder near a forest path, ca 0.5-1.5 m above the ground (Nguyen et al. 2013).
threats: Although this species is at least somewhat tolerant of forest disturbance, as presently understood its range is sufficiently restricted that it may be subject to at least limited or localized threats through extreme forest clearance for agriculture and quarrying.
population: It is locally common, with an apparently stable population.
range: This species is only known from a karst forest near Ban Nua Village, An Lac Commune, Ha Lang District, in Cao Bang Province in northern Vietnam (Nguyen et al. 2013). It is expected to also occur in the contiguous limestone forests in Guangxi Province, China (Nguyen et al. 2013) and in nearby karst forest areas in Cao Bang and Lang Son Provinces in Vietnam (Q.T. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017). It ranges between 435 and 601 m asl (Nguyen et al. 2013).
useTrade: It is not found in trade.
conservationActions: This species is not found in any protected area. There is a need for habitat protection within its small range, and research is recommended to clarify its distribution.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that this species is widespread, common in multiple habitats, and not subject to major threats.
habitat: This scansorial species is found in both primary and secondary forest, where it is active at night and usually found on leaves and branches of small trees and shrubs 1-3 m above the ground (Grismer 2011). Less frequently, it is encountered on rocks and the trunks of small trees, and only occasionally in caves (Grismer 2011).
threats: Based on this species' abundance in all habitats, there are no current or foreseen threats to this species (L. Grismer and E. Quah pers. comm. 2017).
population: This species is common and widespread in peninsular Malaysia, but is relatively rare on Pulau Tioman, possibly due to competition with the larger, more abundant Cyrtodactylus tiomanensis (Grismer 2011).
range: This species ranges from southern Thailand south through Peninsular Malaysia to Singapore (Grismer 2011). It is found on Tioman and Tulai in the Seribuat Archipelago (Grismer 2011). This species has been reported from Sumatra (Grismer 2011), but this record is not considered valid (D. Iskandar pers. comm. 2017).
useTrade: This species is not found in the commercial pet trade (L. Grismer and E. Quah pers. comm. 2017).
conservationActions: No conservation measures are required (L. Grismer and E. Quah pers. comm. 2017).

rationale: This species is restricted to a limited area of Pulau Tioman, an island subject to a degree of development from the tourist industry. The species' extent of occurrence is well below 100 km<sup>2</sup>, the area of occupancy may be as low as 4 km<sup>2</sup>, and the species' forest habitat is not formally protected. Nevertheless this species occurs in a part of the island at little risk from development, although there is a road through part of this area. It is consequently listed as Near Threatened.
habitat: This scansorial species is found in both lowland and hilly primary forest, where adults are primarily associated with large rocks and caves and are less commonly seen on tree trunks (Grismer 2011). Juveniles and hatchlings are regularly found on the forest floor and on the lower leaves of small trees (Grismer 2011). The largest adults are found near the peak of Pulau Tioman, where they are strongly associated with cave-like microhabitats formed by outcrops of large granite boulders (Grismer 2011).
threats: The forests of Tioman are not protected and are currently subject to private management. The island is a well-known tourist destination and development for both residential and tourist areas is both ongoing and expanding. The island's remaining natural forest covers less than 100 km2. The island's area is only 135 km2, and commercial development is therefore likely to accelerate rates of forest loss. The known localities where this species occurs are however close to the highest elevations on the island. Other than a road connecting Tekek on the west coast to Juara village on the east coast habitat degradation in the area where this species occurs is limited and posing little threat to the species' survival (L. Grismer and E. Quah pers. comm. 2017).
population: This species is known from a single trail on the island and nearby localities, suggesting that the population is likely to be very small (L. Grismer and E. Quah pers. comm. 2017).
range: This species is endemic to Pulau Tioman, off the coast of Peninsular Malaysia (Grismer 2011).
useTrade: This species is not found in the commercial pet trade (L. Grismer and E. Quah pers. comm. 2017).
conservationActions: These islands are within the boundaries of a protected marine park (L. Grismer and E. Quah pers. comm. 2017), however this does not confer any protection to the terrestrial habitat. A number of additional lizards and snakes are endemic to Tioman, making this a priority area for conservation in Malaysia (I. Das and G. Vogel pers. comm. 2011), and it is recommended that the island's forests should be included within the protected area system.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that this species is generally abundant and widespread, and is subject to only localized threats. Nevertheless localized, and in some cases poorly-understood, declines have been reported, including within protected areas where they may be a consequence of vegetation regrowth following management changes. Habitat restoration has been shown to reverse declines in experimental treatments, and it is recommended that this practice be adopted in areas where this gecko co-occurs with the Broad-headed Snake in order to benefit both species.
habitat: This species is found in rocky areas, ranges, caves and outcrops in dry sclerophyll forest and woodlands (Wilson and Swan 2013, Cogger 2014). Females lay a clutch of two eggs and produce their first clutch at four years of age, compared to males than can be mature at two years; some individuals can live for 13 years (Webb et al. 2008).
threats: The removal of 'bush rocks' from rock outcrops for urban gardens could cause local population declines as it removes the loose rock habitat used by the species (Webb et al. 2008). As this species nests communally, local subpopulations could be at some risk from localized pressures that reduce reproductive success (Webb et al. 2008). These authors hypothesize that vegetation thickening on rocky outcrops may reduce reproductive success by altering thermal regimes. This is nevertheless expected to be a localized pressure, as this species has a reasonably large range and Webb et al. (2008) base their observations on a single study area (G. Shea pers. comm. 2017).
population: The species is abundant across most of its range, but there are some local declines due to habitat degradation and conversion (G. Shea, H. Cogger and M. Greenlees pers. comm. 2017). In one three-year study, the number of hatchlings showed a steady decline over a three year period (Webb et al. 2008). The causes for this are unclear, but the authors hypothesized that long-term changes in vegetation structure may reduce hatching success if the cues females use for oviposition site selection prompt them to lay in shaded areas that reduce incubation temperature.
range: This species is found along the coast and ranges of New South Wales, and the far southeast of Queensland (Cogger 2014). There is a gap in the distribution in the Hunter Valley (G. Shea, H. Cogger and M. Greenlees pers. comm. 2017).
useTrade: There is no significant use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Studies have introduced artificial rocks to restore the degraded sandstone rock outcrops, resulting in a larger number of juveniles and adults detected, and the survival rates of young were apparently higher (Croak et al. 2013). This experimental restoration has not been conducted on a significant scale, and is not ongoing. There are no ongoing conservation actions specifically for this species, but it is found in protected areas throughout its range. While this gecko is not of conservation concern in its own right, across its range as a whole it appears to be an important prey item for the broad-headed snake (Hoplocephalus bungaroides) and declines in this species have been found to correlate with a reduced abundance of Amalosia lesueurii (Webb et al. 2008), as a consequence both of reduced predation success (Shine et al. 1998) and the direct removal of rocky habitat features required for the persistence of both species. Habitat restoration measures are therefore recommended to benefit this gecko.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern because it is relatively widespread, common, not currently declining and there are no known threats.
habitat: This species is found in seasonally dry woodland with stony ranges and massifs, in rocky crevices and on rocky outcrops, and has also been found in caves (Cogger 2014).
threats: No specific threats have been identified to this species.
population: It is moderately common.
range: This species is found in the Kimberley Region of Western Australia and the north-west of the Northern Territory (Cogger 2014)
useTrade: This species may be kept as a pet with a permit in New South Wales and possibly Victoria. (Office of Environment and Heritage 2016, NSW Native Animal Keepers' Species List 2016, Office of Environment and Heritage, NSW National Parks and Wildlife Service, NSW). It is easy to breed in captivity.
conservationActions: No official conservation actions are in place for this species. It occurs in protected areas within its range.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that this species occurs in a remote area where no major threats have been identified, and it is common in suitable habitat.
habitat: This species is a nocturnal, rock-inhabiting species. It is found in sandstone caves and rock faces (Wilson and Swan 2013, Cogger 2014).
threats: There are no major threats to this species.
population: It is moderately common in appropriate habitat.
range: This species is known to occur from the Mitchell Plateau in the north to the Artesian Range in the south, in the northwest Kimberley Region of Western Australia (Cogger 2014).
useTrade: This species is common in the pet trade, and is bred in captivity.
conservationActions: This species range coincides with protected areas such as the Mitchell River National Park and other protected areas in the region.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that this species is somewhat widespread, very common, and subject to no major threats. There is no evidence of population decline.
habitat: This large, arboreal and rock-dwelling species is found among boulder fields. It is associated with the humid retreats prevailing in the denser thickets of vegetation found in gullies, and in the large caverns formed in boulder slopes, caves and rock fissures (Cogger 2014), as well as adjacent aerial root systems of figs and occasionally buildings (Wilson and Swan 2013).
threats: No threats to this species exist. It is protected from the impacts of fire in its rocky habitat, and not dependent on vegetation structure as long as suitable humid microhabitats remain.
population: This species has a relatively large distribution with little evidence of continuing declines or fluctuations (Shea et al. 2011). It is very common (P. Couper comm. 2017).
range: This Australian endemic species occurs from the vicinity of Cape Melville south to the Mt Leswell area, Cape York Peninsula, Queensland (Cogger 2014). This species is also present on Stanley Island, in the Flinders Islands, just north of Cape Melville (Shea et al. 2011).
useTrade: This species is found in very low numbers (P. Couper pers. comm. 2017) in both the domestic and international pet trade.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species, however, extensive parts of its distribution lie within protected areas (Shea et al. 2011).

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that, as presently understood, this species has a large range, no major threats have been identified, and there is no evidence of decline.
habitat: This species is rock-dwelling and found in caves and large crevices of stony ranges and outcrops, foraging at night (Cogger 2014).
threats: There are no major threats to this species.
population: This species appears to be locally abundant (Horner 2005).
range: This species is known from three distinct areas: one in the limestone ranges of the southern Kimberley in Western Australia, another from the eastern Kimberley in Western Australia and Victoria River region of the Northern Territory, and a third from escarpments in the Litchfield area of the Northern Territory.
useTrade: This species is not in the pet trade.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation actions in place, but this species is known to occur within multiple conservation reserves (Atlas of Living Australia 2015). Taxonomic research is needed to clarify the status of several genetic lineages identified within this species, and if any of these warrant recognition as full species research will be needed to determine whether restricted-range taxa within this group are subject to major threats.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern because it has a wide range, it is a common species and there are no known threats.
habitat: This species is found in rocky habitats, occupying caves, crevices and rock surfaces (Cogger 2014). Females lay a single egg in each clutch (Cogger 2014).
threats: There are no major threats to this species at present.
population: It is a common species.
range: This species is distributed from the Pilbara region south to the Yalgoo region in Western Australia (Cogger 2014).
useTrade: This species is not used or traded.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation actions currently in place for this species, but it has been recorded in many conservation reserves over its range (Atlas of Living Australia 2015). Taxonomic research is underway to clarify the status of this species complex.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern as it is a relatively widespread species, it is common and there are no major threats.
habitat: This species is a specialist rock-dweller, usually found in crevices and caves of sandstone escarpments (Cogger 2014).
threats: There are no major threats to this species.
population: This is a common species in appropriate habitats.
range: This species is found in the northwest Kimberley region of Western Australia, from Kalumburu in the north to King Leopold ranges in the south, including multiple islands (Doughty et al. 2012).
useTrade: This species is not in the pet trade.
conservationActions: This species has been recorded in Prince Regent National Park and Mitchell River National Park (Atlas of Living Australia 2015). Taxonomic research is underway to clarify the systematics of this species complex.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainty as to its extent of occurrence, natural history, threats and conservation status. This is an exceptionally poorly-known species, apparently from a difficult-to-survey habitat.
habitat: It is likely that this species inhabits considerable depths, dwelling in deep and completely dark subterranean cavities (Wilson and Swan 2013).  Here, the karstic red sediments may comprise some of the habitat (Aplin 1998).
threats: Potential threats to this species are not well-known and require confirmation, however, continued mining and drilling activities on the island may degrade this species' possibly specialized habitat. Further information on this species' ecology is required to clarify whether it is at serious risk from these activities.
population: This species is known only from three specimens. The holotype was collected on the outer surface of a bore casing (Wilson and Swan 2013).
range: This presumably subterranean species is only known from Barrow Island in Western Australia (Wilson and Swan 2013).
useTrade: This species is not used or traded.
conservationActions: This species is considered a Priority Two on the Specially Protected Fauna list in Western Australia (DPaW 2015a). There are no conservation actions in place. Barrow Island, from which it is known, is an A Class Nature Reserve (DPaW 2015b), however there are extensive mining activities on the island.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that, although this species has an extremely small known range (estimated at 5 km<sup>2</sup>) and there is some ongoing degradation of habitat, mainly from road construction, it is presently unclear whether impacts of this activity are significant, the species is apparently common and the species occurs in a historical site which may offer some degree of protection. Research is needed to clarify the population status of this species and to determine the impacts, if any, of threats from development and tourism, and formal habitat protection is recommended as a precautionary measure.
habitat: This species inhabits outcrops of granitic rocks and caves in secondary, highly disturbed, semi-deciduous forest on Hon Dat Hill. It has been found in orchards (Q.T. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017). Lizards are common at night within the confines of caves and do not seem to venture out onto the open surfaces of the boulders (Grismer and Ngo 2007, Grismer et al. 2014).
threats: Rocky habitats within the range of this species are undergoing some degradation from ongoing development (such as road construction), including pressure from increased tourism to the area and quarrying.
population: It seems to be common within its limited range (Q.T. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017), although the population may be declining in response to ongoing road development.
range: This recently described species is known only from the type locality at Hon Dat Hill, Hon Dat District, Kien Giang Province, Vietnam, at 30 m asl (Grismer and Ngo 2007, Grismer et al. 2014). It seems possible that the species is restricted to the small area close to the type locality (Q.T. Nguyen and S.N. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017), as this hill belongs to a small cluster of low hills (with a maximum elevation of 100 m) completely surrounded by the agricultural lowlands in the southern regions of the Mekong Delta (Grismer and Ngo 2007, Grismer et al. 2014).
useTrade: The species does not appear to be in the pet trade at present (Q.T. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017), however it is considered possible that this species may be impacted by collection for the pet trade in the future.
conservationActions: This species is not found within by a protected area; however, the area is a historical site which may provide some protection and additional research is needed to confirm this. Monitoring of population trends is needed, along with protection measures for the limited habitat.

rationale: Listed as Near Threatened on the basis that this species has a restricted distribution across six islands (each considered a separate location), with an overall extent of occurrence of 245 km<sup>2</sup>, and there is a continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat as a result of development on the largest of these, representing the major part of its range. Nevertheless the species presently remains abundant, the population is thought to be stable, and no major threats are thought to exist to subpopulations on the remaining islands. As such the species is close to qualifying as Vulnerable under criterion B1, but at present there is no evidence that development is having a sufficient impact, or is sufficiently widespread on Con Son, to threaten this species with extinction. Population monitoring is recommended to evaluate the impacts of development and to detect any future population declines that may warrant listing this species in a higher category.
habitat: This species is extremely abundant in lowland forest habitats and can be found during the day climbing on both granite boulders and tree trunks in all planes of orientation. At night, this species has been observed in rock cracks, on the undersides of rocky overhangs, and within caves.
threats: The islands that this species occurs on are protected, however, increasing development is damaging the available habitat for this species on Con Son, at around 80 km<sup>2</sup> in area by far the largest island on which it occurs, through impacts such as road construction and building of tourist facilities (N.S. Nguyen pers. comm. 2018). It is unlikely to be subject to major threats on the other islands (N.S. Nguyen pers. comm. 2018).
population: This is a common species, with a seemingly stable population.
range: This species is endemic to Viet Nam where it is restricted to the Con Dao islands. There are records from Con Son, Hon Ba, Hon Bay Canh, Hon Cau, Tre Lon, Tre Nho and Hon Tai (Nguyen et al. 2016). Records from the mainland are considered to be misidentifications and are not considered here.
useTrade: There are no current records of this species in the pet trade.
conservationActions: It is found in Con Dao National Park; however, this protected area is being damaged through ongoing development. Monitoring of subpopulation trends would be beneficial.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that this species is known only from protected areas in a region where no major threats are thought to exist.
habitat: This species inhabits rocky crevices at elevations between 200-500 m in Thailand (Grismer et al. 2014). Hala-Bala is a heavily forested area. It has also been found in caves in Malayan mixed dipterocarp forest (Chan-ard et al. 2015)
threats: This species is presently known only from protected areas, and no major threats appear to exist. This is an area with extensive separatist activity, which limits both development and survey effort in this region.
population: Two specimens were found in Narathiwat Province and Yala Province, Thailand. One specimen was collected in Belum-Temengor region (Grismer et al. 2014).
range: This species is known only from the Thai-Malaysian border region from Halabala, in the Waeng District in Narathiwat Province, and from Bang Lang National Park and Bannag Sata District, Yala Province, Thailand and the Belum-Temengor region of Perak in northern Peninsular Malaysia. (Grismer et al. 2014). The range is thought to be continuous between the known localities.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: The species is found in protected areas in both Thailand and Malaysia.

rationale: Listed as Endangered on the basis that this species has an extent of occurrence of 555 km<sup>2</sup> and occurs in two locations, one of which consists of two close localities both subject to pressure from development and the other of which lies within a protected area, and there is a continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This lowland, nocturnal species is a karst microhabitat specialist that has been found in the vicinity of small streams in rainforest. During the day, lizards retreat into limestone crevices and caves (Grismer et al. 2010, 2014). It is lost from areas where forest has been lost.
threats: Deforestation for tourism and residential development is the major threat to this species.
population: This is a common species, but is likely to be in decline as a result of tourist development (M. Sumontha pers. comm. 2017).
range: This species is known from the border regions of Trang Province (Thum Khao Ting, Palean District) and Satun Province (Baan Nam Phut [La-ngu District], Manang and Kuan Kalong Districts) in Thailand, where it ranges between 28 and 46 m asl (Grismer et al. 2010, 2014; M. Sumontha unpubl. data).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Two of the known localities lie within Khao Banthat Wildlife Sanctuary (M. Sumontha pers. comm. 2017).

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable on the basis that this species has a very small range, however, threats from quarrying are presently very limited and may not be significantly impacting the population currently. There is a plausible risk that this activity could spread rapidly through the area in the near future and encompass most or all of the hill to which this species is endemic. Should this threat become active the species will immediately qualify for listing as Critically Endangered.
habitat: The species inhabits granitic outcrops in primary semi-deciduous forest, where it is most active in caverns near areas where sunlight can filter down, supporting growth of plants and mosses within which the lizard forages (Grismer and Ngo 2007). Lizards avoid direct sunlight and remain on the shaded vertical and inverted rocky surfaces nearby (Grismer et al. 2014). At night, lizards venture out into open areas within the cavern as well as onto boulder surfaces exposed to the outside, and appear inactive.
threats: Part of the small hill this species is endemic to is being quarried for both rock and soil, which is transported into the lowland floodplain area. While the quarrying is fairly limited at present, it is considered possible that this threat could eventually impact the majority of the hill and so encroach into the full range of this lizard.
population: It appears to be common within its limited range, and the overall population is generally stable.
range: This species is known only from the type locality of Tuc Dup Hill, located 36.3 km south of Chau Doc in Tri Tron District, An Giang Province, Viet Nam near the border with Cambodia, where it has been recorded at 100 m asl (Grismer and Ngo 2007, Nguyen et al. 2009, Grismer et al. 2014).
useTrade: It is not known if this species is collected for the pet trade.
conservationActions: It is not found in any protected areas. The type locality was a Viet Cong headquarters during the Viet Nam War and currently serves as a museum celebrating Tuc Dup Hill as a strategic military hideout (Grismer et al. 2014). Setting aside areas for protection on the Tuc Dup Hill would be beneficial to the conservation of this species.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that although this species has a restricted known distribution, with both known localities lying close to a village where there is a plausible future threat from deforestation, it is unclear whether it is more widespread or whether it ranges into a nearby protected area, and it is unclear whether a future impact from deforestation is sufficiently plausible or extensive that the species is likely to be driven to Critically Endangered or Extinct in the near future.
habitat: It has been recorded foraging on the surface of karst outcrops above the entrance of a cave, surrounded by secondary forest dominated by species of the families Ebenaceae, Arecaeae, Poaceae, Meliaceae, and Moraceae (Luu et al. 2016). It is a karst associated species that likely requires some forested habitat for foraging.
threats: This species' known distribution lies close to a village, and there is a potential threat from future deforestation.
population: This recently described species is poorly-known, and its abundance and population trend are not well-characterized.
range: This species is known only from two localities: the type locality in the karst forest near Ban Soc Village, Bualapha District, Khammouane Province, central Laos, at 195 m asl (Luu et al. 2016), and a second recently-discovered site in the nearby area (Luu et al. in press).
useTrade: This species has not so far been recorded in trade.
conservationActions: It has not been recorded from any protected areas. Additional surveys to clarify the geographic distribution would be beneficial. There is a need to protect remaining forest habitat within the known range, including extension of an adjacent protected area.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that, while this species is known only from the type locality and is unlikely to have a much wider range, this locality lies within a protected area and no significant threats have been identified.
habitat: It has been recorded at night on limestone cliffs near cave entrances, approximately 0.5-0.8 m above the ground, surrounded by disturbed evergreen forest of medium and small hardwoods and shrubs (Nguyen et al. 2015).
threats: There is some very limited timber logging, and some firewood collection, within the range (including within the nature reserve), but this may not significantly affect this species (Q.T. Nguyen pers. comm. 2018).
population: Very little is known about the population of this species.
range: This recently-described species is known only from the type locality in Ngoc Son-Ngo Luong Nature Reserve in Hoa Binh Province, Vietnam (Nguyen et al. 2015). It ranges between 195 and 618 m asl (Nguyen et al. 2015).
useTrade: There is no use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species is present in Ngoc Son-Ngo Luong Nature Reserve (Nguyen et al. 2015). While this species is likely to have a limited range associated with the availability of karst substrate, some additional field surveys to better-define the range would be beneficial.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that this species, despite having a small range, is well protected and is not thought to be subject to major threats.
habitat: It has been found at night on limestone outcrops surrounded by karst semi-evergreen forest (Luu et al. 2016). Animals can be encountered within caves.
threats: There do not appear to be any threats to this species, which is known only from a well-protected area.
population: This species is locally common in suitable habitat, with a stable population.
range: This species is known only from the type locality in Tham Nok En area, Hin Nam No National Protected Area, Khammouane Province, in central Laos (Luu et al. 2016). It ranges between 190 and 260 m asl (Luu et al. 2016).
useTrade: There is no use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is present in Hin Nam No National Protected Area (Luu et al. 2016). Additional surveys to clarify the range of this species would be useful.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered on the basis that this species is known from a restricted area of karst under heavy pressure from limestone quarrying, which has already destroyed most of the available habitat in this area and is leading to a continuing decline in the extent and quality of the remaining karst. Within this area the species has an estimated area of occupancy below 10 km<sup>2</sup>, and is treated as occurring at a single location defined by the threat from quarrying.
habitat: This species can only be found around or in caves (Bauer et al. 2003)
threats: This area is subject to stone quarrying for limestone for concrete and for stone, which represents a significant threat to this species and is projected to become more severe in future (M. Sumontha pers. comm. 2017). This activity already encroaches into the caves where this species is found, and will become more severe in future (M. Sumontha pers. comm. 2017). The species is collected, which given its restricted range may represent a major threat although it is presently common.
population: Bauer et al. (2003) found three male specimens during day time, and at night they found one female and one juvenile specimen. All specimens were found around or in caves in the Phraputthabata District (Bauer et al. 2003). This species is currently common, but is likely to be declining (M. Sumontha pers. comm. 2017).
range: This species is endemic to caves in the Phraputthabata subdistrict, Chalermphrakiat District, Saraburi Province, central Thailand (Bauer et al. 2003). The estimated total area of karst in this area "may be around 10 km2", including areas that have since been destroyed (M. Sumontha pers. comm. 2018).
useTrade: This species is collected domestically as a pet, as it is easy to keep in captivity (M. Sumontha pers. comm. 2017).
conservationActions: This species is not known from protected areas, although the known distribution lies close to Nantok Samian National Park.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that, although it has a restricted range, there appear to be no current or likely near future threats to this species.
habitat: It is largely limited to crevices in limestone rocky habitats (karst), with individuals having been encountered climbing on the stony walls of caves (Quang et al. 2007).
threats: There is some limited habitat degradation (logging) within the species range, but overall this is not thought to be having an impact on the population.
population: It appears to be a rare species, with nothing known about the population trend.
range: This species is known from the type locality in Chau Quang village, Quy Hop district, Nghe An Province, north-central Vietnam, at 90 m asl (Quang et al. 2007, Nguyen et al. 2009).
useTrade: There is no trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is present within the Pu Huong Nature Reserve in Vietnam. No direct conservation measures are currently needed.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that, while this species is known from a restricted range close to a village and there is a plausible future threat from extensive development already underway in the surrounding area, a recent record has extended its range into the Hin Nam No National Protected area, where a large area of potentially suitable habitat exists and no major or potential threats have been identified. Given the limited data presently available, it is unclear whether the species is more widespread within the protected area, in which case it is unlikely to be at significant risk of extinction, or whether the majority of the range lies in unprotected areas where there is a plausible future threat from development that would remove forest on which it is likely to be dependent. Further research is recommended to clarify its distribution and ecological tolerances.
habitat: This species inhabits limestone karst, where it has been recorded at night on the walls in small-sized caves near numerous cracks that serve as shelters. It has been observed in syntopy with Cyrtodactylus khammouanensis (Nazarov et al. 2014, T. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017). It likely needs forest surrounding the karst to persist, on the basis that although this area is dominated by "sparsely-vegetated limestone karst" (Nazarov et al. 2014) records taken by B. Stuart (pers. comm. 2017) near the type locality were all from forested outcrops.
threats: The type locality is close to a village, and there is plausible potential for the forest to be degraded within the range of this species. There is extensive development underway in the region. Hin Nam No is a protected area within an extensive karst system, and no potential threats operate in this area (V. Luu pers. comm. 2018).
population: This species is not uncommon in suitable habitat. The population trend is unknown.
range: This species is only known from the type locality in the vicinity of Na Phao Village in Bualapha District, Khammouan Province, Laos, at 170 m asl (Nazarov et al. 2014, T. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017), and from a recent record in Hin Nam No (Luu et al. in press).
useTrade: This species is not in trade.
conservationActions: This species is known from the Hin Nam No National Protected Area (Luu et al. in press). Additional research is needed to clarify the distribution of this species.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that this species has a restricted range at the edge of a protected area where it is nonetheless subject to no major threats due both to local traditions limiting disturbance to the cave habitat and only limited disturbance of surrounding forest at the edge of a protected area. If the species is found to be restricted to the cave the global population is likely to be well below 1,000 mature individuals, however it is possible that the species ranges more widely in forest within the park boundary.
habitat: This species is only found within Tham Phabartmaejon (Bauer et al. 2010). It can be found at night outside the cave, in the nearby forest and on rocks (M. Sumontha pers. comm. 2017).
threats: There is a lot of tourism in this area, and there is some disturbance of the forest due to local exploitation of resources (M. Sumontha pers. comm. 2017). Neither is likely to represent a major threat to this species. The area is protected to some degree by local traditions, as people believe that it is unlucky to disturb the cave (M. Cota pers. comm. 2017).
population: Five specimens were collected from Tham Phabartmaejon in 2005: two male and three female adults (Bauer et al. 2010). It is common at the only locality (M. Cota pers. comm. 2017).
range: This species is endemic to Tham (Cave) Phabartmaejon in Chiang Mai Province in the northwest of Thailand (Bauer et al. 2010). It has been observed in forest near the cave at night (M. Sumontha pers. comm. 2017), but may not occur more widely in the forest away from the cave.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species is restricted to a cave at the edge of Cheng Dao National Park.
