There is some encroachment and disturbance to the forest in this area, as it as the margin of the protected area, but no particular conservation measures are required (M. Sumontha and M. Cota pers. comm. 2017).

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that, while this species has a small range, it is exclusively found within caves in a Biosphere Reserve and no threats are either currently active or expected.
habitat: It is a nocturnal cave-dwelling species. It is restricted to the undersides of granitic boulders and does not expose itself to the outside surfaces (Ngo 2008). Lizards can be found as deep as five to seven metres below the surface of the ground.
threats: There are no current or expected threats to this species.
population: It is a relatively rare species found in cave-like situations created by large granitic boulders piled on top of one another. There is little information on population trends for this species, but it may be stable overall.
range: This species is known from Hon Son Island, Lai Son Commune, Kien Hai District, Kien Giang Province, in southwestern Vietnam, ca. 200 m asl (Ngo 2008).
useTrade: This species has not been recorded from the commercial pet trade.
conservationActions: The range of this species is entirely within the Kien Giang Biosphere Reserve.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern on the basis that this species occurs in caves in a remote area where no threats are likely to exist, it is thought to occur in protected areas, and may be more widespread than presently known.
habitat: This species inhabits caves, where it feeds on cave crickets, termites, and various insect larvae; animals taken into in captivity take both meal worms and termites (Bauer et al. 2009). Its breeding takes place in the winter season, at which time males emit advertisement vocalizations to females. The eggs are non-adhesive, and oviposited in rock crevices within caves. The incubation period is about two months (Bauer et al. 2009).
threats: There are multiple protected areas in this region, and this species undoubtedly occurs in at least one of them although it is unclear which. Although people live within the protected areas in this remote region, there are unlikely to be any threats.
population: An adult male was collected and a juvenile specimen was photographed outside Tham Lod cave in 2005 (Bauer et al. 2009). It appears not to be particularly common (P. Duengkae pers. comm. 2017).
range: This species is known only from the type locality, which lies in the West Thanin Thongchai Mountains in Mae Hong Son Province in the extreme northwest of Thailand (Bauer et al. 2009). This locality is less than 10 km from the border with Myanmar (Bauer et al. 2009). It may occur more widely along this mountain range (M. Cota pers. comm. 2017).
useTrade: There is no information on any use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is unlikely that any conservation measures are required, and this species is presumed to occur within protected areas.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable on the basis that this species has a very small range, however, threats from quarrying are presently very limited and may not be significantly impacting the population currently. There is a plausible risk that this activity could spread rapidly through the area in the near future and encompass most or all of the hill to which this species appears to be endemic. Should this threat become active the species will immediately qualify for listing as Critically Endangered.
habitat: This nocturnal and saxicolous species inhabits caves within lowland forests (Ngo 2008, Das 2010).
threats: Part of the small hill to which this species is endemic is being quarried for both rock and soil, which is transported into the lowland floodplain area. While the quarrying is fairly limited at present, it is considered possible that this threat could eventually impact the majority of the hill.
population: It is an uncommon species, but can be found with targeted searches. The population is currently considered to be largely stable.
range: This species is only known from the type locality in Tuc Dup (Co To) Rocky Hill, Tri Ton District, An Giang Province, southwestern Viet Nam, at ca 100 m asl (Ngo 2008).
useTrade: This species is not in trade.
conservationActions: It is not found in any protected areas. Setting aside areas for protection on the Tuc Dup Hill would be beneficial to the conservation of this species. Further surveys for this species are needed in nearby hill areas.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that this species is endemic to a protected island, in which there are no ongoing or likely future threats.
habitat: This nocturnal and saxicolous species inhabits caves within lowland forests, where it has been found in granitic areas (Ngo et al. 2008, Das 2010).
threats: There are no current or expected threats to this species.
population: It is a relatively rare species found in cave-like situations created by large granitic boulders piled on top of one another. Little information on population trends for this species is available, but it may be stable overall.
range: This species is only known from the type locality in Hon Tre Island in Kien Giang Biosphere Reserve, Kien Hai District, Kien Giang Province, in southwestern Vietnam, at ca. 15 to 100 m asl (Ngo et al. 2008, Das 2010).
useTrade: There is no use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is present in the protected area of Kien Giang Biosphere Reserve (Ngo et al. 2008). No direct conservation measures are needed.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable on the basis that, although the species is presently common and the population likely stable, it has a very restricted range (estimated at around 26 km<sup>2</sup>), treated here as a single location defined by a plausible future threat from habitat change as a result of quarrying that could quickly result in this species becoming Critically Endangered or Extinct, and a lesser threat from increasing levels of disturbance from tourism.
habitat: This species inhabits lowland granitic caves. These are sometimes within secondary deciduous forests, although this vegetation structure is not necessary for subpopulation persistence (Ngo and Bauer 2008, Das 2010) and some of the caves are within cashew plantation areas. Animals have been recorded close to houses and other residential buildings.
threats: Any threats to this species are not well-known. While is seems to persist in caves in modified plantation habitat, there are potential pressures from increasing levels of tourist access. This may have some adverse impacts but further research is needed to determine this. Cable car construction has recently begun on the mountain and there are concerns that, in common with other areas of southern Viet Nam, Chua Chan may become a future target for quarrying.
population: While this species seems to be uncommon, it is currently thought to have a stable population overall.
range: This species is only known from Chua Chan Mountain in Xuan Truong Commune, Xuan Loc District, Dong Nai Province, southeastern Viet Nam, at 70 to 300 m asl (Ngo and Bauer 2008, Das 2010).
useTrade: There is no information on any use of or trade in this species, but it is unlikely to be traded.
conservationActions: It is not known from any protected areas. Some research into the possible impacts of tourist activity is recommended.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that this species is common and widespread and not subject to major threats in the Thai part of its range. Although likely threats exist in much of its range in Laos, at present good forest remains in much of this area.
habitat: This nocturnal gecko inhabits caves in the vicinity of limestone hills and also occurs in evergreen forest close to caves. It is an adapted tree-dweller and lives high on tree trunks and in tree crowns (Luu et al. 2016) as well as caves or adjacent fig trees with numerous crevices close to caves (Chan-ard et al. 2015). It forages on the ground or among boulders in close proximity to caves at night (Chan-ard et al. 2015, Luu et al. 2016).
threats: There are no major threats to this species. Forest in this area is in generally good condition and this species is found in multiple protected areas. It can also persist in secondary forest (M. Cota pers. comm. 2017). Hydroelectric dam development is underway in the sites where the species has been recorded in Laos (B. Stuart pers. comm. 2017). More broadly within this area good forest is likely to be relatively extensive, but much of its range in this country is along the Mekong and low-elevation evergreen forest in this area is at risk from settlement and rapid urban development (B. Stuart pers. comm. 2017).
population: This species is very common (M. Sumontha pers. comm. 2017). There is no evidence of decline (M. Sumontha and M. Cota) at least in Thailand. As apparent threats exist within its range in Laos, its population status in this country is not clear.
range: The species is present in central to eastern Laos and Thailand (Ulber 1993, Chan-ard et al. 2015, Luu et al. 2016, B. Stuart and S. Phimmachak pers. comm. 2017). In Laos, it has been found in the provinces of Vientiane and Khammouane (Luu et al. 2016). In Thailand, it occurs in Phu Luang Wildlife Sanctuary in Loei Province, and Nam Nao National Park in Petchabun Province, at 600 m asl (Ulber 1993, Chan-ard et al. 2015). It has also been reported from sites in Tak, Utai Thani and Phetchaburi (Nabhitabhata and Chan-ard 2005), although the Phetchaburi locality (Kaengkrachan) is uncertain as it is some way to the south of the remainder of the range (M. Cota and M. Sumontha pers. comm. 2017).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species is found in protected areas.

rationale: Listed as Endangered on the basis that this species has an extent of occurrence of or below 600 km<sup>2</sup> and has undergone an observed decline in the number of mature individuals, likely to be attributable to predation by uncontrolled domestic cats. It is considered to occur at a single location defined by this threat. At the accessible locality within the cave system anecdotal evidence suggests that the population may have declined by around 50% in a decade; if surveys confirm this rate of decline for the population as a whole, it will also warrant listing under criterion A.
habitat: This species inhabits a limestone cave in Lampang Province. It was found foraging on the cave walls or on boulders at the entrance of the cave during night time (Pauwels et al. 2014). It also occurs outside the cave (M. Sumontha pers. comm. 2017).
threats: Domestic cats are thought to be the reason for the apparent decline in this species, and the cats have been observed to forage within the cave (M. Sumontha pers. comm. 2017). Pauwels et al. (2014) consider that this species is also threatened by tourist activity as this is a heavily-visited site, and by limestone mining. The unprotected portion of the range is however difficult to access and is mountainous with no road access, so although mining is a potential future threat there are no proposed mining operations, and tourism development is unlikely to be a threat.
population: Three specimens were collected in 2008: an adult male, an adult female, and a subadult male (Pauwels et al. 2014). About a decade ago, prior to its description, it was found to be common (M. Sumontha pers. comm. 2017). It is now considered uncommon at the same locality, following a reduction in its population size of about 50% (M. Sumontha pers. comm. 2017).
range: This species is known only from a limestone cave in Pratu Pha, Mae Mo District, Lampang Province, northern Thailand (Pauwels et al. 2014). The mapped range is larger than the true extent of occurrence, which is restricted to a 40 x 15 km2 area (M. Cota pers. comm. 2017).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: The species is found in Tam Pha Thai National Park, encompassing about half the range. Removal of domestic animals from the protected area may be necessary.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that although this species has a restricted range, it is not thought to be subject to major threats and is very common.
habitat: This species is nocturnal, and inhabits limestone caves (Pauwels et al. 2014). It has not been found in forest behind the caves.
threats: Pauwels et al. (2014) suggest that this species may be threatened by intensive tourism. The nearest resorts are however not immediately adjacent to the cave, and although there is likely to be some level of religious tourism this is not likely to be a major threat in this rural area (M. Cota, M. Sumontha and P. Duengkae pers. comm. 2017).
population: Five specimens were found in the limestone cave in Suan Hin Pha Ngam: one adult male, two adult females, one subadult male, and one juvenile (Pauwels et al. 2014). It is very common at this locality (M. Sumontha pers. comm. 2017).
range: This species is known only from a limestone cave in Suan Hin Pha Ngam, Amphoe Nong Hin, Loei Province, northeastern Thailand (Pauwels et al. 2014).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species' range is not protected, but as a religious site this area is not likely to be subjected to significant disturbance.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that this species is known from multiple protected areas, it is common with no evidence of decline, and no major threats have been identified.
habitat: This species has been found on tree trunks in the forest near streams, in the crevices of trees and in houses, in association with karst boulders and caves (Grismer et al. 2012). Two female specimens were collected in 2000 by Pauwels et al. (2000), each of them containing two eggs.
threats: There is no known evidence of major threats or of decline.
population: This species is common, with no evidence of decline (M. Cota and M. Sumontha pers. comm. 2017).
range: This species is known from Khao Chong waterfall, Khao Chamao, Trang Provinc;, from Petch Phanomwung Cave, Kanchanadit District, Surat Thani Province; Krabi, Krabi Province; from Suwankuha Cave, Phung Chang Cave, Tham Phung Chang Cave; and from limestone formations surrounding Phang-nga City, Muang District, Phang-nga Province, Thailand (Grismer et al. 2012). It has also been found in Khao Sok National Park in Surat Thani (reported in Klong Naka Wildklife Sanctuary 2002, as Cyrtodactylus pulchellus - M. Sumontha pers. comm. 2017).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species is found in multiple protected areas.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable on the basis that this species has an apparently highly restricted range close to a major road and a concrete company, and there is a plausible future threat from quarrying that, should it become active, may drive this species to Critically Endangered or Extinct in a short period of time. Further research is needed to clarify whether its geographic distribution is completely known.
habitat: It has been found at the entrance of a cave on a karst hill (Ngo and Pawels 2010). It is thought likely to require both karst and surrounding forest. Animals have been recorded from karst areas in the vicinity of caves.
threats: The known range is close to a major road, and it is possible that it could be impacted in the future through quarrying for limestone (concrete production). It is possible that tourism to the cave disturbs this species (perhaps through noise and incense smoke), as it is difficult to observe the species in cave areas that the tourists visit.
population: This gecko appears to be abundant in suitable habitat. The population may be stable.
range: This species is only known from the type locality in Lomyen Cave and its vicinity, Gnommalath District, Khammouane Province, in southern Lao PDR, at 150 to 200 m asl (Ngo and Pawels 2010).
useTrade: There is no use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is not known from any protected areas. Further surveys to clarify the species' geographic distribution are needed.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered on the basis that this species is known only from Ma Thien Lanh Valley, treated as a single location based on a primary threat from road construction and a secondary threat from habitat degradation driven by tourism, it has an extent of occurrence well below 100 km<sup>2</sup> and an inferred area of occupancy below 10 km<sup>2</sup>, and it is subject to ongoing habitat degradation due to pollution of both the streams and cave systems.
habitat: This nocturnal and saxicolous species inhabits areas close to streams in granite caves, where it has been found in the deeper parts of caves and climbing cave walls (N.S. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017).
threats: The site on the mountain from which this species is most often recorded is threatened by disturbance from ongoing road construction, and from an increasing number of people moving into the area. Road construction is concentrated on the slope along the rocky stream where the gecko occurs, and debris from road construction is known to have washed into the stream (N.S. Nguyen pers. comm. 2018). There is limited quarrying on the mountain, and the possible future expansion of this is not well-known. There is some tourism on the mountain, and rubbish including waste plastic has been found within and near the cave during surveys (N.S. Nguyen pers. comm. 2018), although the effects on the lizard are not clear.
population: It is a very rare species, with little information available on the population trend. Four field trips in 2005, 2007, 2011 and 2017 suggest that the species may be becoming harder to find: while 10 specimens were collected during the first visit, the subsequent surveys collected two, one and four animals respectively (N.S. Nguyen pers. comm. 2018).
range: This species is only known from Ma Thien Lanh Valley in Ba Den Mountain in Tay Ninh Province, southern Viet Nam (Nguyen et al. 2006). This hill has an area of 18 km2 and the species is confined to a small number of caves where it is associated with streams (N.S. Nguyen pers. comm. 2018). While it may be more widespread in low-elevation streams around the mountain, few streams are known from this area, suggesting that the species' area of occupancy will be below 10 km2 (N.S. Nguyen et al. 2018). It has been recorded from 50 to 150 m asl., and the mountain has a maximum elevation of 986 m asl. (N.S. Nguyen pers. comm. 2018).
useTrade: It has been recorded in the pet trade, but the extent of exploitation is not known (S. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017).
conservationActions: It is known from a historical site, but not from any protected areas. Conservation of the few known caves that this species inhabits is urgently needed.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that, while this species occurs in a small area and is not known from protected areas, impacts are limited at present and it is not considered to be at significant risk.
habitat: It has been recorded in limestone caves (Schneider et al. 2011). The known sites are within forested areas (both primary and secondary) and it is considered that it needs forest cover to persist.
threats: Part of the habitat is minimally impacted by road construction and limited quarrying of limestone.
population: This species is not difficult to find within suitable habitat. The population trend seems to be stable overall.
range: This species has been recorded in the Phoukham Cave and Pouna Cave near Ban Na Thong Village, and in Phouthong Cave near Ban Phongeuan, all of them in the Vang Vieng District, Vientiane Province, northwestern Laos (Schneider et al. 2011). It ranges between 260 and 300 m asl (Schneider et al. 2011).
useTrade: This species is not traded.
conservationActions: It is not known from any protected areas. Further research into is distribution is needed.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that this species occurs in a well-protected area of Thailand where no likely threats exist, and it is common with no evidence of decline.
habitat: Within Thanon Khao Yai, outside the protected area, this species inhabits forested mid-hills supporting agriculture at elevations of 400 asl. (Das 2010). In Chaiyaphum, Petchabun, and Loei provinces, this species occurs in limestone caves within dry evergreen forest (Chan-ard et al. 2015). It is found on the ground, small cliffs and rock faces around cave entrances (Chan-ard et al. 2015). In captivity, its diet consists of arthropods such as cockroaches and woodlice. It clutches comprise two eggs, rarely only one egg. The incubation period is about 130 days (Das 2010).
threats: No major threats to this species exist.. It occurs in many protected areas, and there is no significant or forseeable development within unprotected areas within its range.
population: This is a very common species. There is no evidence of decline.
range: Chan-ard et al. (2015) recorded this species in Nakhon Ratchasima, Chaiyaphum, Petchabun, and Loei province. It is found at the western edge of Khao Yai, with the main range encompassing the mountain ridge from Phu Keio to the western edge of Khao Yai in Saraburi (Nabhitabata and Chan-ard 2005, M. Sumontha, M. Cota and P. Duengkae pers. comm. 2017)
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species occurs in numerous protected areas, including Khao Yai.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that, although this species is confined to a single cave, it is common and subject to no threats, and is likely to be protected from any future disturbance by local traditions.
habitat: This species is known from a single cave. It has been found at the entrance of the cave and up to about 100 m from the cave entrance, but always on or along the karst cliffs and boulders. The cave is surrounded by secondary forest with numerous lianas. Individuals have been found actively foraging on the leaf litter, on tree trunks and stumps, on large leaves, boulders, on karst cliff and on the cement walls of a temple associated with the cave. One adult female was gravid with two eggs (Pauwels et al. 2013).
threats: There are no threats to this species. The cave in which it is found is likely to be protected from disturbance by local traditions, which treat the area of the temple as a holy site.
population: In total 15 individuals of this species were encountered in a nocturnal survey between 2000 and 2300 hours, suggesting it can be regarded as locally common (Pauwels et al. 2013). The species was found to be common in a survey in April 2017, which recorded 20 geckos in an hour (M. Sumontha pers. comm. 2017).
range: This species is known only from Tham Sanook, Chumphon Province, southern Thailand (Pauwels et al. 2013).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species does not occur in a protected area.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that, while this species has a small range, it is known from a protected area and is not subject to substantial threats.
habitat: It has been recorded mainly on karst walls above the ground, near cave entrances in lowland limestone forest dominated by species of the families Ebenaceae, Dracaenaceae, Arecaeae, Poaceae, Meliaceae, and Moraceae.
threats: There do not appear to be any threats to this species within its limited, protected range.
population: It seems possible that this is a common species. Nothing is known about the population trend.
range: This species is known only from the type locality in the karst forest of Hin Nam No National Protected Area, Khammouane Province, central Laos, between 269 and 614 m asl (Luu et al. 2016).
useTrade: This species is not used or traded.
conservationActions: This species is known only from Hin Nam No National Protected Area (Luu et al. 2016). Additional research into the distribution of this species may be helpful.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known from a small area and nothing is known of any ongoing threats. Although it is possible that it may be impacted by future limestone quarrying, nothing is known of plans to quarry in this area or whether this species is either likely to be at risk should this activity become active, or whether it occurs in a nearby protected area that may provide safeguards against any future habitat loss.
habitat: It inhabits a typical lowland limestone karst area covered with lush vegetation, where it has always been found inside karst caves (Nazarov et al. 2014).
threats: Any threats to this species are not very clear. Its distribution lies close to a road and there is a possibility that it could be impacted by limestone quarrying in the future. This needs further confirmation.
population: Very little is known about the abundance or population trend for this species.
range: The species is known only from the unnamed type locality in Khammouan Province (incorrectly reported as Vientiane Province in Nazarov et al. 2014; however, the coordinates for the type locality given in this publication correctly refer to a locality in Khammouan).
useTrade: This species is not found in trade.
conservationActions: This species is not known from within a protected area, however the species has been recorded close to Nam Kading National Protected Area. Surveys within this protected area are recommended to determine whether the species is present here.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered on the basis that this species is extremely rare and only known from a single location on an isolated mountain (which represents an extent of occurrence as low as 16 km<sup>2 </sup>and a restricted area of occupancy which is likely to have been reduced by the recent construction of a cable car), to which it is probably endemic and which is subject to an inferred decline in the quality and extent of its habitat as a result of increasing tourism. While the specific mechanism by which this activity degrades the species' habitat is unclear, and population trends are unknown, recent surveys suggest that it is becoming harder to find. The listing is consequently considered precautionary and further research is urgently required to clarify the impacts of tourism on this species.
habitat: This species inhabits lowland deciduous forest, where it is associated with granite rocks and deep caves. It likely needs open areas near good forest (N.S. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017).
threats: Its habitat is often disturbed during the dry season do to an annual influx of visitors and pilgrims who go down the bottom of the cave to get fresh water that they believe will bring them luck (Ngo and Bauer 2008). A shrine in Hang To cave itself which is frequently visited, and may directly disturb animals or introduce torches that may disturb the species. Noise and incense or smoke pollution, and rubbish left by tourists, are likely to degrade habitat quality in the caves, and tourism is increasing every year (N.S. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017).  A cable car has been constructed in this area, resulting in the destruction of surrounding forest for the cable car chain and associated infrastructure (a restaurant, two stations, and a trail and accommodation for tourists) (N.S. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017).
population: This species is very rare, and population trends are unknown. N.S. Sang (pers. comm. 2017) reports that "it is more and more difficult to observe the gecko", based on observations during multiple surveys since 2008, and in both dry and wet seasons.
range: This species is only known from Ta Kou, an isolated mountain, where its range appears to be limited to Hang To Cave, Ta Kou Nature Reserve, Binh Thuan Province, in southern Viet Nam, at 450 m asl. (Ngo and Bauer 2008). Extensive surveys elsewhere on the mountain and in the surrounding area, where similar habitat may be scarce, have only found this species at this locality, with other geckos dominating the fauna elsewhere and at the entrance of Hang To itself (N.S. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017).
useTrade: There is no information on any use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This animal is only known from a protected area, but that designation does not preventing tourists from disturbing the animal (N.S. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017). Further research into the distribution throughout the park and into its population status are urgently needed. So far it has only been found at a single site in the park despite numerous surveys of Ta Kou.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known from a single specimen and there is no information on its distribution, population status, natural history or on any ongoing or likely threats.
habitat: It has been recorded near the entrance of a cave at the bottom of a tall karst formation, at the foot of which runs a small creek which dries up during the dry season. The area is covered with semi-evergreen forests, with small, scattered banana groves in the undergrowth.
threats: Any possible threats to this species are not known.
population: It is known only from a single specimen.
range: This species is only known from the type locality in Ban Na Hin, Nam Kading National Biodiversity Conservation Area (NBCA), in Borikhamxay Province, Laos, at 200 m asl (David et al. 2011).
useTrade: There is no use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: It is found in Nam Kading National Protected Area. Further research needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and any threats is recommended.

rationale: Listed as Near Threatened on the basis that this species is endemic to a single cave and possible future threats exist from both uncontrolled domestic or feral cats, and development. Observations that the species is reliably found in surveys suggest that the population may presently be stable, and the area is not sufficiently attractive for development for this to be considered a plausible future threat sufficient to drive the species to Critically Endangered or Extinct, and any ongoing or future impacts of feral animals are presently speculative. As such the species is close to but does not fully qualify for listing as Vulnerable applying criterion D2.
habitat: This species inhabits a single cave on a relatively isolated, steep limestone hill covered by forest near the beach (Das 2010, Pauwels et al. 2004). The cave is wet and is situated about 30 metres above the surrounding area, and is about 100 metres deep (Pauwels et al. 2004).
threats: Development represents a possible future threat, as the surrounding area is heavily disturbed and the type locality is not protected. This locality is a completely isolated formation and the species is undoubtedly endemic to this site. There appear to be no current plans to develop this locality, which is not likely to be attractive for development. Domestic animals, especially cats, may represent a current or future threat to this species.
population: Four specimens were seen by Pauwels et al. (2004) during a one-day survey. It can reliably be found on visits to the site (M. Sumontha pers. comm. 2017); this worker reports seeing this species every time he has surveyed the area.
range: This species is endemic to Khao Song in Surat Thani Province, southern peninsular Thailand. (Pauwels et al. 2004, Chan-ard et al. 2015)
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species is not found in protected areas. Control of cats recommended as a precautionary measure.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable D2 on the basis that this species is confined to a single unprotected mountain and although threats appear to be limited at present, there is potential for an expansion of quarrying in particular to result in this species rapidly becoming significantly threatened if this takes place.
habitat: This cave-dwelling species inhabits mixed forest of hardwood and vine, dominated by trees of the families Moraceae, Fabaceae, and Dipterocarpaceae (Phung et al. 2014). It has been recorded at night on a rocky wall in a small cave, approximately 0.5-2.5 m above the ground (Phung et al. 2014). Most of the specimens were found inside the cave, ca 2-5 m from the entrance, and only one was collected outside, ca 1.5 m away from the entrance (Phung et al. 2014).
threats: There is some tourism on the mountain, but it is not known if these activities are likely to significantly impact the species. There is limited quarrying on the mountain; this may represent a plausible future threat to this species, but the likelihood of future expansion of this activity is not well-known.
population: The population and trends are unknown.
range: This species is only known from Ba Den Mountain, Thanh Tan Ward in Tay Ninh Town, Tay Ninh Province, southern Viet Nam, at 600 m asl. (Phung et al. 2014).
useTrade: There is no information on trade.
conservationActions: This species has not been recorded from any protected areas. There is a need to set aside areas for the conservation of this species within its limited range. Further study is required, particularly on a molecular level, to clarify its taxonomy.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that this species was described from a well-managed protected area, it is common, and recent records have extended its range further in a region where no major threats exist.
habitat: In Sai Yok this species has been found in bamboo forest on a limestone hill. It is found on exposed limestone 1-1.5 m above ground (Das 2010). It is also found both deep inside (Chan-ard et al. 2015) and outside (M. Sumontha pers. comm. 2017) limestone caves and crevices (Chan-ard et al. 2015). It is mainly nocturnal.(Das 2010, Chan-ard et al. 2015). It has been found close to streams along limestone (M. Sumontha pers. comm. 2017).
threats: There are no known or likely threats to this species.
population: Two specimens were collected in 2002: an adult male and an adult female (Bauer et al. 2003). The species is common (P. Duengkae and M. Sumontha pers. comm. 2017).
range: This species was until recently known only from Sai Yok National Park, Kanchanaburi Province, western Thailand, close to the Myanmar border (Bauer et al. 2003, Das 2010, Chan-ard et al. 2015). Recent records have extended its range north as far as Songkhla Buri (N. Panitvong, unpubl. data), and it has also been recorded as far south as Sueng Phuang District (P. Niyomwan, unpubl. data) based on a record originally thought to represent an undescribed species. It probably occurs through the intervening area.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species was described from Sai-Yok National Park (Bauer et al. 2003) and also occurs in other protected areas (M. Cota pers. comm. 2017).

rationale: This species appears to have a very fragmented distribution, with the area of occupancy estimated to be smaller than 500 km<sup>2</sup> (as it is unlikely that this much lowland forest survives on the island based on estimates from 20 years ago that only 600 km<sup>2</sup> of forest then remained below 400 m asl). In addition, deforestation, mining, and over collection for pet trade is causing a continue decline in its distribution, habitat quality, and numbers of mature individuals. It is therefore assessed as Endangered.
habitat: On Sulawesi it was collected from a large Ficus tree growing in disturbed secondary forest, planted heavily with coffee; while specimens from Kabaena Island were collected from the walls of a large cave complex (Hayden et al. 2008). In south Sulawesi, this species has been found associated with large holes. These survey suggest this species might be dependent on very high quality forest with large cave systems. It is possible occur between 0-500 m asl (G. Gillespre pers. comm. 2019).
threats: The threats to this species include habitat loss due to deforestation (conversion of land to agricultural use), limestone mining, and potentially collection of animals for the pet trade (G. Gillespie pers. comm. 2019). Estimates of forest clearance show an 89% loss of lowland forest across Sulawesi below 400 m above sea level (from 546,500 to 60,000 ha) between 1985-1997 (FWI and GFW 2002), and lowland forest on the island was considered to have been reduced to "statistical insignificance" by 2002 (FWI and GFW 2002).
population: This species currently seems to be known only from the type series of four specimens (two from Sulawesi and two from Kabaena). In population on Kabaena is presumed to be very small (G. Gillespie pers. comm. 2019). The population trend remains unknown, but the species is likely to be in decline as a result of habitat loss, potentially exacerbated by collection should this species become targeted by the pet trade.
range: This species has been recorded from Desa Kelapa Dua, in Southern Provence of Sulawesi on the island of Sulawesi and also on the island of Kabaena in the Southeast Province, both in Indonesia (Hayden 2008, Koch 2012). Surveys indicates the this species might have a very restricted and fragmented distribution (G. Gillespie pers. comm. 2019). On Kabaena, this species was only found inside one limestone cave. Despite extensive surveys this species has not been found anywhere else in Southeast Sulawesi. It is possible occur between 0-500 m asl (G. Gillespre pers. comm. 2019).
useTrade: This species is potentially of interest to the pet trade, as a large and distinctive gecko (G. Gillespie pers. comm. 2019).
conservationActions: This species is not known from any protected areas. Trade regulation and habitat protection are needed for this species. Further research needed for its distribution, taxonomy, and population (G. Gillespie pers. comm. 2019).

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable on the basis that this species is known from only two localities, one of which requires verification to confirm that it represents this species, and the confirmed site is close to a road where a plausible threat from limestone quarrying exists. Should this threat become active, the species could plausibly be driven to Critically Endangered or Extinct.
habitat: Animals have been found at the entrance of, and within, a cave on a karst hill, in karst areas in the vicinity of caves, and on trees in the surrounding forest.
threats: The known range is close to a major road, and it is possible that this species could be impacted in the future through quarrying for limestone (concrete production). It is possible that tourism to the cave disturbs this species (perhaps through noise and incense smoke) as it is difficult to observe the species in cave areas that the tourists visit. The species is also likely to be susceptible to possible future loss or degradation of the forest, which appears to be required by this species for foraging.
population: It appears to be abundant in suitable habitat. The population may be stable.
range: This species is known from the type locality in Lom Yen Cave, Nhommalath District, Khammouan Province, central Lao PDR, at approximately 150-200 m asl (Ngo et al. 2015). The description referred an adult female specimen from a cave near Ban Nathan (Hin Boun District) to this species (Ngo et al. 2015), however, this second subpopulation needs additional taxonomic review to confirm its identity.
useTrade: There is no use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species is not known from a protected area. Further research is needed to try to locate additional subpopulations and to confirm the identity of a record from Ban Lathan.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable on the basis that this species is known from a single karst block where there is some ongoing degradation of its forest habitat. As the species is capable of persisting in secondary forest this is not presently considered a major threat, however it will not tolerate complete forest clearance and there is a plausible threat that the removal of forest to support the expansion of plantation agriculture would rapidly drive the species to Critically Endangered.
habitat: This crepuscular or nocturnal species has been observed in a karst forest at night on the tree trunk of shrubs, about 1.0-1.5 m above the ground, near the entrance of a karst cave surrounded by secondary forest of small hardwood and shrubs near a village and about 40 m from a main road (Luu et al. 2015).
threats: Threats are presently limited within the karst block, not extensive and unlikely to be causing significant decline, however, the known locality is impacted by habitat loss through quarrying of limestone, and loss of forest habitat. It is close to a road, village and cement company.
population: It seems to be an uncommon species, with little information about the population trends.
range: This species is only known from the type locality in a karst forest near Bam Kouanphavang, Thakhek Town, in the Khammouane Province of central Lao PDR, at 146 m asl (Luu et al. 2015).
useTrade: This species is not in trade.
conservationActions: This species is not known from any protected areas. A taxonomic review of this species and Gekko thakhekensis is needed to determine whether these taxa are conspecific. More research is recommended into its distribution and the impact of possible threats.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered on the basis that this species is known from a restricted area of karst under heavy pressure from limestone quarrying, which has already destroyed most of the available habitat in this area and is leading to a continuing decline in the extent and quality of the remaining karst. Within this area the species has an estimated area of occupancy below 10 km<sup>2</sup> and is treated as occurring at a single location defined by the threat from quarrying.
habitat: This species inhabits limestone caves and areas near the cave entrances. It is active on the surfaces and tree roots, and retreats to holes and crevices if disturbed. This species lays eggs during the dry season (Panitvong et al. 2010).
threats: This area is subject to stone quarrying for limestone for concrete and for stone, which represents a significant threat to this species (M. Sumontha pers. comm. 2017). This activity already encroaches into the caves where this species is found, and will become more severe in future (M. Sumontha pers. comm. 2017). Panitvong et al. (2010) suggests that a potential threat exists from domestic cats.
population: Three adult male specimens and one adult female specimen were collected in 2009 (Panitvong et al. 2010). This species has a very small population: only one or two animals are found on most surveys (M. Sumontha pers. comm. 2017). Population densities appear to be about a tenth of those in the sympatric Cyrtodactylus chanhomeae (M. Sumontha, unpubl. data). Population trends are difficult to determine as a consequence, but the species may be in decline as a result of threats operating in this area.
range: This species is distributed in Khao Wong and Khao E-Mod, two karst formations within Chalermphrakiat District, Saraburi Province, central Thailand (Panitvong et al. 2010). The estimated total area of karst in this region "may be around 10 km2", including areas that have now been destroyed (M. Sumontha pers. comm. 2018).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Panitvong et al. (2010) suggest there is a need for more research focusing on the distribution and ecology of the species in order to better understand and protect it.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that this species, despite its restricted range, is subject to no major threats, is found in a protected area, and has recently been found to range more widely within Kanchanaburi than presently known.
habitat: This species inhabits a limestone hill within bamboo forest, where it is active on the walls of shallow caves and on slender vegetation, especially bamboo.(Das 2010, Bauer et al. 2008). The recent range extension elsewhere in Kanchanburi is characterized by similar habitats, in a building surrounded by forest, and it has also been found retreating into crevices between limestone rocks (M. Sumontha and M. Cota pers. comm. 2017).
threats: No major threats to this species are known.
population: Four specimens were collected in 2003: two adult males and three adult females (Bauer et al. 2008). This species is common, with no indication of population change (M. Sumontha pers. comm. 2017).
range: This species is endemic to a single limestone hill near Sai Yok Noi waterfall, in Sai Yok District, Kanchanaburi Province, cental western Thailand (Bauer et al. 2008, Das 2010). This species is endemic to Kanchanaburi Province in western Thailand, near Ban Tha Sao and Sai Yok National Park (Bauer et al. 2008, Das 2010, Chan-ard et al. 2015), and the range has recently been extended to include the Mueng District (M. Sumontha, unpubl. data).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species is known from Sai Yok National Park.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that this species is widespread and common, and adapts moderately well to disturbance as long as suitable karst forest remains.
habitat: This rock-dwelling species inhabits sandstone rocky hill habitats in disturbed, dry deciduous dipterocarp and semi-evergreen forest, where it is commonly encountered in cracks and crevices on boulders, rock faces and walls, between large rocks, at the entrance of karst caves, under rock ceilings and on house walls and columns, both during the day and night (Stuart 1999, Neang et al. 2015, Chan-ard et al. 2015). It has been found in karst forest in Laos (B. Stuart pers. comm. 2017), and in buildings in forested areas (M. Cota pers. comm. 2017).
threats: There are no likely threats to this species.
population: This species is common in protected areas in Thailand (M. Cota pers. conn, 2017) and can be very common: M. Sumontha (unpubl. data) recorded eight animals in 1-2 m. It is common in Cambodia (T. Neang pers. comm. 2017). It is locally abundant in suitable habitat in Laos, but there are few known localities (B. Stuart pers. comm. 2017). The population is likely to be stable.
range: This species is present in Laos, Thailand and Cambodia (Taylor 1962, Stuart 1999, Harbig 2006, Chan-ard et al. 2015). In Thailand, it has been recorded in the northeastern part of the country, in the provinces of Ubon Ratchatani and Si Saket (Taylor 1962, Chan-ard et al. 2015) and Buriram and Sa Keo (W. Thaksintham and M. Cota unpubl. data). In Laos, it has been reported from the southern part of the country (Stuart 1999). In Cambodia, it has been found from Preah Vihear Province (Preah Vihear temple) to karsts in Stung Treng Province (Thalaborivath District), and as far south to areas with small granite hills near Phnom Chi (Prey Lang, San Dan District) in Kampong Thom Province, between 124 and 562 m asl (Neang et al. 2015).
useTrade: There is no use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species occurs in protected areas. Taxonomic research is recommended to clarify the identity of records from northern Laos.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable on the basis that, although the species is presently common and the population likely stable despite ongoing impacts from plantations, it has a very restricted range (estimated at around 18 km<sup>2</sup>), treated here as a single location defined by a plausible future threat from habitat change as a result of quarrying that could quickly result in this species becoming Critically Endangered or Extinct.
habitat: This species is associated with caves, which it uses as a diurnal shelter site and to lay eggs (N.S. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017). It is usually found at night on rocky surfaces, lianas, shrubs and trees (particularly figs) (N.S. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017).
threats: This species may be disturbed by tourists, as the known locality lies along the path to a pagoda.  It may be threatened by habitat loss resulting from land use change to plantations, as plantations lack the vegetation structure this species appears to favour for foraging (N.S. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017). Plantations are, however, long-established in this area and the species remains common (N.S. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017). Cable car construction has recently begun on the mountain and there are concerns that, in common with other areas of southern Viet Nam, Chua Chan may become a future target for quarrying.
population: This species is common. Its population is thought likely to be stable on the basis that its rocky habitat is presently largely undisturbed (N.S. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017). There have however been only two recent surveys of this area (N.S. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017) so nothing is known for certain of population trends.
range: This species is only known from Chua Chan Mountain in the Suoi Cat Commune, Xuan Loc District, Dong Nai Province, Viet Nam (Ngo et al. 2009). It ranges between 100 m (Ngo et al. 2009) and 500 m asl (N.S. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017).
useTrade: There is no information on any use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no species specific conservation measures in place. It does not occur in a protected area.

rationale: Although this species has a large distribution, this species is facing considerable threats from pet trade, as well as pressures from road construction, land clearing for small agriculture and plantations, and tourism development. It seems reasonable to infer that the population could decline more than 30% in a three generation length window (12 years). Therefore it is assessed as Vulnerable.
habitat: The species is associated with grasslands and hilly landscapes with open monsoon forests (Barker et al. 2018). It has been found in coastal caves, preying on bats (S. Reilly pers. comm. 2019), as well as in grasslands, mangroves, shrublands, and monsoon forest. One specimen was found inside a village house (N. Rusli pers. comm. 2019).
threats: The major threat for this species is overcollection for the international pet trade (S. Reilly and E. Arida pers. comm. 2019). Road construction - including a major highway through central Flores that is likely to open remaining forest areas to development - land clearing for small agriculture and plantations, and tourism development could also be threats to this species in Flores (A. Stubbs pers. comm. 2019).
population: This python appears to be a rare species (de Lang 2011). It is in high and seemingly increasing demand in the international pet trade, and as a combination of this and habitat loss (which is expected to accelerate following the recent completion of a major highway through central Flores) it is estimated that the population is likely to decline by over 30% in a 12 year window - estimated to correspond to three generations - from the past to the future (A. Stubbs pers. comm. 2019).
range: This species is endemic to the Lesser Sunda Islands of Indonesia, where it has been recorded from the islands of Flores, Solor, Lembata, Adonara, Lomblen and Pantar (de Lang 2011, Barker et al. 2018). The reported occurrence on Lombok is in error, and to date its presence on Alor and Timor is unconfirmed (Barker et al. 2018, de Lang 2011), despite Mertens (1930) indicating its occurrence on the latter island. It ranges from sea level to about 500 m asl.
useTrade: The species is involved in the international pet trade, with specimens typically collected from the eastern Lesser Sunda Islands (de Lang 2011). Between 2000–2018, Indonesia exported more than 450 live specimens, of which all were documented as captive-bred (the species is protected in Indonesia, and species protected are only permitted to leave the country as captive-bred, that would imply that all exports represented F2 specimens. Markets in Europe and the USA sell the species between 700–800 Euros per specimen (R. Lilley pers. comm. 2019), and prices in the international pet trade have increased over the last few years (A. Stubbs pers. comm. 2019). From 2010–2018, Indonesian records show about 250 specimens were exported from Indonesia, labelled as farmed (E. Arida pers. comm. 2019).  These numbers, however, appear to be "clear" underestimates, as more than 50 individuals have been recorded at a single wholesaler in a short period (A. Stubbs, unpubl. data), and the species is commonly included in price lists of many wholesalers and available for retail in the USA (A. Stubbs pers. comm. 2019); also the export of live animals is suspected to take place under the name of other species (A. Stubbs pers. comm. 2020).
conservationActions:
This species occurs in several protected areas, including Komodo National Park (a population on Rinca Island has been recorded that likely reveals a new sister species of Malayopython timoriensis). The species is protected according to Indonesian law, thus only permitting the export of captive-bred (F2) specimens. Improved enforcement of trade restrictions on this species is needed, particularly to prevent laundering of wild or farmed individuals (see Lyons and Natusch 2011, Janssen and Chng 2017).

More research is needed to clarify its taxonomy, distribution, ecology and habitats (N. Rusil pers. comm. 2019).

The species is included under CITES Appendix II because of the listing of the family.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a broad range of habitats and its presumed large population.
habitat: It is a species of extremely arid localities, and is often found far from the nearest permanent water. It breeds in temporary pools in desert and semi-desert savannah, gheltas (permanent pools at the foot of cliffs or in the mouth of caves) and in water in caves. It can be found deep in burrows during droughts, it emerges from these to breed after rains.
threats: The most likely threat is the increase in human expansion and settlement, with the resulting increase in populations of domestic livestock impacting breeding pools.
population: It is apparently very common and widespread in Somalia, and has been reported as numerous near Port Sudan, but is somewhat rarer and more localized in Ethiopia and Eritrea. It is highly localized and rare in Egypt.
range: This species ranges from northern and central Somalia, through eastern Ethiopia, Djibouti and Eritrea, northwards through Sudan to extreme southeastern Egypt (vicinity of Gebel Elba only). It occurs from sea level up to 1,800 m asl.
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilized.
conservationActions: It occurs in the Awash National Park in Ethiopia, in the Elba protected area in Egypt, but it is not in any protected areas in Somalia.

rationale: Listed as Near Threatened (NT) because this species has an extent of occurrence of 3,168 km<sup>2</sup>, although it is likely that it has a larger distribution, but still less than 20,000km<sup>2</sup>. When considering habitat loss and degradation due to climate change, it is considered to occur at two locations. Climate models predict a 95% loss of vegetation on Sarisariñama by 2100 (Rull et al. 2019b) but at present there is no known ongoing decline in the extent or quality of the habitat or the number of individuals. It is therefore considered Near Threatened as it is close to qualifying for Vulnerable and is likely to do so in the near future.
habitat:
This nocturnal species has been observed on plants 0.3–1.5 m above the ground, on mossy sandstone walls soaked by water near cascades, inside caves or in crevices (Barrio-Amorós and Brewer-Carias 2008). It is sympatric with Osteocephalus taurinus, and Pristimantis sarisarinama, the gecko Gonatodes superciliaris, and the lizard Anolis ortonii.

Like other members of this genus, females carry their eggs and juveniles on their back and breed by direct development (Señaris et al. 1997; Duellman and Hoogmoed 1984; Salerno and Pauly 2012; Duellman 2015). A large Homoptera was found in a male's stomach.
threats: Climate change is an ongoing threat to this restricted range species. Despite having direct development, changes in humidity and temperature extremes could affect the reproductive success of this species and force it to shift their altitudinal distributions in the slopes (Rull et al. 2019b). On Sarsariñama, where this species occurs, ARS-GIS modelling and vegetation fragmentation analyses predict a ca 95% loss of its vegetation by 2100 (Vegas-Vilarrúbia et al. 2012; Rull et al. 2019b).Ye’kwana people living at the foot of Jaua-Sarisariñama perceive an increase in temperature, a decrease in rainfall and changes in flood and drought regimes (Bevilacqua et al. 2018; Bevilacqua et al. 2019). Also, viral, bacterial and fungal pathogens of global impact are potential threats to this species.
population: This species was described from three adults collected in 1974 on top of Cerro Sarisariñama. In March 2002, Barrio-Amorós and Brewer-Carias (2008) collected 12 individuals from two other localities in Sarisariñama; the species appeared to be abundant inside the Sima Mayor (sinkhole). It is also likely to be common in lowlands, as Ye’kwana indigenous people have named this species.
range:
This species has been observed at 1,100-1,400 m asl on Cerro Sariariñama, Bolívar state, Venezuela, (Duellman and Hoogmoed 1984; Barrio-Amorós and Brewer-Carias 2008), but it is likely to have a larger geographic distribution on the lowlands and slopes of Sarisariñama tepui. Ye’kwana indigenous people (also known as Makiritare) recognize this species and name it “müdü wënäwësiye” (Barrio-Amorós and Brewer-Carias 2008).

The Jaua massif is part of the Roraima group and includes two large sandstones: Cerro Jaua, with a maximum elevation of 2,250 m asl, and Cerro Sarisariñama, with a maximum elevation 2,350 m asl (Rull et al. 2019a). Sarisariñama is a large tepui with a summit area (≥1,500 m) of 546.88 km2 and a slope area of 286 km2 (Rull et al. 2019a); this massif is famous for its immense sinkholes (simas) including the Sima Mayor, the volumetrically largest sima in the world with 350 m depth and 350 m diameter (Brewer-Carias 1976; Brewer-Carias and Steyermark 1976; Aubrecht et al. 2012).
useTrade: This taxon has no known use or trade.
conservationActions:
Conservation actions in-place:
There are no conservation actions in-place specifically aimed to this species, but the extension of is known presence is entirely within the limits of the Jaua-Sarisariñama National Park.

Conservation Needed
Because this range restricted species is threatened by climate change, germplasm banks and captive breeding are the only known strategies to effectively ensure populations and genetic diversity.

Research Needed
Its habitat has been under-explored. In light of the potential effects of climate change on Pantepui habitats (Rull et al. 2019b), we need to monitor changes in habitat quality and better understand the vulnerability of this species to changes in temperature, drought and the loss of its habitat.

This species is listed as DD in the Venezuelan Fauna Red List (http://wikieva.org.ve/index.php/Stefania_riae).

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable because its extent of occurrence is only 4 km2 and when considering the threat of temperature extremes, and prolonged and more frequent droughts due to climate change, it is considered to occur at only one location. At present there is no significant ongoing decline in the extent or quality of its habitat, but the predicted habitat loss on the summit of tepuis due to climate change and an increase in the frequency of fires could threaten this species. It is therefore considered Vulnerable as it is close to qualifying for Critically Endangered and is likely to do so in the near future.
habitat: This nocturnal species is found on low vegetation in forests or on the walls inside small caves. Its breeding habits are unknown, although it presumably breeds by direct development.
threats: This species lives in pristine ecosystems of the remote Guiana Shield highlands. However, climate change is an ongoing threat to restricted range species of these highlands, because extreme temperatures and droughts can affect its reproductive success. Altitudinal Range Shift (ARS) and Species-Area Relationship (SAR) climate change models predict a loss of 97% of the vascular vegetation of the Pantepui area in the Yutajé-Corocoro, under a 2-4°C temperature increase scenario (Solomon et al. 2007), threatening this species in the future (Nogué et al. 2009, Rödder et al. 2009, Vegas-Vilarrúbia et al. 2012, Rull et al. 2019). Viral, bacterial and fungal pathogens are potential threats to this species.
population: This species was described from two adult females and one adult male collected in 1995. However, no other records are known from explorations to Cerro Yaví (Gorzula and Señaris 1999). Therefore, this species appears to be rare.
range: This species is only known from the summit of the Cerro Yaví in northern Amazonas state, Venezuela, at 2,150 m asl (Myers and Donnelly 1996). This species could occur more widely in the Yutajé subdistrict, including tepui summits between 1,800 and 2,300 m asl (Cerro Yaví, Serranía Yutajé-Coro Coro, and Cerro Guanay) with high variety of shrublands and high levels of endemism, but this requires confirmation. The tepuis of this subdistrict (Yaví, Yutajé) are characterized by the absence of peats, present in most other tepuis (Rull et al. 2019a). The estimated current area of occupancy (AOO) and extent of occurrence (EOO) of this species is only 4 km2.
useTrade: This taxon has no known use or trade.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
There are no conservation measures specifically aimed at this species, but its range includes the Monumento Natural Cerro Yaví, and Monumento Natural Serranía Yutaje-CoroCoro. This species is listed as Vulnerable (VU) in the Venezuelan Fauna Red List (Señaris and Rojas-Runjaic 2015).

Conservation Needed
Continued management of Monumento Natural Cerro Yaví, and Monumento Natural Serranía Yutaje-CoroCoro is essential for the conservation of this species, and other endemic amphibians of the Guiana Highlands.

Research Needed
This species is still missing from phylogenetic analyses, and its relationships with others members of the genus is unknown. Further research into the taxonomy, distribution, ecology, life history, population status and threats of this species is needed. It is urgent to assess the vulnerability of this taxa to the potential effects of climate change on the Guiana Highlands ecosystems to plan future conservation actions.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered because its inferred extent of occurrence is only 92 km<sup>2</sup>, and it is known from only a single location where habitat loss due to agriculture, urban and dam developments is an ongoing threat.
habitat: It is a nocturnal species. The holotype was collected in a cave at 1,830 m asl, just above where a cloud forest existed, and around an elfin forest with rocky areas, lichens, bromeliads and mosses. This species is sympatric with Allobates mandelorum. As with other congeners, it is presumed to breed by direct development.
threats: The forested habitats of the Turimiquire massif, where this species was found, have been largely degraded by agricultural activities (subsistence and commercial), logging, urban developments, recurrent fires and, especially, by hydraulic developments such as reservoirs, and aqueducts that provide water to four major cities in eastern Venezuela. Forests have been converted to modified savannas and shrublands, and only the upper elevations (>2,000 m asl) maintain some of the original cloud forests (Oliveira-Miranda et al. 2010).
population: This species is only known from three individuals collected in 1925 (see Rivero 1961, Tate 1935). Several sightings of unidentified Pristimantis specimens at Cerro El Guamal suggest a second subpopulation of this species, but their taxonomic status needs to be confirmed.
range: This species is only known from three individuals collected by Tate in 1925 in a cave at about 1,830 m asl, at La Trinidad, Turimiquire masif, in the eastern portion of the Venezuelan coastal range, between Sucre and Monagas states (Tate 1935, Rivero 1961, La Marca 1992, Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019, Paynter 1982). However, later sightings of unidentified Pristimantis specimens, suggest that this species could also be present at Cerro Guamal (Schmidt 1932, Manzanilla and Sánchez 2005 “2004”, Manzanilla et al. 2006, G. Rivas pers. comm.).
useTrade: This taxon has no known use or trade.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species occurs within Area Protectora Macizo del Turimiquire, a protected area with little enforcement.

Conservation Needed
Effective forest preservation and continued management of existing protected areas is essential for the conservation of this species. Environmental vigilance in Area Protectora Macizo del Turimiquire must be reinforced in order to stop the ongoing loss of forests. An extensive local educational program is also recommended.

Research Needed
Further research into the distribution, ecology, life history, population status and threats to this species is needed. Further explorations to Cerro Guamal are required to confirm the taxonomic status of Pristimantis sp. present there.

rationale: This species has declined rapidly in the past, probably as a result of changing agricultural practice and hunting in its wintering grounds, and possibly habitat loss in its breeding grounds, and this decline is projected to continue. These factors qualify it as Vulnerable; although there have been reported local population increases, and if this should prove to be a more general trend then the species may warrant downlisting in the future.
habitat: It breeds in holes in trees, buildings, cliffs, earth banks, and potentially on power lines (D. L. Bohra in litt. 2016) in semi-arid and desert areas, including around human settlement and (at least in Kazakhstan) in woodland. In winter, it occurs in open areas with scattered trees, often with agricultural crops, and in areas with suitable fruiting trees, where it roosts and feeds gregariously. It is reportedly on the rise in the western part of the Thar Desert where it experiences extreme temperatures, within a habitat of sparse thorny vegetation and grasses (D. L. Bohra in litt. 2016). Its diet includes grass seeds, arable crop seeds and the fruit of trees and shrubs, including Zizyphus and mulberry Morus alba.
threats: Hunting in both its breeding and wintering grounds has been the primary cause of its decline and continues to be a major threat in China. In India, intensification of arable cultivation and a change from the large-scale cultivation of pulses and mustard to wheat and rice has reduced the quality of habitat in its key wintering areas. Destruction of poplar Populus woodland is believed to have had a major impact on the breeding population in eastern Kazakhstan.
population: The population size is preliminarily estimated to fall into the band 10,000-19,999 mature individuals. This equates to 15,000-29,999 individuals in total, rounded here to 15,000-30,000 individuals.
range: Columba eversmanni breeds in southern Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Turkmenistan, Tajikistan, Kyrgyzstan, Afghanistan, north-east Iran and extreme north-west China (BirdLife International 2001). Its status and distribution within this range are poorly known. It winters in Pakistan and north-west India, historically as far east as Bihar, and southern Xinjiang and western Gansu, China. During the 19th and early 20th centuries, it was recorded in huge flocks in its wintering grounds, particularly in the Punjab, India. However, it has declined rapidly, from wintering flocks numbering thousands of birds to flocks generally only of tens or a few hundreds of birds, with occasional larger counts, most recently (1995) of up to 2,000 individuals in a single flock. Whether it continues to decline is unclear, and there is some evidence that it may have steadily increased at one site in India (Jorbeer dead animal dump) since 2011 (Bohra and Vyas 2014, D. L. Bohra in litt. 2016).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions Underway
In China, 15 protected areas have been designated within its range. In India, it occurs around the Harike Lake Bird Sanctuary, Punjab.

Conservation Actions Proposed
Survey its central Asian breeding range to establish the size and distribution of the breeding population, key threats and habitat requirements. Investigate habitat requirements in its wintering grounds. Protect important breeding habitat from further loss and degradation. Protect it from hunting across its range, particularly in China, where it should be listed as a protected species, and in India. Improve management of protected areas holding the species.

rationale: This species is only known to be extant in a cave in Nagasaki Prefecture. It has an area of occupancy (AOO) of 4 km<sup>2</sup> and the cave represents a single location based on the threat of sedimentation. This threat is leading to a continuing decline in habitat and the population. Therefore, this species is assessed as Critically Endangered.
habitat: This species inhabits groundwater in caves (Ministry of the Environment, Government of Japan 2015).
threats: Sedimentation in caves is the primary threat to this species (Ministry of the Environment, Government of Japan 2015).
population: One subpopulation of this species (in Shimane Prefecture) is now extinct. The only confirmed extant subpopulation of this species is in Nagasaki Prefecture (Ministry of the Environment, Government of Japan 2015).
range: There are records of this species from caves in Shimane, Nagasaki and Kochi Prefectures (Ministry of the Environment, Government of Japan 2015). However, the subpopulation in Shimane Prefecture is known to be extinct and the individuals from Kochi Prefecture have not been confirmed as this species based on the specimens collected (Ministry of the Environment, Government of Japan 2015). Therefore, the only confirmed extant subpopulation of this species is in Nagasaki Prefecture (Ministry of the Environment, Government of Japan 2015).
useTrade: There is no use or trade information on this species.
conservationActions: There is no information on conservation actions for this species.

rationale: This species qualifies as Near Threatened because, within its very small range, it is restricted to just four islands, on which threats remain that could negatively impact the species in the future.
habitat: It prefers thermophilous forest, with a potential altitudinal range of 200–500 m asl on the north slopes of the islands, and 600–1000 m asl in the south (Nogales et al. 2009) and occurs in areas with steep slopes, escarpments and gullies, as well as in laurel forest and Canary pine forest, and cultivated areas (Martín et al. 2000). Nests are on the ground - in fissures, holes or small ledges, at the bases of trees, and under rocks or fallen tree trunks - in steep, rocky, shady areas with abundant shrubby vegetation, and contain one or occasionally two eggs (Martín et al. 2000). The breeding season varies between islands, but extends from January to September, with a peak between April-June. At least on Tenerife, breeding success appears to be low, as a consequence of intense nest predation (Hernández et al. 1999, Martín et al. 2000). It is usually sedentary but can move from upland forests to lowland agricultural land to feed (Baptista et al. 2017). It feeds on fruit, grain, buds and flowers (Baptista et al. 2017).
threats: Habitat loss has been extensive. Dry and laurel forests have been intensively exploited since the 15th century, and some areas of remaining forest continue to be felled and fragmented owing to the demand for wooden stakes and poles for agriculture, particularly vine-growing (Hernández 2004, Martín et al. 2000). Grazing by livestock, notably sheep, is degrading habitat on El Hierro and La Gomera. Predation of eggs and chicks by rats, and of nesting adults by feral cats Felis catus, are important threats (Hernández 2004), particularly on Tenerife where five of seven nests monitored were predated, primarily by black rats Rattus rattus (Hernández et al. 1999, Martín et al. 2000). Illegal hunting remains a threat, especially when birds concentrate at drinking and feeding sites (Hernández 2004). Recreational activities such as climbing, abseiling, quad-biking, mountain-biking and motocross may disturb nesting birds (Hernández 2004, Barov and Derhé 2011). The species is potentially threatened by outbreaks of Avian Pox, Trichomoniasis, Newcastle Disease and Tuberculosis (Barov and Derhé 2011, A. Martín in litt. 2016).
population: In the absence of detailed censuses, the breeding population is estimated to number 1,000-2,500 breeding pairs, equating to 3,000-7,500 individuals, roughly equivalent to 2,000-5,000 mature individuals.
range: This species is endemic to the Canary Islands, Spain, where it occurs on the islands of La Palma, La Gomera, Tenerife and El Hierro (González 1996, Martín and Lorenzo 2001), and formerly on Gran Canaria (Barov and Derhé 2011). In the 1980s, the population was estimated at 1,200-1,480 individuals, but more surveys conducted during 1997-2000 estimated the population at 1,000-2,499 pairs (BirdLife International 2004). Although this figure is considerably higher than the previous estimate, the increase in numbers may reflect increased sampling effort rather than an actual population increase, however the species is now believed to be more widely distributed than previously thought (Martín and Lorenzo 2001, Martín et al. 2000). Data from censuses and recent phylogenetic studies have shown that the preferred vegetation type of the species is thermophilous forest (Marrero et al. 2008, Gonzalez et al. 2009, Nogales et al. 2009), which has been heavily reduced and only small fragments of original habitat remain (Santos 2000). Habitat loss has had severe consequences on the distribution of the species, which currently survives in secondary areas of laurel and pine forest (Martín et al. 2000). The largest subpopulation is found on La Palma, where it occurs across much of the northern half of the island. The species is common on La Gomera, where it is found primarily in the north, and also occurs patchily on the northern slopes of Tenerife. It has recently also been recorded on El Hierro; however, breeding there has not yet been confirmed (Martín and Lorenzo 2001, Martín et al. 2000). Although the species was recently suspected to be declining on Tenerife (Hernández 2004), data suggest that its Area of Occupancy, and so presumably its population, has increased overall during the last 20 years (Barov and Derhé 2011).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions Underway
EU Birds Directive Annex I. Bern Convention Appendix II. It is fully protected under Spanish law. Many protected areas have been established, including Garajonay National Park (La Gomera), and El Canal and Los Tiles (La Palma). The majority of areas inhabited by the species now have protected status under regional or national law (Barov and Derhé 2011). There have been several projects focused on the conservation of this species (and Dark-tailed Laurel Pigeon Columba bollii) since the 1980s. An action plan was published in 1996 and reviewed in 2010 (Barov and Derhé 2011). The restoration of pine forest and thermophile forest is still pending full implementation (Barov and Derhé 2011). As part of a LIFE project (2005-2008), work has been carried out to eradicate exotic plant species, plant native species, raise public awareness and increase knowledge of the survival of different native species found in thermophilous forest. Rat control programmes are in place on some islands. There are on-going efforts to reintroduce the species to Gran Canaria using birds from La Palma (Barov and Derhé 2011). Breeding facilities have been built and so far 201 individuals have been released on Gran Canaria, with at least 20 chicks hatched in the wild (A. Martín in litt. 2016).

Conservation Actions Proposed
Conduct a population census and initiate monitoring. Ensure the adequate protection of key sites, particularly as yet unprotected ones on La Gomera and La Palma. Continue to promote the restoration of dry and laurel forests. Avoid further damage to laurel forest from commercial forestry. Control introduced predators at breeding sites, particularly on Tenerife. Control illegal hunting, especially at drinking sites. Continue on-going education and awareness campaigns. Develop and implement a new national Conservation Plan (J. A. Lorenzo in litt. 2016).

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that, while this species is known from a restricted area, it is confined to a karst formation close to a temple, where cultural taboos are likely to limit any disturbance, and no threats have been identified.
habitat: This species inhabits a karst formation in a lowland limestone forest surrounded by highly disturbed, urbanized habitat (Wood et al. 2017). Wood et al. (2017) suggest it is a diurnal species that shelters in vegetation at night.
threats: This species was found adjacent to temple grounds, where no disturbance to its habitat is likely due to local cultural taboos (M. Cota pers. comm. 2017).
population: One male and one female adult specimen were collected at Phung Chang Cave (Wood et al. 2017). It was fairly common when collected (M. Cota pers. comm. 2017).
range: This species is known only from the Phung Chang Cave, Phang-nga, southwestern Thailand (Wood et al. 2017). It may have a slightly larger range along the adjacent karst ridge, but not more than a few kilometres in extent (M. Cota pers. comm. 2017).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: No conservation measures are in place or needed. Although this species is not found in a protected area, cultural norms will limit disturbance to this area.

rationale: This species declined in the past owing to road building schemes and principally predation by introduced cats. However, these threats have ceased and the population may now begin to increase. Given the species's longevity it is retained as Near Threatened on the basis of the past declines.
habitat: Breeding takes place in burrows in sandy soil and rocky crevices. Birds attend colonies for at least 10 months of the year, arriving nocturnally to reduce predation by Western Gulls Larus occidentalis (Keitt et al. 2004) and ravens. Eggs are laid in March and hatching begins in early May (Keitt 1998).
threats: On Natividad, in the past, predation by c.20 feral cats reduced the population causing >1,000 recorded deaths per month prior to their eradication which reduced mortality to less than 100 per month (Keitt et al. undated, 2002). Road construction and the establishment of a small fishing community have decreased breeding habitat and burrows (Keitt 1998), and trampled burrows and lights continue to cause some mortality (Keitt and Albores-Barajas unpublished data).
